Original: Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita mi ritrovai per una selva oscura, ché la diritta via era smarrita
Translate: "In the middle of the path of human life, I found myself in a dark forest, for I had lost the right path."

Original: Ahi quanto a dir qual era è cosa dura esta selva selvaggia e aspra e forte che nel pensier rinova la paura
Translate: "Alas, it is difficult to describe what that forest was like, wild, inextricable and terrible, so that at the very thought it makes the fear return"

Original: Tant’è amara che poco è più morte
Translate: "It is so frightening that death is little more so: "

Original: ma per trattar del ben ch’i’ vi trovai, dirò de l’altre cose ch’i’ v’ ho scorte
Translate: "but to describe the good that I found in it, I will say what other things I have seen in it."

Original: Io non so ben ridir com’i’ v’intrai, tant’era pien di sonno a quel punto che la verace via abbandonai
Translate: "I can't explain how I got in there, so I was full of sleep when I left the right way."

Original: Ma poi ch’i’ fui al piè d’un colle giunto, là dove terminava quella valle che m’avea di paura il cor compunto,  guardai in alto e vidi le sue spalle vestite già de’ raggi del pianeta che mena dritto altrui per ogne calle
Translate: "But after I came to the foot of a hill, where that valley that had made my heart grieved with fear ended, I looked up and saw its peak already illuminated by the rays of the sun, which leads every man to the right path."

Original: Allor fu la paura un poco queta, che nel lago del cor m’era durata la notte ch’i’ passai con tanta pieta
Translate: "Then the fear that I had in my heart, that night that I spent with so much anguish, was a little appeased."

Original: E come quei che con lena affannata, uscito fuor del pelago a la riva, si volge a l’acqua perigliosa e guata,  così l’animo mio, ch’ancor fuggiva, si volse a retro a rimirar lo passo che non lasciò già mai persona viva
Translate: "And as the shipwreck that with its breath of breath, thrown from the sea on the shore, turns and looks at the dangerous waters from which it escaped, so my soul, which was still on the run, turned back to observe the passage that never left any man alive."

Original: Poi ch’èi posato un poco il corpo lasso, ripresi via per la piaggia diserta, sì che ’l piè fermo sempre era ’l più basso
Translate: "After I had rested a little the tired body, I went back to walk along the desert slope of the hill, so that the firmest foot was always the lowest."

Original: Ed ecco, quasi al cominciar de l'erta, una lonza leggera e presta molto, che di pel macolato era coverta
Translate: "And there appeared, almost at the beginning of the ascent, a slender and very agile loin, covered with spotted hair."

Original: e non mi si partia dinanzi al volto, anzi ’mpediva tanto il mio cammino, ch’i’ fui per ritornar più volte vòlto
Translate: "and did not turn away before me, but prevented my journey so much that I thought of going back several times."

Original: Temp’era dal principio del mattino, e ’l sol montava ’n sù con quelle stelle ch’eran con lui quando l’amor divino  mosse di prima quelle cose belle
Translate: "It was the first hours of the morning, and the sun was rising together with that constellation that was with him on the day of Creation, when divine love moved those beautiful things for the first time."

Original: sì ch’a bene sperar m’era cagione di quella fiera a la gaetta pelle  l’ora del tempo e la dolce stagione
Translate: So the time of day and the spring season gave me good reason to hope well about that spotted beast.

Original: ma non sì che paura non mi desse la vista che m'apparve d'un leone
Translate: "but not to the point that I was not afraid of the sight, which appeared to me immediately afterwards, of a lion"

Original: Questi parea che contra me venisse con la test’alta e con rabbiosa fame, sì che parea che l’aere ne tremesse
Translate: "This seemed to come against me, with his head high and with an angry hunger, to the point that even the air seemed to tremble"

Original: Ed una lupa, che di tutte brame sembiava carca ne la sua magrezza, e molte genti fé già viver grame,  questa mi porse tanto di gravezza con la paura ch’uscia di sua vista, ch’io perdei la speranza de l’altezza
Translate: "And behold, a wolf appears, that in her wretchedness seems full of all desires and moved many people to live miserably."

Original: E qual è quei che volontieri acquista, e giugne ’l tempo che perder lo face, che ’n tutti suoi pensier piange e s’attrista
Translate: "This caused me such anguish, with the terror that inspired me his appearance, that I lost the hope of reaching the top of the hill."

Original: tal mi fece la bestia sanza pace, che, venendomi ’ncontro, a poco a poco mi ripigneva là dove ’l sol tace
Translate: "so he made me the beast without peace, that coming against me pushed me little by little down, where there was no sun."

Original: Mentre ch’i’ rovinava in basso loco, dinanzi a li occhi mi si fu offerto chi per lungo silenzio parea fioco
Translate: "While I was slipping down the valley to the forest, someone appeared before my eyes who could not see well by the shadows."

Original: Quando vidi costui nel gran diserto, "Miserere di me", gridai a lui, "qual che tu sii, od ombra od omo certo
Translate: "When I saw him in the wilderness, I cried to him, "Have mercy on me, whoever you are, a soul or a man in the flesh."

Original: Rispuosemi: "Non omo, omo già fui, e li parenti miei furon lombardi, mantoani per patrïa ambedui
Translate: "I replied, "No, I am not a man, I have already been, and my parents were from Lombardy, both natives of Mantua."

Original: Nacqui sub Iulio, ancor che fosse tardi, e vissi a Roma sotto ’l buono Augusto nel tempo de li dèi falsi e bugiardi
Translate: "I was born under the government of Julius Caesar, though in recent years, and lived in Rome under the government of the good emperor Augustus, at the time of the pagan gods."

Original: Poeta fui, e cantai di quel giusto figliuol d’Anchise che venne di Troia, poi che ’l superbo Ilïón fu combusto
Translate: "I was a poet, and I sang of that righteous son of Anchise who fled from Troy after the haughty Ilio was burned."

Original: Ma tu perché ritorni a tanta noia? perché non sali il dilettoso monte ch’è principio e cagion di tutta gioia?"
Translate: "But why do you return to the evil of the forest? Why do you not lead the joyful hill, which is the beginning and cause of all happiness?"

Original: "Or se’ tu quel Virgilio e quella fonte che spandi di parlar sì largo fiume?", rispuos’io lui con vergognosa fronte
Translate: So are you that Virgil and the spring that spreads such a vast river of words?

Original: "O de li altri poeti onore e lume, vagliami ’l lungo studio e ’l grande amore che m’ ha fatto cercar lo tuo volume
Translate: "O you who are the light and guidance of other poets, may the long commitment and great love that have moved me to read your work help me"

Original: Tu se’ lo mio maestro e ’l mio autore, tu se’ solo colui da cu’ io tolsi lo bello stilo che m’ ha fatto onore
Translate: You are my teacher and my model, you are the only one from whom I drew the beautiful style that made me famous

Original: Vedi la bestia per cu’ io mi volsi
Translate: See the beast that turned me around.

Original: aiutami da lei, famoso saggio, ch’ella mi fa tremar le vene e i polsi"
Translate: "Help me from her, a famous wise man, for she makes every drop of my blood tremble"

Original: "A te convien tenere altro vïaggio", rispuose, poi che lagrimar mi vide, "se vuo’ campar d’esto loco selvaggio
Translate: "You must make another journey, he answered me after seeing me weep, if you want to save yourself from this wild place."

Original: ché questa bestia, per la qual tu gride, non lascia altrui passar per la sua via, ma tanto lo ’mpedisce che l’uccide
Translate: "In fact, the beast that makes you scream doesn't let anyone walk his way, but prevents him to the point of killing him."

Original: e ha natura sì malvagia e ria, che mai non empie la bramosa voglia, e dopo ’l pasto ha più fame che pria
Translate: "And he has such an evil and evil disposition that he can never satisfy his lust, and after every meal he is more hungry than before."

Original: Molti son li animali a cui s’ammoglia, e più saranno ancora, infin che ’l veltro verrà, che la farà morir con doglia
Translate: "There are many animals to which she mates, and they will be more and more, until the hunting dog arrives that will cause her to die with pain."

Original: Questi non ciberà terra né peltro, ma sapïenza, amore e virtute, e sua nazion sarà tra feltro e feltro
Translate: "This one will not care for material riches, but only for spiritual riches, and his birth will take place between felt and felt."

Original: Di quella umile Italia fia salute per cui morì la vergine Cammilla, Eurialo e Turno e Niso di ferute
Translate: "It will be the salvation of that humble Italy, so they died in battle Eurialo and Niso, Turno, the virgin Camilla"

Original: Questi la caccerà per ogne villa, fin che l’avrà rimessa ne lo ’nferno, là onde ’nvidia prima dipartilla
Translate: "He will hunt her down for every city, until he has put her back into hell, from where envy brought her forth for the first time."

Original: Ond’io per lo tuo me’ penso e discerno che tu mi segui, e io sarò tua guida, e trarrotti di qui per loco etterno
Translate: "Therefore I think and judge for thy good that thou shouldest follow me, and I will guide thee, and I will take thee away from this place to lead thee to the place of the underworld,

Original: ove udirai le disperate strida, vedrai li antichi spiriti dolenti, ch’a la seconda morte ciascun grida
Translate: "where you will hear the desperate cries and see the ancient souls of the damned, each of whom invokes definitive death"

Original: e vederai color che son contenti nel foco, perché speran di venire quando che sia a le beate genti
Translate: "And then you will see those who are happy to suffer pain, because they hope one day to reach the Blesseds of Paradise."

Original: A le quai poi se tu vorrai salire, anima fia a ciò più di me degna: con lei ti lascerò nel mio partire
Translate: "And if you want to go up and visit the latter, then there will be a soul more worthy of me to guide you: when I go away, I will leave you with her."

Original: ché quello imperador che là sù regna, perch’i’ fu’ ribellante a la sua legge, non vuol che ’n sua città per me si vegna
Translate: "For that emperor who reigns up there does not want me to enter into his city, because I was rebellious to his law."

Original: In tutte parti impera e quivi regge
Translate: God has authority throughout the Universe and in Paradise he governs

Original: quivi è la sua città e l’alto seggio: oh felice colui cu’ ivi elegge
Translate: "Here is his city and his other throne: oh, happy is he who chooses to reside in that place."

Original: E io a lui: "Poeta, io ti richeggio per quello Dio che tu non conoscesti, acciò ch’io fugga questo male e peggio,  che tu mi meni là dov’or dicesti, sì ch’io veggia la porta di san Pietro e color cui tu fai cotanto mesti"
Translate: "And I said unto him, Poet, in the name of that God which thou hast not known, and that I may flee this evil, and some worse, I ask thee to lead thee where thou hast said, that I may see the gate of St. Peter, and them that describe so miserable."

Original: Allor si mosse, e io li tenni dietro
Translate: "Then he set out, and I followed him."

Original: Lo giorno se n’andava, e l’aere bruno toglieva li animai che sono in terra da le fatiche loro
Translate: "The day was almost over, and the darkness took away the animals that are on the ground from their labors."

Original: e io sol uno m’apparecchiava a sostener la guerra sì del cammino e sì de la pietate, che ritrarrà la mente che non erra
Translate: "and I was the only one who prepared to face an anguish and terrible path, which my infallible mind will describe"

Original: O muse, o alto ingegno, or m’aiutate
Translate: "O muse, or high poetic ingenuity, help me"

Original: o mente che scrivesti ciò ch’io vidi, qui si parrà la tua nobilitate
Translate: "O mind, that you wrote down what you saw, here you will have to prove your nobility."

Original: Io cominciai: "Poeta che mi guidi, guarda la mia virtù s’ell’è possente, prima ch’a l’alto passo tu mi fidi
Translate: "I began to say: "Poet who guides me, evaluates if my virtue is sufficient, before leading me on this arduous journey"

Original: Tu dici che di Silvïo il parente, corruttibile ancora, ad immortale secolo andò, e fu sensibilmente
Translate: "You say that Silvio's father, still alive, went into the afterlife in the flesh, with all his body."

Original: Però, se l’avversario d’ogne male cortese i fu, pensando l’alto effetto ch’uscir dovea di lui, e ’l chi e ’l quale  non pare indegno ad omo d’intelletto
Translate: "Therefore, if the enemy of all evil was kind to him, man and his merits do not seem unworthy to a man endowed with intellect, if one thinks of the high effect that was to be produced by him."

Original: ch’e’ fu de l’alma Roma e di suo impero ne l’empireo ciel per padre eletto:  la quale e ’l quale, a voler dir lo vero, fu stabilita per lo loco santo u’ siede il successor del maggior Piero
Translate: "In fact he was chosen in the Empire as the founder of the noble Rome and its empire: and Rome and its empire, to tell the truth, were established as the holy seat where the successor of the first pope resides."

Original: Per quest’andata onde li dai tu vanto, intese cose che furon cagione di sua vittoria e del papale ammanto
Translate: "Thanks to this journey that you narrate, Enea heard things that led him to victory and produced the papal cloak "

Original: Andovvi poi lo Vas d’elezïone, per recarne conforto a quella fede ch’è principio a la via di salvazione
Translate: "Then went there the instrument of choice, to make firm that faith which is the beginning to the way of salvation."

Original: Ma io, perché venirvi? o chi ’l concede? Io non Enëa, io non Paulo sono
Translate: "But why should I go? who grants it? I am not Aeneas, nor St Paul"

Original: me degno a ciò né io né altri ’l crede
Translate: neither I nor anyone else believes me to be up to this task.

Original: Per che, se del venire io m’abbandono, temo che la venuta non sia folle
Translate: "So if I agree to follow you, I fear my journey is madness."

Original: Se’ savio intendi me’ ch’i’ non ragiono"
Translate: "You are wise, you understand better than I can explain"

Original: E qual è quei che disvuol ciò che volle e per novi pensier cangia proposta, sì che dal cominciar tutto si tolle,  tal mi fec’ïo ’n quella oscura costa, perché, pensando, consumai la ’mpresa che fu nel cominciar cotanto tosta
Translate: "And as he who no longer wants what he wanted, and changes his mind because of new thoughts, so that he totally withdraws from his purposes, so I became in those dark places, because thinking about it put an end to the task that was so fast at the beginning."

Original: "S’i’ ho ben la parola tua intesa", rispuose del magnanimo quell’ombra, "l’anima tua è da viltade offesa
Translate: "The shadow of that noble man answered, "If I have understood your words well, your soul is a victim of cowardice, "

Original: la qual molte fïate l’omo ingombra sì che d’onrata impresa lo rivolve, come falso veder bestia quand’ombra
Translate: "which many times oppresses man and causes him to desist from an honorable undertaking, just as a false image makes a beast pummel when it is shaded."

Original: Da questa tema acciò che tu ti solve, dirotti perch’io venni e quel ch’io ’ntesi nel primo punto che di te mi dolve
Translate: "For you to be free from these fears, I will tell you why I came here and what I felt at the first moment I felt pain for you."

Original: Io era tra color che son sospesi, e donna mi chiamò beata e bella, tal che di comandare io la richiesi
Translate: "I was among the suspended souls of Limbo, and he called me a woman so blessed and so beautiful that I asked her to command me."

Original: Lucevan li occhi suoi più che la stella
Translate: His eyes were brighter than a star

Original: e cominciommi a dir soave e piana, con angelica voce, in sua favella:
Translate: "and she began to speak to me in a sweet and sweet tone, with a voice that seemed like the language of an angel:"

Original: "O anima cortese mantoana, di cui la fama ancor nel mondo dura, e durerà quanto ’l mondo lontana,
Translate: ""O noble Mantua soul, whose fame still lasts in the world and will last as long as the world, "

Original: l’amico mio, e non de la ventura, ne la diserta piaggia è impedito sì nel cammin, che vòlt’è per paura
Translate: He who loved me unselfishly on the desert slope of a hill is prevented so much that he turned back for fear

Original: e temo che non sia già sì smarrito, ch’io mi sia tardi al soccorso levata, per quel ch’i’ ho di lui nel cielo udito
Translate: "and I'm afraid he's already so lost that I moved too late to help him, for what I heard about him in heaven."

Original: Or movi, e con la tua parola ornata e con ciò c’ ha mestieri al suo campare, l’aiuta sì ch’i’ ne sia consolata
Translate: "Now move, and with your elegant word, and with what is necessary for his salvation, help him that I may be comforted."

Original: I’ son Beatrice che ti faccio andare
Translate: I'm the one who lets you go. I'm Beatrice.

Original: vegno del loco ove tornar disio
Translate: I come from where I want to come back

Original: amor mi mosse, che mi fa parlare
Translate: Love made me come here to talk to you

Original: Quando sarò dinanzi al segnor mio, di te mi loderò sovente a lui"
Translate: "When I am before God, I will often praise your name"""

Original: Tacette allora, e poi comincia’ io:  "O donna di virtù sola per cui l’umana spezie eccede ogne contento di quel ciel c’ ha minor li cerchi sui,  tanto m’aggrada il tuo comandamento, che l’ubidir, se già fosse, m’è tardi
Translate: "Then he kept quiet, and I said, "O virtuous woman, the only one for whom the human species rises above all that is under the sky of the Moon, your request finds me so in agreement that even if I had obeyed down it would be late."

Original: più non t’è uo’ ch’aprirmi il tuo talento
Translate: All you have to do is tell me what you want.

Original: Ma dimmi la cagion che non ti guardi de lo scender qua giuso in questo centro de l’ampio loco ove tornar tu ardi"
Translate: "But tell me why you are not afraid to go down here, to Hell, from the wider place where you wish to return""

Original: "Da che tu vuo’ saver cotanto a dentro, dirotti brievemente", mi rispuose, "perch’i’ non temo di venir qua entro
Translate: "She said to me, "Because you want more details, I'll explain briefly why I'm not afraid to come in here."

Original: Temer si dee di sole quelle cose c' hanno potenza di fare altrui male
Translate: You have to fear only those things that have the power to hurt others

Original: de l'altre no, ché non son paurose
Translate: "the others are not, for they are not frightening."

Original: I’ son fatta da Dio, sua mercé, tale, che la vostra miseria non mi tange, né fiamma d’esto ’ncendio non m’assale
Translate: "I am made by God, his goodness, so that your misery does not touch me and no flame of Hell can harm me"

Original: Donna è gentil nel ciel che si compiange di questo 'mpedimento ov'io ti mando, sì che duro giudicio là sù frange
Translate: "In heaven there is a noble woman who grieves at this impediment for which I ask for your help, so that she breaks the hard divine judgment."

Original: Questa chiese Lucia in suo dimando e disse: - Or ha bisogno il tuo fedele di te, e io a te lo raccomando -
Translate: She asked to speak to Lucia and said to her: "Now your faithful one needs you and I recommend it to you."

Original: Lucia, nimica di ciascun crudele, si mosse, e venne al loco dov’i’ era, che mi sedea con l’antica Rachele
Translate: "Lucia, the enemy of every cruel man, moved and came where I was, sitting next to the ancient Rachel."

Original: Disse: - Beatrice, loda di Dio vera, ché non soccorri quei che t’amò tanto, ch’uscì per te de la volgare schiera?  Non odi tu la pieta del suo pianto, non vedi tu la morte che ’l combatte su la fiumana ove ’l mar non ha vanto? -
Translate: "He said to me: "Beatrice, the true praise of God, why don't you help him who loved you to the point of rising above the vulgar host?Do you not feel the anguish of his weeping?Do you not see the death fighting on the stormy gorgo of sin?

Original: Al mondo non fur mai persone ratte a far lor pro o a fuggir lor danno, com’io, dopo cotai parole fatte,  venni qua giù del mio beato scanno, fidandomi del tuo parlare onesto, ch’onora te e quei ch’udito l’ hanno"
Translate: "In the world there were never people so quick to pursue their advantage or to flee their harm, as I, after hearing those words, came down here from my heavenly scano, entrusting myself to your noble words that honor you and those who have heard them"""

Original: Poscia che m’ebbe ragionato questo, li occhi lucenti lagrimando volse, per che mi fece del venir più presto
Translate: "After he had told me this, he turned his eyes shining through the weeping, which led me to come soon."

Original: E venni a te così com’ella volse: d’inanzi a quella fiera ti levai che del bel monte il corto andar ti tolse
Translate: And I came to thee as she wanted; and I helped thee out of the beast, which prevented thee an easy ascent to the hill.

Original: Dunque: che è perché, perché restai, perché tanta viltà nel core allette, perché ardire e franchezza non hai,
Translate: "So what is it? why, why are you staying here? why are you cultivating so much cowardice in your heart? why do you not have courage and determination, "

Original: poscia che tai tre donne benedette curan di te ne la corte del cielo,
Translate: seeing that these three blessed women care for you in the heavenly court

Original: e ’l mio parlar tanto ben ti promette?"
Translate: And my words promise you all good?

Original: Quali fioretti dal notturno gelo chinati e chiusi, poi che ’l sol li ’mbianca, si drizzan tutti aperti in loro stelo,
Translate: "As little flowers closed and turned down by the night frost they all stand open on their stem, after the sun has illuminated them, "

Original: tal mi fec’io di mia virtude stanca, e tanto buono ardire al cor mi corse, ch’i’ cominciai come persona franca:
Translate: "so I did with my weary virtue, and to my heart came so much courage that I began to say, as a refreshed person:"

Original: "Oh pietosa colei che mi soccorse
Translate: "Oh merciful woman who helped me, "

Original: e te cortese ch’ubidisti tosto a le vere parole che ti porse
Translate: And thou gracious that thou obeyedst at once the true words which he spake unto thee,

Original: Tu m’ hai con disiderio il cor disposto sì al venir con le parole tue, ch’i’ son tornato nel primo proposto
Translate: "You, with your words, have set my heart to the desire to come, to the point that I have returned to the first purpose."

Original: Or va, ch’un sol volere è d’ambedue: tu duca, tu segnore e tu maestro"
Translate: "Now go, for we both want the same thing: you are my guide, my lord, my teacher."

Original: Così li dissi e poi che mosso fue,
Translate: "So I told him, and after he had set out on his way "

Original: intrai per lo cammino alto e silvestro
Translate: undertaken the arduous and wild path

Original: ’Per me si va ne la città dolente, per me si va ne l'etterno dolore, per me si va tra la perduta gente
Translate: ""Through me you enter into the city of pain, through me you go into eternal pain, through me you go among the lost souls "

Original: Giustizia mosse il mio alto fattore
Translate: "Justice has made my high Creator act,"

Original: fecemi la divina podestate, la somma sapïenza e ’l primo amore
Translate: "They have built me divine power, supreme wisdom and first love."

Original: Dinanzi a me non fuor cose create se non etterne, e io etterno duro
Translate: "Before me nothing was created except eternal, and I will endure eternally"

Original: Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch’intrate’
Translate: "Leave all hope, you who enter here"""

Original: Queste parole di colore oscuro vid’ïo scritte al sommo d’una porta
Translate: "I saw these words written in dark color at the top of a door, "

Original: per ch’io: "Maestro, il senso lor m’è duro"
Translate: "So I said, "Master, I don't understand the meaning"

Original: Ed elli a me, come persona accorta: "Qui si convien lasciare ogne sospetto
Translate: "And he answered me, as a wise person: "Here it is necessary to abandon all hesitation, "

Original: ogne viltà convien che qui sia morta
Translate: and you don't have to be cowardly

Original: Noi siam venuti al loco ov’i’ t’ ho detto che tu vedrai le genti dolorose c’ hanno perduto il ben de l’intelletto"
Translate: "We have come to the place where, as I have told you, you will see the damned souls who have lost the light of divine intelligence."

Original: E poi che la sua mano a la mia puose con lieto volto, ond’io mi confortai, mi mise dentro a le segrete cose
Translate: "And when he had taken me by the hand, with a smiling face that comforted me, he brought me into that place separate from the world of the living. "

Original: Quivi sospiri, pianti e alti guai risonavan per l’aere sanza stelle, per ch’io al cominciar ne lagrimai
Translate: "Here sighs, weeps and loud laments resonated in that starless air, so that at first I wept."

Original: Diverse lingue, orribili favelle, parole di dolore, accenti d’ira, voci alte e fioche, e suon di man con elle  facevano un tumulto, il qual s’aggira sempre in quell’aura sanza tempo tinta, come la rena quando turbo spira
Translate: "Weird tongues, horrible pronunciations, words of pain, imprecations of anger, sharp and faint voices, and a sound of hands with them created a noise, which continually resonates in that eternally dark air, just like the sand when the storm blows."

Original: E io ch’avea d’error la testa cinta, dissi: "Maestro, che è quel ch’i’ odo? e che gent’è che par nel duol sì vinta?"
Translate: "And I, who had my head full of doubts, said: "Master, what is what I feel? and who are these who seem so overwhelmed by pain?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Questo misero modo tegnon l’anime triste di coloro che visser sanza ’nfamia e sanza lodo
Translate: He said to me, "This is the poor condition of the sad souls of those who lived without infamy and without merit."

Original: Mischiate sono a quel cattivo coro de li angeli che non furon ribelli né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro
Translate: "They are mixed with that despicable set of angels who did not rebel against God, nor remained faithful to him, but were neutral"

Original: Caccianli i ciel per non esser men belli, né lo profondo inferno li riceve, ch’alcuna gloria i rei avrebber d’elli"
Translate: "The heavens cast them out so as not to lose their beauty, neither does Hell welcome them into its depths, for the damned could receive any glory from their presence."

Original: E io: "Maestro, che è tanto greve a lor che lamentar li fa sì forte?"
Translate: "And I: "Master, what is so annoying to them, that they complain so loudly? "

Original: Rispuose: "Dicerolti molto breve
Translate: He said to me, "I'll tell you very briefly."

Original: Questi non hanno speranza di morte, e la lor cieca vita è tanto bassa, che ’nvidïosi son d’ogne altra sorte
Translate: "These souls cannot hope to die, and their present condition is so despicable that they envy any other fate."

Original: Fama di loro il mondo esser non lassa
Translate: The world doesn't let there be any memory of them

Original: misericordia e giustizia li sdegna:
Translate: God's mercy and justice disdain them

Original: non ragioniam di lor, ma guarda e passa"
Translate: "Let's not waste time talking about them, but take a quick look and move on."

Original: E io, che riguardai, vidi una ’nsegna che girando correva tanto ratta, che d’ogne posa mi parea indegna
Translate: "And I, looking, saw a sign that, turning on itself, ran so quickly that it seemed never to stop."

Original: e dietro le venìa sì lunga tratta di gente, ch’i’ non averei creduto che morte tanta n’avesse disfatta
Translate: "and behind it came such a long line of souls, that I would never believe that death had destroyed so many of them. "

Original: Poscia ch’io v’ebbi alcun riconosciuto, vidi e conobbi l’ombra di colui che fece per viltade il gran rifiuto
Translate: "After I had recognized one of them, I saw and recognized the shadow of him who vilely refused."

Original: Incontanente intesi e certo fui che questa era la setta d’i cattivi, a Dio spiacenti e a’ nemici sui
Translate: I immediately understood, and I was certain that this was the host of the cowards who displeased God as much as his enemies.

Original: Questi sciaurati, che mai non fur vivi, erano ignudi e stimolati molto da mosconi e da vespe ch’eran ivi
Translate: "These wretches, who never really lived, were naked and points continually from flies and wasps all around"

Original: Elle rigavan lor di sangue il volto, che, mischiato di lagrime, a’ lor piedi da fastidiosi vermi era ricolto
Translate: "They made their faces bleed, and they fell to the ground with tears, and were gathered with repulsive worms."

Original: E poi ch’a riguardar oltre mi diedi, vidi genti a la riva d’un gran fiume
Translate: "And when I looked beyond, I saw souls on the bank of a great river."

Original: per ch’io dissi: "Maestro, or mi concedi  ch’i’ sappia quali sono, e qual costume le fa di trapassar parer sì pronte, com’i’ discerno per lo fioco lume"
Translate: "So I said, "Master, now allow me to know who those souls are, and what instinct makes them seem so anxious to pass on the other side, just as I seem to see in the little light."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Le cose ti fier conte quando noi fermerem li nostri passi su la trista riviera d’Acheronte"
Translate: And he said unto me, The things shall be clear unto thee, when we shall come to the sad bank of the river Acheron.

Original: Allor con li occhi vergognosi e bassi, temendo no ’l mio dir li fosse grave, infino al fiume del parlar mi trassi
Translate: "Then, lowering my eyes with shame, in the fear that I might annoy him, I uttered no word to the river."

Original: Ed ecco verso noi venir per nave un vecchio, bianco per antico pelo, gridando: "Guai a voi, anime prave
Translate: "And behold, an old man, with his face covered with a white beard, came to us in a boat, crying out, "Woe to you, wicked souls."

Original: Non isperate mai veder lo cielo: i’ vegno per menarvi a l’altra riva ne le tenebre etterne, in caldo e ’n gelo
Translate: "Do not hope to ever see the sky: I come to lead you to the other side, into eternal darkness, between flames and ice."

Original: E tu che se’ costì, anima viva, pàrtiti da cotesti che son morti"
Translate: "And you who are there, living soul, away from them who are dead"

Original: Ma poi che vide ch’io non mi partiva,  disse: "Per altra via, per altri porti verrai a piaggia, non qui, per passare:
Translate: " But because he saw that I was not leaving, he said: "You will come to the landing place by another way, by other ports, certainly not here to pass by "

Original: più lieve legno convien che ti porti"
Translate: It is established that it will bring you a lighter ship than mine.

Original: E ’l duca lui: "Caron, non ti crucciare: vuolsi così colà dove si puote ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare"
Translate: "And the teacher said to him, 'Caron, do not be distressed: you want it so up there where everything you want is possible, so don't say anything else."

Original: Quinci fuor quete le lanose gote al nocchier de la livida palude, che ’ntorno a li occhi avea di fiamme rote
Translate: "From there onward the fur-covered cheeks of the ferryman of that swampy slum, who had his eyes surrounded by wheels of flames"

Original: Ma quell’anime, ch’eran lasse e nude, cangiar colore e dibattero i denti, ratto che ’nteser le parole crude
Translate: "But those souls, who were naked and prostrated, changed color and beat their teeth, as soon as they heard his words raw."

Original: Bestemmiavano Dio e lor parenti, l’umana spezie e ’l loco e ’l tempo e ’l seme di lor semenza e di lor nascimenti
Translate: "They blasphemed God and their parents, the human species, the place, the time and the seed of their conception and birth."

Original: Poi si ritrasser tutte quante insieme, forte piangendo, a la riva malvagia ch’attende ciascun uom che Dio non teme
Translate: "Then they all went together, weeping desperately, to the shore of the infernal river that awaits every man who does not fear God."

Original: Caron dimonio, con occhi di bragia loro accennando, tutte le raccoglie
Translate: "The devil Charon, with his eyes flaming like fire, giving them hints, gathers them all"

Original: batte col remo qualunque s'adagia
Translate: beats with his oar any of them that stretches out

Original: Come d’autunno si levan le foglie l’una appresso de l’altra, fin che ’l ramo vede a la terra tutte le sue spoglie,  similemente il mal seme d’Adamo gittansi di quel lito ad una ad una, per cenni come augel per suo richiamo
Translate: "As in autumn the leaves fall, one after the other, until the branch sees to the ground all his garments, likewise Adam's bad descent throws itself from that shore to one by one, responding to the hints of Charon, as a bird responds to the call."

Original: Così sen vanno su per l’onda bruna, e avanti che sien di là discese, anche di qua nuova schiera s’auna
Translate: "So they go along the dark waters of the river, and before they went down to the other side, from this side there is another host."

Original: "Figliuol mio", disse 'l maestro cortese, "quelli che muoion ne l'ira di Dio tutti convegnon qui d'ogne paese
Translate: "My son," said the noble master, "all those who die in disgrace gather here from all the world:"

Original: e pronti sono a trapassar lo rio, ché la divina giustizia li sprona, sì che la tema si volve in disio
Translate: "and they are anxious to pass through the river, for the righteousness of God spurs them, and causes fear to turn into desire."

Original: Quinci non passa mai anima buona
Translate: "No soul that is good passes through here,

Original: e però, se Caron di te si lagna, ben puoi sapere omai che ’l suo dir suona"
Translate: "So if Charon complains about you, you can understand what his words mean by now."

Original: Finito questo, la buia campagna tremò sì forte, che de lo spavento la mente di sudore ancor mi bagna
Translate: "At the end of this, those dark places trembled so strongly that, from fear, the only memory wets me with sweat"

Original: La terra lagrimosa diede vento, che balenò una luce vermiglia la qual mi vinse ciascun sentimento
Translate: "The earth weeped with tears produced a wind, which caused a reddish light to flash that overwhelms all my senses."

Original: e caddi come l’uom cui sonno piglia
Translate: And I fell like a man of sleep.

Original: Ruppemi l’alto sonno ne la testa un greve truono, sì ch’io mi riscossi come persona ch’è per forza desta
Translate: "A strong thunder interrupted sleep in my head, so that I shook like someone who woke up on top."

Original: e l’occhio riposato intorno mossi, dritto levato, e fiso riguardai per conoscer lo loco dov’io fossi
Translate: "and I moved around my rested gaze, staring straight at him, and I watched carefully to see where I was."

Original: Vero è che ’n su la proda mi trovai de la valle d’abisso dolorosa che ’ntrono accoglie d’infiniti guai
Translate: "In fact, I found myself on the extreme edge of the painful valley of Hell, which embraces in itself a rumble of infinite lamentations"

Original: Oscura e profonda era e nebulosa tanto che, per ficcar lo viso a fondo, io non vi discernea alcuna cosa
Translate: "It was so dark, so deep and nebula that while I looked at the bottom, I couldn't see anything."

Original: "Or discendiam qua giù nel cieco mondo", cominciò il poeta tutto smorto
Translate: "Now we begin to descend into the blind world," began Virgilio pale in his face."

Original: "Io sarò primo, e tu sarai secondo"
Translate: "I'll go first, you'll follow me."

Original: E io, che del color mi fui accorto, dissi: "Come verrò, se tu paventi che suoli al mio dubbiare esser conforto?"
Translate: "And I, aware of his pallor, said, "How can I come, if you, who usually comfort all my doubts, are frightened?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "L’angoscia de le genti che son qua giù, nel viso mi dipigne quella pietà che tu per tema senti
Translate: He said to me, "The anguish of the souls who are relegated here paints on my face that torment that you believe fear."

Original: Andiam, ché la via lunga ne sospigne"
Translate: "Let's go, for the journey is long and we don't have time to waste"

Original: Così si mise e così mi fé intrare nel primo cerchio che l’abisso cigne
Translate: So he proceeded and introduced me into the first circle that surrounds the hell's chasm.

Original: Quivi, secondo che per ascoltare, non avea pianto mai che di sospiri che l’aura etterna facevan tremare
Translate: "Here, listening, they felt only sighs, which made the eternal air tremble"

Original: ciò avvenia di duol sanza martìri, ch’avean le turbe, ch’eran molte e grandi, d’infanti e di femmine e di viri
Translate: "This was due to the pain without torments suffered by the hosts of souls, which were very numerous, of children, women and men."

Original: Lo buon maestro a me: "Tu non dimandi che spiriti son questi che tu vedi? Or vo’ che sappi, innanzi che più andi,  ch’ei non peccaro
Translate: "The good teacher said to me, "Who are these spirits you see?" Before you go any further, I want you to know that they didn't sin."

Original: e s’elli hanno mercedi, non basta, perché non ebber battesmo, ch’è porta de la fede che tu credi
Translate: "and if they have merit, this is not enough, because they have not received the baptism that admits to the faith in which you believe."

Original: e s’e’ furon dinanzi al cristianesmo, non adorar debitamente a Dio: e di questi cotai son io medesmo
Translate: "and if they lived before Christianity, they did not worship God properly: I myself am part of this category"

Original: Per tai difetti, non per altro rio, semo perduti, e sol di tanto offesi che sanza speme vivemo in disio"
Translate: "We are lost for this guilt and not for other sins, and our only pain is to live in a hopeless desire"

Original: Gran duol mi prese al cor quando lo ’ntesi, però che gente di molto valore conobbi che ’n quel limbo eran sospesi
Translate: "When I heard this I felt a great pain in the heart, for I understood that in that Limbo were suspended souls of very eminent characters."

Original: "Dimmi, maestro mio, dimmi, segnore", comincia’ io per volere esser certo di quella fede che vince ogne errore:
Translate: "Tell me, O my teacher and lord, I began to make sure of that faith that takes away all doubt:"

Original: "uscicci mai alcuno, o per suo merto o per altrui, che poi fosse beato?"
Translate: "Did it ever happen that someone came out of this place, either by virtue of himself or of others, who would then become blessed? "

Original: E quei che ’ntese il mio parlar coverto,  rispuose: "Io era nuovo in questo stato, quando ci vidi venire un possente, con segno di vittoria coronato
Translate: "And Virgilio, who understood my veiled words, answered and said, 'I was just in this condition, when I saw a mighty man enter here, bearing the signs of victory."

Original: Trasseci l’ombra del primo parente, d’Abèl suo figlio e quella di Noè, di Moïsè legista e ubidente
Translate: "He brought forth from here the shadow of the first father, his son Abel, and Noah, and Moses the lawgiver, obedient."

Original: Abraàm patrïarca e Davìd re, Israèl con lo padre e co’ suoi nati e con Rachele, per cui tanto fé,
Translate: "that of the patriarch Abraham and King David, Israel with his sons and his wife Rachel, for whom he did so much."

Original: e altri molti, e feceli beati
Translate: "and many others, and made them all blessed"

Original: E vo’ che sappi che, dinanzi ad essi, spiriti umani non eran salvati"
Translate: "And I want you to know that, before them, no spirit could be saved"

Original: Non lasciavam l’andar perch’ei dicessi, ma passavam la selva tuttavia, la selva, dico, di spiriti spessi
Translate: "While Virgil spoke, we did not cease to walk, but surpassed that dense crowd of spirits."

Original: Non era lunga ancor la nostra via di qua dal sonno, quand’io vidi un foco ch’emisperio di tenebre vincia
Translate: "We had not gone a long way since I woke up, when I saw a light that surpassed a hemisphere of darkness."

Original: Di lungi n’eravamo ancora un poco, ma non sì ch’io non discernessi in parte ch’orrevol gente possedea quel loco
Translate: "We were still at a certain distance from it, but not so much that I could not understand that that place was occupied by honorable spirits"

Original: "O tu ch’onori scïenzïa e arte, questi chi son c’ hanno cotanta onranza, che dal modo de li altri li diparte?"
Translate: "Who are these who have so much consideration that they have a different condition than other souls?"

Original: E quelli a me: "L’onrata nominanza che di lor suona sù ne la tua vita, grazïa acquista in ciel che sì li avanza"
Translate: "And Virgil answered me, "The excellent fame that still survives them in the earthly world, acquires them a grace in Heaven that distinguishes them from other spirits."

Original: Intanto voce fu per me udita: "Onorate l’altissimo poeta
Translate: In the meantime I heard a voice: "Render honor to the very high poet:

Original: l’ombra sua torna, ch’era dipartita"
Translate: "His soul, which was gone, returns"

Original: Poi che la voce fu restata e queta, vidi quattro grand’ombre a noi venire: sembianz’avevan né trista né lieta
Translate: "After the voice ceased and rested, I saw four great souls coming to meet us: they did not look sad, nor glad."

Original: Lo buon maestro cominciò a dire: "Mira colui con quella spada in mano, che vien dinanzi ai tre sì come sire:  quelli è Omero poeta sovrano
Translate: "The good teacher began to say, "Look to him who has that sword in his hand, who precedes others as their master: that is Homer, the greatest of all poets."

Original: l’altro è Orazio satiro che vene
Translate: "The other who follows him is Horace, author of the Satire"

Original: Ovidio è ’l terzo, e l’ultimo Lucano
Translate: the third is Ovid, and the last is Lucan.

Original: Però che ciascun meco si convene nel nome che sonò la voce sola, fannomi onore, e di ciò fanno bene"
Translate: "For every one of them has in common with me the name which he uttered that single voice, they honor me, and in this they do well."

Original: Così vid’i’ adunar la bella scola di quel segnor de l’altissimo canto che sovra li altri com’aquila vola
Translate: "So I saw the beautiful poetic school of the gentleman who wrote very high verses, flying over others like an eagle"

Original: Da ch’ebber ragionato insieme alquanto, volsersi a me con salutevol cenno, e ’l mio maestro sorrise di tanto
Translate: "After they had spoken a little to each other, they addressed me with greetings and my teacher smiled at this."

Original: e più d’onore ancora assai mi fenno, ch’e’ sì mi fecer de la loro schiera, sì ch’io fui sesto tra cotanto senno
Translate: "and they made me an even greater honor, for they welcomed me into their ranks, so that I was the sixth member of that very sensible group."

Original: Così andammo infino a la lumera, parlando cose che ’l tacere è bello, sì com’era ’l parlar colà dov’era
Translate: "In this way we went to the light, saying things that are nice to keep quiet, just as it was nice to talk about them in that place."

Original: Venimmo al piè d’un nobile castello, sette volte cerchiato d’alte mura, difeso intorno d’un bel fiumicello
Translate: "We reached the foot of a noble castle, surrounded by seven orders of walls and protected around by a beautiful river"

Original: Questo passammo come terra dura
Translate: We passed it as if it were of earth.

Original: per sette porte intrai con questi savi: giugnemmo in prato di fresca verdura
Translate: And I went in with these wise men through seven gates, and came into a lawn of fresh green grass.

Original: Genti v’eran con occhi tardi e gravi, di grande autorità ne’ lor sembianti: parlavan rado, con voci soavi
Translate: "There were souls with calm and austere looks, with a very authoritative look: they spoke little, with sweet voices"

Original: Traemmoci così da l’un de’ canti, in loco aperto, luminoso e alto, sì che veder si potien tutti quanti
Translate: "We took ourselves to a corner, to an open spot, bright and high, so that we could see them all."

Original: Colà diritto, sovra ’l verde smalto, mi fuor mostrati li spiriti magni, che del vedere in me stesso m’essalto
Translate: "There in front, on the green grass as enamel, were shown to me the magnificent spirits, and in myself I exalt myself to have seen them."

Original: I’ vidi Eletra con molti compagni, tra ’ quai conobbi Ettòr ed Enea, Cesare armato con li occhi grifagni
Translate: "I saw Elettra with many companions, including Hector and Aeneas, Caesar armed with menacing eyes."

Original: Vidi Cammilla e la Pantasilea
Translate: I saw Camilla and Pentesilea

Original: da l’altra parte vidi ’l re Latino che con Lavina sua figlia sedea
Translate: "On the opposite side I saw King Latin, who sat with his daughter Lavinia"

Original: Vidi quel Bruto che cacciò Tarquino, Lucrezia, Iulia, Marzïa e Corniglia
Translate: "I saw Lucio Bruto who chased Tarquinio il Superbo, Lucrezia, Giulia, Marzia and Cornelia"

Original: e solo, in parte, vidi ’l Saladino
Translate: "and all alone, in one corner, I saw the Saladin"

Original: Poi ch’innalzai un poco più le ciglia, vidi ’l maestro di color che sanno seder tra filosofica famiglia
Translate: "After looking up a little more, I saw the master of all the wise who sat among other philosophers."

Original: Tutti lo miran, tutti onor li fanno: quivi vid’ïo Socrate e Platone, che ’nnanzi a li altri più presso li stanno
Translate: "Everyone admires him, all honour him: here I saw Socrates and Plato, who are closer to him than others."

Original: Democrito che ’l mondo a caso pone, Dïogenès, Anassagora e Tale, Empedoclès, Eraclito e Zenone
Translate: " Democritus, which says that the world is ruled by chance, Diogenes, Anassagoras and Tales, Empedocles, Heraclitus and Zenon"

Original: e vidi il buono accoglitor del quale, Dïascoride dico
Translate: "and I saw the wise man who described the qualities of plants, that is, Dioscorides."

Original: e vidi Orfeo, Tulïo e Lino e Seneca morale
Translate: "And I saw Orpheus, and Cicero, and Lino, and the philosopher Seneca."

Original: Euclide geomètra e Tolomeo, Ipocràte, Avicenna e Galïeno, Averoìs che ’l gran comento feo
Translate: " Euclid, founder of geometry, and Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Avicenna and Galen, and Averroe who wrote the great commentary "

Original: Io non posso ritrar di tutti a pieno, però che sì mi caccia il lungo tema, che molte volte al fatto il dir vien meno
Translate: "I cannot speak in detail of everyone, for the vastness of matter impels me to such an extent that, often, I must omit details."

Original: La sesta compagnia in due si scema: per altra via mi mena il savio duca, fuor de la queta, ne l’aura che trema
Translate: "The group of six poets is divided into two: the wise master leads me on another road, out of the quiet air and in the one that is stormy."

Original: E vegno in parte ove non è che luca
Translate: And I come to a part where there is nothing that is enlightened

Original: Così discesi del cerchio primaio  giù nel secondo, che men loco cinghia e tanto più dolor, che punge a guaio
Translate: "So I descended from the first circle to the second, which encircles a smaller space, but contains so much greater pain that drives to complain"

Original: Stavvi Minòs orribilmente, e ringhia: essamina le colpe ne l’intrata
Translate: Minos stands horribly on the threshold and growls: examines the sins of the damned who appear

Original: giudica e manda secondo ch’avvinghia
Translate: He judges them, and assigns them according to how he twists his tail.

Original: Dico che quando l’anima mal nata li vien dinanzi, tutta si confessa
Translate: "I say that when the damned soul comes before him, it makes full confession"

Original: e quel conoscitor de le peccata  vede qual loco d’inferno è da essa
Translate: and that knowledgeer of sins establishes which area of Hell to go to

Original: cignesi con la coda tante volte quantunque gradi vuol che giù sia messa
Translate: He girds himself with his tail so many times how many are the Circles that the damned must descend

Original: Sempre dinanzi a lui ne stanno molte: vanno a vicenda ciascuna al giudizio, dicono e odono e poi son giù volte
Translate: "In front of him there are always many souls one after the other going to submit to his judgment they speak and listen, then they rushed down."

Original: "O tu che vieni al doloroso ospizio", disse Minòs a me quando mi vide, lasciando l’atto di cotanto offizio,  "guarda com’entri e di cui tu ti fide
Translate: "And Minos, when he saw me, said this to me, leaving aside for a moment his high task: "O you who come to this place of sorrow, take care of the way you enter and who you are entrusting yourself to."

Original: non t’inganni l’ampiezza de l’intrare
Translate: Do not deceive yourself with the ease of entry

Original: E ’l duca mio a lui: "Perché pur gride?  Non impedir lo suo fatale andare: vuolsi così colà dove si puote ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare"
Translate: "And Virgilio answered, "Why do you keep shouting?Don't prevent his journey from God's will: so you want in Heaven, where everything you want is possible, so don't say anything else."

Original: Or incomincian le dolenti note a farmisi sentire
Translate: Now I'm starting to feel the painful notes

Original: or son venuto là dove molto pianto mi percuote
Translate: Now I have come to a place where much suffering strikes me

Original: Io venni in loco d’ogne luce muto, che mugghia come fa mar per tempesta, se da contrari venti è combattuto
Translate: "I came to a totally dark place, which resounds like the stormy sea when it blows opposite winds"

Original: La bufera infernal, che mai non resta, mena li spirti con la sua rapina
Translate: "The infernal storm, which is incessant, rapinously drags souls"

Original: voltando e percotendo li molesta
Translate: tormenting them by beating them and beating them

Original: Quando giungon davanti a la ruina, quivi le strida, il compianto, il lamento
Translate: "When they come in front of the ruin, then they scream, cry, complain."

Original: bestemmian quivi la virtù divina
Translate: Here they blaspheme God

Original: Intesi ch’a così fatto tormento enno dannati i peccator carnali, che la ragion sommettono al talento
Translate: "I knew that the sinners of lust, who submit reason to pleasure, are damned to this penalty."

Original: E come li stornei ne portan l’ali nel freddo tempo, a schiera larga e piena, così quel fiato li spiriti mali
Translate: "And as in the winter the stunners are carried in flight by their wings, forming a broad host, so the wind carries the evil spirits."

Original: di qua, di là, di giù, di sù li mena
Translate: "Drags them here and there, up and down"

Original: nulla speranza li conforta mai, non che di posa, ma di minor pena
Translate: "they have no hope of comforting them, neither of rest nor of a reduction of punishment."

Original: E come i gru van cantando lor lai, faccendo in aere di sé lunga riga, così vid’io venir, traendo guai,  ombre portate da la detta briga
Translate: "And as the cranes make out their laments, forming a long line in the sky, so I saw coming sighing souls, carried by that storm."

Original: per ch’i’ dissi: "Maestro, chi son quelle genti che l’aura nera sì gastiga?"
Translate: "So I said, "Master, who are those souls chastised by the dark blizzard?"

Original: "La prima di color di cui novelle tu vuo' saper", mi disse quelli allotta, "fu imperadrice di molte favelle
Translate: "The first of those of whom you want to hear," answered Virgil, "she was the empress of many peoples."

Original: A vizio di lussuria fu sì rotta, che libito fé licito in sua legge, per tòrre il biasmo in che era condotta
Translate: "He was so devoted to the habit of lust, that he made lawful in his law all that she liked, to eliminate the moral condemnation that was due to her."

Original: Ell’è Semiramìs, di cui si legge che succedette a Nino e fu sua sposa: tenne la terra che ’l Soldan corregge
Translate: "She is Semiramide, of whom it is said that she was married to Nino and then succeeded: she ruled the land which is now ruled by the Soldano."

Original: L’altra è colei che s’ancise amorosa, e ruppe fede al cener di Sicheo
Translate: "The other is the one who committed suicide out of love, and did not keep faith in the memory of her husband Sicheo"

Original: poi è Cleopatràs lussurïosa
Translate: Then there's the lustful Cleopatra.

Original: Elena vedi, per cui tanto reo tempo si volse, e vedi ’l grande Achille, che con amore al fine combatteo
Translate: "See Elena, so you fought a long and bloody war, and you see the great Achilles, who fought for loving purposes."

Original: Vedi Parìs, Tristano"
Translate: "See Paride, Tristano"

Original: e più di mille ombre mostrommi e nominommi a dito, ch’amor di nostra vita dipartille
Translate: "and pointed to me with his finger more than a thousand souls, who died because of love"

Original: Poscia ch’io ebbi ’l mio dottore udito nomar le donne antiche e ’ cavalieri, pietà mi giunse, e fui quasi smarrito
Translate: "After hearing my teacher mention ancient women and knights, I was soon disturbed and almost lost."

Original: I’ cominciai: "Poeta, volontieri parlerei a quei due che ’nsieme vanno, e paion sì al vento esser leggeri"
Translate: "I began: "Poet, I would gladly speak to those two who fly together and seem to be transported so lightly by the wind"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Vedrai quando saranno più presso a noi
Translate: He said to me, "Wait when they're closer to us."

Original: e tu allor li priega per quello amor che i mena, ed ei verranno"
Translate: Then pray to them in the name of that love that draws them, and they will come.

Original: Sì tosto come il vento a noi li piega, mossi la voce: "O anime affannate, venite a noi parlar, s’altri nol niega
Translate: "As soon as the wind brought them to us, I began to speak: "O souls who are drowned, come and speak to us if God allows you to."

Original: Quali colombe dal disio chiamate con l’ali alzate e ferme al dolce nido vegnon per l’aere, dal voler portate
Translate: "As the doves called by desire fly to the sweet nest, with their wings firm and lifted up, carried by desire, "

Original: cotali uscir de la schiera ov’è Dido, a noi venendo per l’aere maligno, sì forte fu l’affettüoso grido
Translate: "In the same way the two came out of the army of Dido, coming to us through the infernal air, so strong and affectionate was my call."

Original: "O animal grazïoso e benigno che visitando vai per l’aere perso noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,  se fosse amico il re de l’universo, noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace, poi c’ hai pietà del nostro mal perverso
Translate: "O kind and benevolent creature, who in the dark air visit us who dyed the world of blood, if the king of the universe were our friend we would ask him to give you peace, seeing that he shows mercy on our terrible evil."

Original: Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace, noi udiremo e parleremo a voi, mentre che ’l vento, come fa, ci tace
Translate: "We will listen to you and we will tell you what you want, while the wind is silent as it is at this point."

Original: Siede la terra dove nata fui su la marina dove ’l Po discende per aver pace co’ seguaci sui
Translate: "The land where I was born rises at the mouth of the Po, where the river flows into the sea to find peace with its tributaries"

Original: Amor, ch'al cor gentil ratto s'apprende, prese costui de la bella persona che mi fu tolta
Translate: "Love, which immediately clings to the noble heart, took him for the beautiful body that was taken from me, "

Original: e 'l modo ancor m'offende
Translate: and the way still hurts me

Original: Amor, ch’a nullo amato amar perdona, mi prese del costui piacer sì forte, che, come vedi, ancor non m’abbandona
Translate: "Love, which does not allow anyone who is loved not to return, took me by the beauty of him with such strength that, as you see, he does not abandon me even now."

Original: Amor condusse noi ad una morte
Translate: Love led us to the same death:

Original: Caina attende chi a vita ci spense"
Translate: Cain waits for the one who killed us.

Original: Queste parole da lor ci fuor porte
Translate: They told us these words.

Original: Quand’io intesi quell’anime offense, china’ il viso, e tanto il tenni basso, fin che ’l poeta mi disse: "Che pense?"
Translate: "When I heard those souls offended, I looked down and kept it low for so long that in the end Virgil said to me, "What do you think?"

Original: Quando rispuosi, cominciai: "Oh lasso, quanti dolci pensier, quanto disio menò costoro al doloroso passo
Translate: "When I answered, I said, 'Alas, how many sweet thoughts, how much desire they took these two to the painful step'"

Original: Poi mi rivolsi a loro e parla’ io, e cominciai: "Francesca, i tuoi martìri a lagrimar mi fanno tristo e pio
Translate: "Then I turned to them and said, "Francesca, your pains make me sad and make me cry."

Original: Ma dimmi: al tempo d’i dolci sospiri, a che e come concedette amore che conosceste i dubbiosi disiri?"
Translate: "But tell me: at the time of your relationship, how and under what circumstances did Love allow you to know the doubtful desires?"

Original: E quella a me: "Nessun maggior dolore che ricordarsi del tempo felice ne la miseria
Translate: And she said to me, "There is no greater pain than remembering the happy time when you are miserable."

Original: e ciò sa 'l tuo dottore
Translate: And your teacher knows that.

Original: Ma s’a conoscer la prima radice del nostro amor tu hai cotanto affetto, dirò come colui che piange e dice
Translate: "But if you have so much desire to know the origin of our love, then I will do as he who weeps and speaks at the same time."

Original: Noi leggiavamo un giorno per diletto di Lancialotto come amor lo strinse
Translate: One day we read for leisure the book about Lancelot and how he loved Geneva.

Original: soli eravamo e sanza alcun sospetto
Translate: We were alone and didn't suspect what would happen.

Original: Per più fïate li occhi ci sospinse quella lettura, e scolorocci il viso
Translate: Several times that reading moved us to look with our eyes and made us pale

Original: ma solo un punto fu quel che ci vinse
Translate: but it was only one point that overwhelmed us

Original: Quando leggemmo il disïato riso esser basciato da cotanto amante, questi, che mai da me non fia diviso,  la bocca mi basciò tutto tremante
Translate: "When we read that the desired mouth of Geneva was kissed by such a lover, this one, who will never be divided by me, kissed my mouth all trembling"

Original: Galeotto fu ’l libro e chi lo scrisse: quel giorno più non vi leggemmo avante"
Translate: Galeotto was the book, and who wrote it?

Original: Mentre che l'uno spirto questo disse, l'altro piangëa
Translate: We didn't read any more pages that day.

Original: sì che di pietade io venni men così com'io morisse
Translate: "While one spirit said this, the other wept, so that I fainted because of the disturbance, just as if I died."

Original: E caddi come corpo morto cade
Translate: And I fell like a lifeless body

Original: Al tornar de la mente, che si chiuse dinanzi a la pietà d’i due cognati,
Translate: "When my senses came back, overwhelmed by the anguish of the two brothers-in-laws "

Original: che di trestizia tutto mi confuse, novi tormenti e novi tormentati mi veggio intorno,
Translate: "that filled me with sadness, I see myself around new penises and new damned ones, "

Original: come ch’io mi mova e ch’io mi volga, e come che io guati
Translate: "No matter how you move me, and look around me."

Original: Io sono al terzo cerchio, de la piova etterna, maladetta, fredda e greve
Translate: "I am in the third circle, where an eternal, cursed, cold and harassing rain falls."

Original: regola e qualità mai non l’è nova
Translate: its rhythm and quality never change

Original: Grandine grossa, acqua tinta e neve per l’aere tenebroso si riversa
Translate: "In the dark air are poured a thick hail, dirty water and snow"

Original: pute la terra che questo riceve
Translate: the earth that is wet sends an unpleasant smell

Original: Cerbero, fiera crudele e diversa, con tre gole caninamente latra sovra la gente che quivi è sommersa
Translate: "Cerber, cruel and monstrous beast, latra like a dog with three heads above the damned who are lying in the mud"

Original: Li occhi ha vermigli, la barba unta e atra, e ’l ventre largo, e unghiate le mani
Translate: "His eyes are red, his snout is dirty and greasy, his belly is swollen and his legs with claws."

Original: graffia li spirti ed iscoia ed isquatra
Translate: "Scratch, skin and tear the damned"

Original: Urlar li fa la pioggia come cani
Translate: Rain makes them scream like dogs

Original: de l’un de’ lati fanno a l’altro schermo
Translate: they try to protect each other with their hips

Original: volgonsi spesso i miseri profani
Translate: the wretched sinners turn often

Original: Quando ci scorse Cerbero, il gran vermo, le bocche aperse e mostrocci le sanne
Translate: "When Cerberus, the horrible monster, saw us, opened his mouth and showed us his tusks."

Original: non avea membro che tenesse fermo
Translate: He had no part of the body that didn't tremble.

Original: E ’l duca mio distese le sue spanne, prese la terra, e con piene le pugna la gittò dentro a le bramose canne
Translate: "And my master opened his hands, took some land, and threw it with his fists full of hunger into the monster's mouth."

Original: Qual è quel cane ch’abbaiando agogna, e si racqueta poi che ’l pasto morde, ché solo a divorarlo intende e pugna,
Translate: "Like that dog that barks and is hungry, and then calms down when he penetrates the bite, for he has no other thought than to devour it, "

Original: cotai si fecer quelle facce lorde de lo demonio Cerbero, che ’ntrona l’anime sì, ch’esser vorrebber sorde
Translate: "In the same way the filthy faces of the Devil Cerberus were appeased, and so reunited the souls who would be deaf."

Original: Noi passavam su per l’ombre che adona la greve pioggia, e ponavam le piante sovra lor vanità che par persona
Translate: "We walked on the souls that the heavy rain brought down, and we rested our feet on their bodies that were inconsistent, with a human appearance."

Original: Elle giacean per terra tutte quante, fuor d’una ch’a seder si levò, ratto ch’ella ci vide passarsi davante
Translate: "They were all lying on the ground, except one who sat down as soon as he saw us passing by."

Original: "O tu che se’ per questo ’nferno tratto", mi disse, "riconoscimi, se sai: tu fosti, prima ch’io disfatto, fatto"
Translate: "He said to me, "O you who are guided through Hell, recognize me, if you can: you were born before I died."

Original: E io a lui: "L’angoscia che tu hai forse ti tira fuor de la mia mente, sì che non par ch’i’ ti vedessi mai
Translate: "I said to him, "The anguish you show makes you unrecognizable, just as if I had never seen you."

Original: Ma dimmi chi tu se’ che ’n sì dolente loco se’ messo, e hai sì fatta pena, che, s’altra è maggio, nulla è sì spiacente"
Translate: "But tell me who you are, that you are placed in such a painful place and suffer such pain that, perhaps, others are more serious, but none is just as unpleasant"

Original: Ed elli a me: "La tua città, ch’è piena d’invidia sì che già trabocca il sacco, seco mi tenne in la vita serena
Translate: "And he said, 'Your city, which is so full of envy that it has now reached its limit, hosted me in the life of this world.'

Original: Voi Cittadini mi chiamaste Ciacco per la dannosa colpa de la gola, come tu vedi, a la pioggia mi fiacco
Translate: "You Florentines called me Ciacco: because of the guilt of the throat, as you can see, I am broken by the rain."

Original: E io anima trista non son sola, ché tutte queste a simil pena stanno per simil colpa"
Translate: "And I am not the only damned here, for these other souls are subject to the same penalty for the same sin"

Original: E più non fé parola
Translate: Then he didn't say anything.

Original: Io li rispuosi: "Ciacco, il tuo affanno mi pesa sì, ch’a lagrimar mi ’nvita
Translate: "I said, 'Ciacco, your pain distresses me to the point that I feel weeping."

Original: ma dimmi, se tu sai, a che verranno  li cittadin de la città partita
Translate: " but tell me, if you know, what will be the destiny of the inhabitants of the divided city "

Original: s’alcun v’è giusto
Translate: if any of them is right

Original: e dimmi la cagione per che l’ ha tanta discordia assalita"
Translate: and tell me the cause of the discord that attacked her.

Original: E quelli a me: "Dopo lunga tencione verranno al sangue, e la parte selvaggia caccerà l’altra con molta offensione
Translate: "And that to me: "After a long strife they will come to violent confrontation, and the part of the peasant will hunt the other with serious damage"

Original: Poi appresso convien che questa caggia infra tre soli, e che l’altra sormonti con la forza di tal che testé piaggia
Translate: "Then it is destined that the Whites fall before three years, and that the other side take over with the help of a man who now stands in the balance between the two factions."

Original: Alte terrà lungo tempo le fronti, tenendo l’altra sotto gravi pesi, come che di ciò pianga o che n’aonti
Translate: "The Blacks will remain in power for a long time, oppressing the Whites with heavy condemnations, despite their complaints"

Original: Giusti son due, e non vi sono intesi
Translate: The right Florentines are only two and no one listens to them

Original: superbia, invidia e avarizia sono le tre faville c’ hanno i cuori accesi"
Translate: "Haughtiness, envy, and greed are the three sparks that have kindled the hearts"

Original: Qui puose fine al lagrimabil suono
Translate: Here he stopped speaking in a lamentous tone

Original: E io a lui: "Ancor vo’ che mi ’nsegni e che di più parlar mi facci dono
Translate: And I said to him, "I want you to explain other things to me and talk to me again."

Original: Farinata e ’l Tegghiaio, che fuor sì degni, Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo e ’l Mosca e li altri ch’a ben far puoser li ’ngegni, dimmi ove sono e fa ch’io li conosca
Translate: "Tell me where I am Farinata Degli Uberti, and the Tegghiaio, who were so worthy citizens, Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo, Moscow of the Lamberti and all the others who worked with the ingenuity to do well: let me know their destiny, "

Original: ché gran disio mi stringe di savere se ’l ciel li addolcia o lo ’nferno li attosca"
Translate: For I desire to know whether Heaven softens them, or Hell poisons them.

Original: E quelli: "Ei son tra l’anime più nere
Translate: And he: "They are among the most evil souls:

Original: diverse colpe giù li grava al fondo: se tanto scendi, là i potrai vedere
Translate: "Various faults place them in the bottom of Hell, and if you go down there, you can see them."

Original: Ma quando tu sarai nel dolce mondo, priegoti ch’a la mente altrui mi rechi: più non ti dico e più non ti rispondo"
Translate: "But when you return to the sweet earthly world, please remember me to the living: I tell you nothing else and I will not answer you anymore."

Original: Li diritti occhi torse allora in biechi
Translate: "Then Ciacco scrambled his eyes, "

Original: guardommi un poco e poi chinò la testa: cadde con essa a par de li altri ciechi
Translate: And he looked at me a little, and bowed his head: and he fell down with the other souls that were damned.

Original: E ’l duca disse a me: "Più non si desta di qua dal suon de l’angelica tromba, quando verrà la nimica podesta:
Translate: "And the teacher said unto me, He shall not rise again, until the sound of the angelic trumpet, when the power of the enemy shall come:"

Original: ciascun rivederà la trista tomba, ripiglierà sua carne e sua figura, udirà quel ch’in etterno rimbomba"
Translate: "Each one of them will see the sad grave, clothe himself with his mortal body, hear the final sentence"

Original: Sì trapassammo per sozza mistura de l’ombre e de la pioggia, a passi lenti, toccando un poco la vita futura
Translate: "So we passed the mixture of souls and rain in slow passages, speaking a little of life beyond the earth."

Original: per ch’io dissi: "Maestro, esti tormenti crescerann’ei dopo la gran sentenza, o fier minori, o saran sì cocenti?"
Translate: "Then I said: "Master, will these penalties increase after the final sentence, or will they decrease, or will they remain unchanged?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Ritorna a tua scïenza, che vuol, quanto la cosa è più perfetta, più senta il bene, e così la doglienza
Translate: "And he to me: "Go back to your knowledge, according to which, the more a creature is perfect, the more he will feel pleasure and pain."

Original: Tutto che questa gente maladetta in vera perfezion già mai non vada, di là più che di qua essere aspetta"
Translate: "Although these damned cursed ones will never be perfect, yet after the Judgment they will attain the completeness of their being"

Original: Noi aggirammo a tondo quella strada, parlando più assai ch’i’ non ridico
Translate: "We walked around the circle in circles, saying many other things I don't mean."

Original: venimmo al punto dove si digrada:
Translate: We came to the point where we descended into the fourth circle.

Original: quivi trovammo Pluto, il gran nemico
Translate: "and here we found Pluto, the great enemy"

Original: "Pape Satàn, pape Satàn aleppe",
Translate: "Oh, Satan, oh, Satan, king of Hell "

Original: cominciò Pluto con la voce chioccia
Translate: began to say Pluto with a roaring voice

Original: e quel savio gentil, che tutto seppe, disse per confortarmi: "Non ti noccia la tua paura
Translate: " and that noble wise man who knew all things, to comfort me said, "Do not be overwhelmed by fear, "

Original: ché, poder ch’elli abbia, non ci torrà lo scender questa roccia"
Translate: "for by the power of this demon he will not prevent us from descending this rock"

Original: Poi si rivolse a quella ’nfiata labbia, e disse: "Taci, maladetto lupo
Translate: Then he turned to his face full of anger, and said, "Shut up, you goddamn wolf."

Original: consuma dentro te con la tua rabbia
Translate: consumes within you with your anger

Original: Non è sanza cagion l’andare al cupo: vuolsi ne l’alto, là dove Michele fé la vendetta del superbo strupo"
Translate: "It is not without reason our journey to the bottom of Hell: this is what we want in Heaven, where the archangel Michael avenged the supreme sin of Lucifer"

Original: Quali dal vento le gonfiate vele caggiono avvolte, poi che l’alber fiacca, tal cadde a terra la fiera crudele
Translate: "As the sails swelled by the wind fall revolted, if the tree of the ship breaks, so the cruel beast fell to the ground."

Original: Così scendemmo ne la quarta lacca, pigliando più de la dolente ripa che ’l mal de l’universo tutto insacca
Translate: "Then we went down into the fourth circle, proceeding further down into that painful chasm that contains all the evil in the world."

Original: Ahi giustizia di Dio
Translate: "Alas, divine justice, "

Original: tante chi stipa nove travaglie e pene quant’io viddi? e perché nostra colpa sì ne scipa?
Translate: How many pains and torments did I see in that place? And why is our guilt torment us in this way?

Original: Come fa l’onda là sovra Cariddi, che si frange con quella in cui s’intoppa, così convien che qui la gente riddi
Translate: "As the wave does near Cariddi, when it breaks with the one that comes from Scylla, so those damned must dance the laugh"

Original: Qui vid’i’ gente più ch’altrove troppa, e d’una parte e d’altra, con grand’urli, voltando pesi per forza di poppa
Translate: "Here I saw more damned than in any other place of Hell, that on one side and on the other they rolled boulders with the strength of the chest, screaming."

Original: Percotëansi ’ncontro
Translate: "They were going to crush one another, "

Original: e poscia pur lì si rivolgea ciascun, voltando a retro, gridando: "Perché tieni?" e "Perché burli?"
Translate: Then each side turned back and cried out to each other, "Why are you holding on to the rock?" and "Why do you roll it?"

Original: Così tornavan per lo cerchio tetro da ogne mano a l’opposito punto, gridandosi anche loro ontoso metro
Translate: "So they went back into the Dark Circle from each side to the opposite point, continuing to shout the abusive words"

Original: poi si volgea ciascun, quand’era giunto, per lo suo mezzo cerchio a l’altra giostra
Translate: "then, when they came to the other side, they would turn around and start the ride again."

Original: E io, ch’avea lo cor quasi compunto,  dissi: "Maestro mio, or mi dimostra che gente è questa, e se tutti fuor cherci questi chercuti a la sinistra nostra"
Translate: " And I, who had a heart full of anguish, said, "My master, show me that these are the damned ones, and if these on our left who have tonsure were all clerics."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tutti quanti fuor guerci sì de la mente in la vita primaia, che con misura nullo spendio ferci
Translate: "And he to me: "Everyone alive had a dark mind, so that they didn't make any expense with measure."

Original: Assai la voce lor chiaro l’abbaia, quando vegnono a’ due punti del cerchio dove colpa contraria li dispaia
Translate: "Their voice clearly expresses it when they reach the two points of the Circle, where their opposite guilt separates them into two distinct ranks."

Original: Questi fuor cherci, che non han coperchio piloso al capo, e papi e cardinali, in cui usa avarizia il suo soperchio"
Translate: "These, who do not have hair on their heads, were clerics, and popes and cardinals, in whom greed exerts its excess"

Original: E io: "Maestro, tra questi cotali dovre’ io ben riconoscere alcuni che furo immondi di cotesti mali"
Translate: "And I: "Master, I should surely recognize some among these damned, who were stained with these sins"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Vano pensiero aduni: la sconoscente vita che i fé sozzi, ad ogne conoscenza or li fa bruni
Translate: "And he to me: "Your thought is vain: the senseless life that made them sin, now makes them completely unrecognizable."

Original: In etterno verranno a li due cozzi: questi resurgeranno del sepulcro col pugno chiuso, e questi coi crin mozzi
Translate: "They will come to crush forever: the greedy ones will rise from the grave with their fist closed, the prodigals with their hair cut"

Original: Mal dare e mal tener lo mondo pulcro ha tolto loro, e posti a questa zuffa: qual ella sia, parole non ci appulcro
Translate: "Too much to spend and too much to save has taken away from them Paradise, and placed them at this issue: I do not use other words to describe their punishment"

Original: Or puoi, figliuol, veder la corta buffa d’i ben che son commessi a la fortuna, per che l’umana gente si rabuffa
Translate: "Now, son, you can see the short life span of the goods that are entrusted to fortune, so mankind is so busy"

Original: ché tutto l’oro ch’è sotto la luna e che già fu, di quest’anime stanche non poterebbe farne posare una"
Translate: "For all the gold of the world, which was in the past, could not cause even one of these souls to rest"

Original: "Maestro mio", diss’io, "or mi dì anche: questa fortuna di che tu mi tocche, che è, che i ben del mondo ha sì tra branche?"
Translate: "I said, "My master, now explain to me: this fortune of which you speak to me, and which has the goods of the world among its claws, what is it?"

Original: E quelli a me: "Oh creature sciocche, quanta ignoranza è quella che v’offende
Translate: And he said unto me, O foolish men, how much ignorance doth hurt you.

Original: Or vo’ che tu mia sentenza ne ’mbocche
Translate: Now I want you to listen carefully to my words.

Original: Colui lo cui saver tutto trascende, fece li cieli e diè lor chi conduce sì, ch’ogne parte ad ogne parte splende,  distribuendo igualmente la luce
Translate: "He whose wisdom surpassed all created the heavens, and set up angelic intelligences to govern them, so that his light may be reflected from heaven into heaven and reverberated equally in the Universe."

Original: Similemente a li splendor mondani ordinò general ministra e duce  che permutasse a tempo li ben vani di gente in gente e d’uno in altro sangue, oltre la difension d’i senni umani
Translate: " In the same way, he set up an intelligence to govern and administer earthly goods, to transmute them at the appropriate time between the various families and the various races, beyond the opposition of the understanding of men."

Original: per ch’una gente impera e l’altra langue, seguendo lo giudicio di costei, che è occulto come in erba l’angue
Translate: "so one family thrives and another decade, according to the judgment of the fortune that is hidden, like the serpent nesting among the grass"

Original: Vostro saver non ha contasto a lei: questa provede, giudica, e persegue suo regno come il loro li altri dèi
Translate: "Your wisdom cannot oppose it: it provides, judges and implements its decrees, just as the other angelic intelligences"

Original: Le sue permutazion non hanno triegue: necessità la fa esser veloce
Translate: His transmutations have no respite

Original: sì spesso vien chi vicenda consegue
Translate: must be quick to fulfill the divine will

Original: Quest’è colei ch’è tanto posta in croce pur da color che le dovrien dar lode, dandole biasmo a torto e mala voce
Translate: so it often happens that there are changes of condition

Original: ma ella s’è beata e ciò non ode: con l’altre prime creature lieta volve sua spera e beata si gode
Translate: "She is happy and feels nothing: with the other first creatures she cheerfully turns her orbit and enjoys her happiness."

Original: Or discendiamo omai a maggior pieta
Translate: Now is the time to go down to a greater anguish

Original: già ogne stella cade che saliva quand’io mi mossi, e ’l troppo star si vieta"
Translate: By now every rising star is setting when I left Limbo and we can't waste too much time.

Original: Noi ricidemmo il cerchio a l’altra riva sovr’una fonte che bolle e riversa per un fossato che da lei deriva
Translate: "We crossed the Circle to the opposite bank, over a fountain that boils and pours down a ditch that begins from it."

Original: L’acqua era buia assai più che persa
Translate: The water was very dark

Original: e noi, in compagnia de l’onde bige, intrammo giù per una via diversa
Translate: "and we, following the black waves, descended along an evil way"
