Original: In la palude va c’ ha nome Stige questo tristo ruscel, quand’è disceso al piè de le maligne piagge grige
Translate: "This sad stream goes into the swamp called Stige, once it has come down at the foot of that bleak hellish slope."

Original: E io, che di mirare stava inteso, vidi genti fangose in quel pantano, ignude tutte, con sembiante offeso
Translate: "And I, who looked intently, saw some damned people immersed in that muddy mud, all naked and with a wrinkled appearance."

Original: Queste si percotean non pur con mano, ma con la testa e col petto e coi piedi, troncandosi co’ denti a brano a brano
Translate: "They struck themselves not only with their hands, but with their heads, breasts, feet, biting off their flesh."

Original: Lo buon maestro disse: "Figlio, or vedi l’anime di color cui vinse l’ira
Translate: "The good teacher said, "Son, now you see the souls that were overwhelmed by anger."

Original: e anche vo’ che tu per certo credi  che sotto l’acqua è gente che sospira, e fanno pullular quest’acqua al summo, come l’occhio ti dice, u’ che s’aggira
Translate: "and I also want you to believe for sure that under the water there are souls sighing, and they make the surface of the water gurgle, as you can see everywhere you look."

Original: Fitti nel limo dicon: "Tristi fummo ne l'aere dolce che dal sol s'allegra, portando dentro accidïoso fummo:  or ci attristiam ne la belletta negra"
Translate: They say, "We were sad in the sweet air that brings joy from the sun, harboring in the soul an unexpressed anger: now we grieve in the black mud"""

Original: Quest’inno si gorgoglian ne la strozza, ché dir nol posson con parola integra"
Translate: " They make these words gurgle in their throats, for they cannot pronounce them with a clear voice"

Original: Così girammo de la lorda pozza grand’arco, tra la ripa secca e ’l mézzo, con li occhi vòlti a chi del fango ingozza
Translate: "So we skirted that swampy subway through a great arch, between the rocky embankment and the water, with our eyes turned to the souls immersed in the mud."

Original: Venimmo al piè d’una torre al da sezzo
Translate: Eventually we reached the foot of a tower

Original: Io dico, seguitando, ch’assai prima che noi fossimo al piè de l’alta torre, li occhi nostri n’andar suso a la cima per due fiammette che i vedemmo porre,
Translate: "Going on, I say that long before we reached the foot of the high tower, our eyes went to his top and saw that someone had set two flames there, "

Original: e un’altra da lungi render cenno, tanto ch’a pena il potea l’occhio tòrre
Translate: "while another tower farther away, so much so that one could barely see, he had answered"

Original: E io mi volsi al mar di tutto ’l senno
Translate: "I turned to Virgilio, whose sense is as broad as the sea, "

Original: dissi: "Questo che dice? e che risponde quell’altro foco? e chi son quei che ’l fenno?"
Translate: And I said, "What does this signal mean?" And that other thing answers? And who did all this?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Su per le sucide onde già scorgere puoi quello che s’aspetta, se ’l fummo del pantan nol ti nasconde"
Translate: "And he to me: "Along the murky waters you can already see the one we are waiting for, if the steam of the swamp does not hide him from sight."

Original: Corda non pinse mai da sé saetta che sì corresse via per l’aere snella, com’io vidi una nave piccioletta  venir per l’acqua verso noi in quella,
Translate: "The rope of an arch never struck an arrow that would crack the air so fast, as I saw a small boat coming to us at that moment in the water, "

Original: sotto ’l governo d’un sol galeoto, che gridava: "Or se' giunta, anima fella
Translate: "ruled by one helmsman, who cried, "Finally you have arrived, evil soul"

Original: "Flegïàs, Flegïàs, tu gridi a vòto", disse lo mio segnore, "a questa volta: più non ci avrai che sol passando il loto"
Translate: "My teacher said, "Flegias, Flegias, you shout in vain this time: we will come with you only to cross the swamp."

Original: Qual è colui che grande inganno ascolta che li sia fatto, e poi se ne rammarca, fecesi Flegïàs ne l’ira accolta
Translate: "As he who hears a great deception that has been done to him, and then regrets it, so did Flegias burning with anger."

Original: Lo duca mio discese ne la barca, e poi mi fece intrare appresso lui
Translate: And my guide went up into the boat, and brought me up after him.

Original: e sol quand’io fui dentro parve carca
Translate: And only then did the boat seem to have a load

Original: Tosto che ’l duca e io nel legno fui, segando se ne va l’antica prora de l’acqua più che non suol con altrui
Translate: "As soon as Virgil and I were in the boat, she departed, slitting up the water more than usual with others."

Original: Mentre noi corravam la morta gora, dinanzi mi si fece un pien di fango, e disse: "Chi se’ tu che vieni anzi ora?"
Translate: "While we were walking through that stagnant swamp, a damned mud-filled man came to me and said, "Who are you, who are you, who arrives in Hell before the time?"

Original: E io a lui: "S’i’ vegno, non rimango
Translate: "I said, "If I come, I will not stay."

Original: ma tu chi se’, che sì se’ fatto brutto?"
Translate: "Who are you, who are made unrecognizable? "

Original: Rispuose: "Vedi che son un che piango"
Translate: He said, "You see that I am a afflicted soul."

Original: E io a lui: "Con piangere e con lutto, spirito maladetto, ti rimani
Translate: "And I to him: "And it is good for you to be grieved and grieved, a cursed spirit."

Original: ch’i’ ti conosco, ancor sie lordo tutto"
Translate: "For I know thee, though thou art full of mud."

Original: Allor distese al legno ambo le mani
Translate: Then the damned man stretched out with both hands toward the boat.

Original: per che ’l maestro accorto lo sospinse, dicendo: "Via costà con li altri cani"
Translate: "The master, aware, pushed him away saying, "Get out of here, come back with the other dogs."

Original: Lo collo poi con le braccia mi cinse
Translate: "Then he hugged me around my neck with his arms, "

Original: basciommi ’l volto e disse: "Alma sdegnosa, benedetta colei che ’n te s’incinse
Translate: "He kissed my face and said, "O disdainful soul, blessed she who became pregnant with you."

Original: Quei fu al mondo persona orgogliosa
Translate: That one in the world was a proud person

Original: bontà non è che sua memoria fregi: così s’è l’ombra sua qui furïosa
Translate: "There is no good deed of his that honours his memory, so his soul is here, furious."

Original: Quanti si tegnon or là sù gran regi che qui staranno come porci in brago, di sé lasciando orribili dispregi"
Translate: "How many men believe in the life of the great kings, while here in Hell they will be like swine in the mud, leaving a horrible memory of themselves."

Original: E io: "Maestro, molto sarei vago di vederlo attuffare in questa broda prima che noi uscissimo del lago"
Translate: "And I: "Master, I would have great desire to see him sink into this slime, before leaving the swamp"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Avante che la proda ti si lasci veder, tu sarai sazio: di tal disïo convien che tu goda"
Translate: "And he to me: "Before we see the mighty one, you will be satisfied: it is fitting that such desire be fulfilled"

Original: Dopo ciò poco vid’io quello strazio far di costui a le fangose genti, che Dio ancor ne lodo e ne ringrazio
Translate: "Soon afterward I saw that the damned immersed in the mud made him a great torment, which I still praise and thank God."

Original: Tutti gridavano: "A Filippo Argenti"
Translate: All the damned shouted, "Added to Filippo Argenti"

Original: e ’l fiorentino spirito bizzarro in sé medesmo si volvea co’ denti
Translate: and that bizarre Florentine spirit bit itself with its teeth

Original: Quivi il lasciammo, che più non ne narro
Translate: "We left him here, and I won't say anything about him."

Original: ma ne l’orecchie mi percosse un duolo, per ch’io avante l’occhio intento sbarro
Translate: "But, behold, my ears heard a lamenting choir, so I looked up alarmed."

Original: Lo buon maestro disse: "Omai, figliuolo, s’appressa la città c’ ha nome Dite, coi gravi cittadin, col grande stuolo"
Translate: "The good teacher said, 'Now, son, the city called Dite is drawing near, with its afflicted inhabitants, with the great multitude of devils.'"

Original: E io: "Maestro, già le sue meschite là entro certe ne la valle cerno, vermiglie come se di foco uscite  fossero"
Translate: "And I: "Master, I already see his distinct mosques in the distance, red as if they had come out of the fire"

Original: Ed ei mi disse: "Il foco etterno ch’entro l’affoca le dimostra rosse, come tu vedi in questo basso inferno"
Translate: " And he said to me, "The eternal fire that burns them inside makes them become of that color, as you see in this low Hell."

Original: Noi pur giungemmo dentro a l’alte fosse che vallan quella terra sconsolata: le mura mi parean che ferro fosse
Translate: We came into the deep ditches surrounding that painful land: the walls seemed to me made of iron.

Original: Non sanza prima far grande aggirata, venimmo in parte dove il nocchier forte "Usciteci", gridò: "qui è l’intrata"
Translate: "Not before we crossed a wide ride, we reached a point where the horrible ferryman shouted: "Get down, the entrance is here"

Original: Io vidi più di mille in su le porte da ciel piovuti, che stizzosamente dicean: "Chi è costui che sanza morte  va per lo regno de la morta gente?"
Translate: "I saw on the gates more than a thousand devils rained from heaven, saying with fury: "Who is this that, still alive, dares go into the kingdom of the dead? "

Original: E ’l savio mio maestro fece segno di voler lor parlar segretamente
Translate: And my wise teacher showed that he wanted to speak with them separately.

Original: Allor chiusero un poco il gran disdegno e disser: "Vien tu solo, e quei sen vada che sì ardito intrò per questo regno
Translate: "Then they appeased their indignation a little, and said, "Come alone, and let the other go, for he had the courage to enter into this place."

Original: Sol si ritorni per la folle strada:
Translate: "Return alone along the road that he has walked madly, he is capable of it: "

Original: pruovi, se sa ché tu qui rimarrai, che li ha’ iscorta sì buia contrada"
Translate: "For thou shalt stay here, seeing that thou hast guided him in the dark path"

Original: Pensa, lettor, se io mi sconfortai nel suon de le parole maladette, ché non credetti ritornarci mai
Translate: "Think, reader, if I didn't mind hearing those cursed words, I thought I would never return to Earth."

Original: "O caro duca mio, che più di sette volte m’ hai sicurtà renduta e tratto d’alto periglio che ’ncontra mi stette,  non mi lasciar", diss’io, "così disfatto
Translate: "I said, "O my dear guide, who has often given me confidence and saved me from a grave danger that threatened me, do not leave me in this situation."

Original: e se ’l passar più oltre ci è negato, ritroviam l’orme nostre insieme ratto"
Translate: "and if we are denied to go further, let's hurry back to our steps"

Original: E quel segnor che lì m’avea menato, mi disse:
Translate: And that teacher who led me there said to me:

Original: "Non temer ché ’l nostro passo non ci può tòrre alcun: da tal n’è dato
Translate: "Don't be afraid, since no one can oppose our journey, willed by God"

Original: Ma qui m’attendi, e lo spirito lasso conforta e ciba di speranza buona, ch’i’ non ti lascerò nel mondo basso"
Translate: "Now wait here for me, and comfort your prostrated spirit with good hope, for I will not leave you in hell."

Original: Così sen va, e quivi m’abbandona lo dolce padre, e io rimagno in forse, che sì e no nel capo mi tenciona
Translate: "So the sweet father went away and left me there, full of doubts, uncertain about what would happen."

Original: Udir non potti quello ch’a lor porse
Translate: I couldn't hear what he said to the devils.

Original: ma ei non stette là con essi guari, che ciascun dentro a pruova si ricorse
Translate: "but he remained not long to speak, for every one of them ran back into the walls."

Original: Chiuser le porte que’ nostri avversari nel petto al mio segnor, che fuor rimase e rivolsesi a me con passi rari
Translate: "Those of our enemies shut the doors in the face of my master, who remained outside and returned to me at a slow pace."

Original: Li occhi a la terra e le ciglia avea rase d’ogne baldanza, e dicea ne’ sospiri: "Chi m' ha negate le dolenti case"
Translate: "He had his eyes on the ground and his eyes devoid of all security, and sighing, he said, "He who denied me access to the sorrowful city."

Original: E a me disse: "Tu, perch’io m’adiri, non sbigottir, ch’io vincerò la prova, qual ch’a la difension dentro s’aggiri
Translate: "And he said unto me, Thou shalt not lose heart, though I am angry, for I will overcome the test, whatever the defense they prepare within the city."

Original: Questa lor tracotanza non è nova
Translate: This haughtiness of theirs is not new.

Original: ché già l’usaro a men segreta porta, la qual sanza serrame ancor si trova
Translate: "They used it to defend a less hidden door, which is still without doors."

Original: Sovr’essa vedestù la scritta morta:
Translate: On it you read the threatening inscription:

Original: e già di qua da lei discende l’erta, passando per li cerchi sanza scorta,  tal che per lui ne fia la terra aperta"
Translate: "and already from it is coming down along the slope a heavenly messenger, passing through the Circles without escort, that will make sure to open the passage to us"

Original: Quel color che viltà di fuor mi pinse veggendo il duca mio tornare in volta, più tosto dentro il suo novo ristrinse
Translate: "That pallor that my vileness colored on my face, seeing my guide return to his footsteps, caused Virgil to hold within himself his doubts"

Original: Attento si fermò com’uom ch’ascolta
Translate: "He stopped, stretching his ear to listen."

Original: ché l’occhio nol potea menare a lunga per l’aere nero e per la nebbia folta
Translate: "for he could not cast away his gaze, because of the darkness and the thick fog."

Original: "Pur a noi converrà vincer la punga", cominciò el, "se non tal ne s’offerse
Translate: "He began to say: "And yet it is inevitable that we will win the battle, unless we are promised a valid help"

Original: Oh quanto tarda a me ch’altri qui giunga"
Translate: "Oh, how I'd like you to get here right away."

Original: I’ vidi ben sì com’ei ricoperse lo cominciar con l’altro che poi venne, che fur parole a le prime diverse
Translate: "I realized that he changed his speech from what he had begun, that it would probably be different."

Original: ma nondimen paura il suo dir dienne, perch’io traeva la parola tronca forse a peggior sentenzia che non tenne
Translate: "less his words created fear in me, because I interpreted the sentence interrupted with a sense perhaps worse than it actually did."

Original: "In questo fondo de la trista conca discende mai alcun del primo grado, che sol per pena ha la speranza cionca?"
Translate: "Did it ever happen that a soul of the First Circle, whose only penalty is not to have hope of salvation, has fallen to the bottom of low Hell?"

Original: Questa question fec’io
Translate: "I asked this question to Virgil, "

Original: e quei "Di rado incontra", mi rispuose, "che di noi faccia il cammino alcun per qual io vado
Translate: And he said, "It is rare for any of us to walk this same way."

Original: Ver è ch’altra fïata qua giù fui, congiurato da quella Eritón cruda che richiamava l’ombre a’ corpi sui
Translate: "It is true that I came down here once more, evoked by that cruel magician Eritone who called the souls into their bodies"

Original: Di poco era di me la carne nuda, ch’ella mi fece intrar dentr’a quel muro, per trarne un spirto del cerchio di Giuda
Translate: "I had recently separated myself from my body, when she brought me into those walls to draw a spirit out of Judecca."

Original: Quell’è ’l più basso loco e ’l più oscuro, e ’l più lontan dal ciel che tutto gira: ben so ’l cammin però ti fa sicuro
Translate: "That is the lowest and darkest point of hell, as well as the furthest from the First Mobile: I know the way, so be quiet."

Original: Questa palude che ’l gran puzzo spira cigne dintorno la città dolente, u’ non potemo intrare omai sanz’ira"
Translate: "This swamp that emanates the great smell surrounds the city of Dite, where we can no longer enter without forcing the will of the demons"

Original: E altro disse, ma non l’ ho a mente
Translate: "He added something else, but I don't remember it, "

Original: però che l’occhio m’avea tutto tratto ver’ l’alta torre a la cima rovente,
Translate: "for my gaze was drawn to the high tower from the hot top, "

Original: dove in un punto furon dritte ratto tre furïe infernal di sangue tinte, che membra feminine avieno e atto,  e con idre verdissime eran cinte
Translate: "where the three hellish furies, stained with blood, which had female limbs and behavior, and were surrounded by very green creatures, stood at one point."

Original: serpentelli e ceraste avien per crine, onde le fiere tempie erano avvinte
Translate: "They had serpentine and waxy hair, of which they had wrapped their temples."

Original: E quei, che ben conobbe le meschine de la regina de l’etterno pianto, "Guarda", mi disse, "le feroci Erine
Translate: "And Virgil, who immediately recognized the maidens of the queen of Hell, said to me, "Look at the ferocious Erinni."

Original: Quest’è Megera dal sinistro canto
Translate: This one on the left is Megera.

Original: quella che piange dal destro è Aletto
Translate: The one crying on the right is Aletto

Original: Tesifón è nel mezzo"
Translate: Thesis is in the center of the thesis

Original: e tacque a tanto
Translate: At that point, he was silent.

Original: Con l’unghie si fendea ciascuna il petto
Translate: Each one ripped his chest with his fingernails

Original: battiensi a palme e gridavan sì alto, ch’i’ mi strinsi al poeta per sospetto
Translate: "They fought with the palms of their hands, and cried so loudly that I, out of fear, shook Virgil."

Original: "Vegna Medusa: sì ’l farem di smalto",
Translate: "Come here Medusa, so we will turn it into stone, "

Original: dicevan tutte riguardando in giuso
Translate: They were all looking down.

Original: "mal non vengiammo in Tesëo l’assalto"
Translate: We did wrong not to avenge the assault of Theseus.

Original: "Volgiti ’n dietro e tien lo viso chiuso
Translate: Turn back and keep your eyes closed:

Original: ché se ’l Gorgón si mostra e tu ’l vedessi, nulla sarebbe di tornar mai suso"
Translate: "In fact, if the Gorgone showed up and you saw it, you would have no hope of returning to Earth"

Original: Così disse ’l maestro
Translate: That's what the teacher said.

Original: ed elli stessi mi volse, e non si tenne a le mie mani, che con le sue ancor non mi chiudessi
Translate: "and he himself turned me around, and he did not content himself that I should put my hands on my eyes, but he also added his own."

Original: O voi ch'avete li 'ntelletti sani, mirate la dottrina che s'asconde sotto 'l velame de li versi strani
Translate: "O you who have the intellects of integrity, observe well the teaching that is hidden under the veil of my mysterious verses."

Original: E già venìa su per le torbide onde un fracasso d’un suon, pien di spavento, per cui tremavano amendue le sponde,  non altrimenti fatto che d’un vento impetüoso per li avversi ardori, che fier la selva e sanz’alcun rattento  li rami schianta, abbatte e porta fori
Translate: "Already came along the muddy waters of the Stige a great noise, which was frightening, so both sides trembled, just like an impetuous wind that hits the forest and without any regard crashes, knocks down and drags away the branches"

Original: dinanzi polveroso va superbo, e fa fuggir le fiere e li pastori
Translate: "proceeding haughty among the dust, causing beasts and shepherds to escape"

Original: Li occhi mi sciolse e disse: "Or drizza il nerbo del viso su per quella schiuma antica per indi ove quel fummo è più acerbo"
Translate: "Virgilio made me open my eyes and said, "Now look at that old swamp, where the steam is thicker."

Original: Come le rane innanzi a la nimica biscia per l’acqua si dileguan tutte,
Translate: "Like frogs, they all flee before their opponent's biscuit, "

Original: fin ch’a la terra ciascuna s’abbica,
Translate: "as long as everyone piles up on the mainland, "

Original: vid’io più di mille anime distrutte fuggir così dinanzi ad un ch’al passo passava Stige con le piante asciutte
Translate: "so I saw more than a thousand souls of wrath fleeing before one who crossed the Stige walking, with dry feet."

Original: Dal volto rimovea quell’aere grasso, menando la sinistra innanzi spesso
Translate: With his left hand he often drove the smoke out of his face

Original: e sol di quell’angoscia parea lasso
Translate: and this seemed his only annoyance

Original: Ben m’accorsi ch’elli era da ciel messo, e volsimi al maestro
Translate: I immediately realized that this was the heavenly messenger, and I turned to the master.

Original: e quei fé segno ch’i’ stessi queto ed inchinassi ad esso
Translate: And he beckoned me that I should remain calm and bow down to the new man.

Original: Ahi quanto mi parea pien di disdegno
Translate: "Oh, how disdainful it seemed to me "

Original: Venne a la porta e con una verghetta l’aperse, che non v’ebbe alcun ritegno
Translate: "He came to the door of Dite and opened it with a stick, without encountering opposition."

Original: "O cacciati del ciel, gente dispetta", cominciò elli in su l’orribil soglia, "ond’esta oltracotanza in voi s’alletta?
Translate: "O you whom Heaven has cast out, despised people, "he began to say on the horrible threshold, "Where does this haughtiness originate in you?"

Original: Perché recalcitrate a quella voglia a cui non puote il fin mai esser mozzo, e che più volte v’ ha cresciuta doglia?
Translate: "Why do you oppose that will that can never fail to succeed, and that has increased your pains several times?"

Original: Che giova ne le fata dar di cozzo? Cerbero vostro, se ben vi ricorda, ne porta ancor pelato il mento e ’l gozzo"
Translate: "What good is it to oppose destiny? Your Cerberus, if you remember correctly, still carries his chin and throat skinned for this."

Original: Poi si rivolse per la strada lorda, e non fé motto a noi, ma fé sembiante d’omo cui altra cura stringa e morda  che quella di colui che li è davante
Translate: "Then he returned to the muddy path, without speaking to us, but he gave the impression of someone who had much more concerns than he had in front of him."

Original: e noi movemmo i piedi inver’ la terra, sicuri appresso le parole sante
Translate: "and we moved toward the earth, sure after those holy words"

Original: Dentro li ’ntrammo sanz’alcuna guerra
Translate: We entered the city without further obstacles

Original: e io, ch’avea di riguardar disio la condizion che tal fortezza serra,  com’io fui dentro, l’occhio intorno invio: e veggio ad ogne man grande campagna, piena di duolo e di tormento rio
Translate: "and I, who had a desire to look at the condition of the souls closed in that fortress, as I was inside I turned my gaze here and there, and saw all around a great expanse, full of horrible sorrows and torments."

Original: Sì come ad Arli, ove Rodano stagna, sì com’a Pola, presso del Carnaro ch’Italia chiude e suoi termini bagna,  fanno i sepulcri tutt’il loco varo, così facevan quivi d’ogne parte, salvo che ’l modo v’era più amaro
Translate: "Just like Arles, where the Rhône swamps, and as in Pula, near the Gulf of Kvarner which is at the borders of Italy and bathes them, the tombs make the place all rough, so it happened here, except that the tombs produced more pain"

Original: ché tra li avelli fiamme erano sparte, per le quali eran sì del tutto accesi, che ferro più non chiede verun’arte
Translate: "In fact, flames were scattered among the tombs, which burned them so that no craftsmanship requires warmer iron."

Original: Tutti li lor coperchi eran sospesi, e fuor n’uscivan sì duri lamenti, che ben parean di miseri e d’offesi
Translate: "All the lids were open and shored, and the laments came out so miserable that they looked just like bloody souls."

Original: E io: "Maestro, quai son quelle genti che, seppellite dentro da quell’arche, si fan sentir coi sospiri dolenti?"
Translate: "And I: "Master, who are those souls who, buried inside those graves, make themselves heard with sorrowful sighs?"

Original: E quelli a me: "Qui son li eresïarche con lor seguaci, d’ogne setta, e molto più che non credi son le tombe carche
Translate: "And he to me: "Here are the heresiarchs with their followers of every sect, and the tombs are filled much more than you think."

Original: Simile qui con simile è sepolto, e i monimenti son più e men caldi"
Translate: Here every heretic is buried with his like, and the tombs are more or less warm.

Original: E poi ch’a la man destra si fu vòlto,  passammo tra i martìri e li alti spaldi
Translate: "And when he had turned to the right, we walked between the tombs and the high stands."

Original: Ora sen va per un secreto calle, tra ’l muro de la terra e li martìri, lo mio maestro, e io dopo le spalle
Translate: "At that point my teacher went on a hidden path, between the walls and the graves, and I followed him."

Original: "O virtù somma, che per li empi giri mi volvi", cominciai, "com’a te piace, parlami, e sodisfammi a’ miei disiri
Translate: "I asked him: "O supreme wise man, who leads me to the Hell Circles, please answer me and satisfy my desire."

Original: La gente che per li sepolcri giace potrebbesi veder? già son levati tutt’i coperchi, e nessun guardia face"
Translate: Could you see the damned ones lying in the graves? All the lids are lifted up and no demon makes them the guard.

Original: E quelli a me: "Tutti saran serrati quando di Iosafàt qui torneranno coi corpi che là sù hanno lasciati
Translate: And he to me: "They will all be closed when the souls return here from the valley of Jehoshaphat with the bodies they have left on Earth.

Original: Suo cimitero da questa parte hanno con Epicuro tutti suoi seguaci, che l’anima col corpo morta fanno
Translate: "At this point of the cemetery are punished Epicurus and all his followers, who proclaim the death of the soul"

Original: Però a la dimanda che mi faci quinc’entro satisfatto sarà tosto, e al disio ancor che tu mi taci"
Translate: "Therefore the desire which thou hast revealed to me shall soon be fulfilled, and that which thou wilt not tell me."

Original: E io: "Buon duca, non tegno riposto a te mio cuor se non per dicer poco, e tu m’ hai non pur mo a ciò disposto"
Translate: "And I: "My good guidance, I do not hide my thoughts from you except to speak little, and it was you who taught me on various occasions."

Original: "O Tosco che per la città del foco vivo ten vai così parlando onesto, piacciati di restare in questo loco
Translate: "O Tuscan, that you go to the city of fire speaking so dignifiedly, have the complacency to keep you"

Original: La tua loquela ti fa manifesto di quella nobil patrïa natio, a la qual forse fui troppo molesto"
Translate: "Your accent indicates that you were born in that noble country to which, perhaps, I was too annoying"

Original: Subitamente questo suono uscìo d’una de l’arche
Translate: "This voice suddenly came out of one of the graves, "

Original: però m’accostai, temendo, un poco più al duca mio
Translate: So I was afraid, and I held on to my teacher a little.

Original: Ed el mi disse: "Volgiti
Translate: "And he said to me, 'Turn,'

Original: Che fai? Vedi là Farinata che s’è dritto: da la cintola in sù tutto ’l vedrai"
Translate: What are you doing? Don't you see Farinata up there who's uplifted?

Original: Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto
Translate: I had already put my gaze in his

Original: ed el s’ergea col petto e con la fronte com’avesse l’inferno a gran dispitto
Translate: "and he stood with his forehead and his breast high, as though he despised all Hell."

Original: E l’animose man del duca e pronte mi pinser tra le sepulture a lui, dicendo: "Le parole tue sien conte"
Translate: "And the hands of Virgil, ready and animosity, pushed me into the tombs toward him, while the teacher said, "Make your words measured."

Original: Com’io al piè de la sua tomba fui, guardommi un poco, e poi, quasi sdegnoso, mi dimandò: "Chi fuor li maggior tui?"
Translate: "As soon as I was at the foot of his grave, he looked at me a little and then, almost with disdain, asked me, "Who were your ancestors?"

Original: Io ch’era d’ubidir disideroso, non gliel celai, ma tutto gliel’apersi
Translate: "I, who was eager to obey, did not hide them from him but, indeed, answered fully"

Original: ond’ei levò le ciglia un poco in suso
Translate: "then he lifted up his eyelashes a little, "

Original: poi disse: "Fieramente furo avversi a me e a miei primi e a mia parte, sì che per due fïate li dispersi"
Translate: "And he said, 'They were fierce enemies of mine, of my fathers, and of my political part, so that I chased them out of Florence twice.'"

Original: "S’ei fur cacciati, ei tornar d’ogne parte", rispuos’io lui, "l’una e l’altra fïata
Translate: "I said to him, "If they were driven out, then they returned to every side, on both occasions."

Original: ma i vostri non appreser ben quell’arte"
Translate: "but your ancestors were not as good"

Original: Allor surse a la vista scoperchiata un’ombra, lungo questa, infino al mento: credo che s’era in ginocchie levata
Translate: "In that moment a soul appeared at our sight, leaning beside that of Farinata up to the chin: I think she was kneeling."

Original: Dintorno mi guardò, come talento avesse di veder s’altri era meco
Translate: "He looked around me, as if he had a desire to see if there was anyone else with me."

Original: e poi che ’l sospecciar fu tutto spento,  piangendo disse: "Se per questo cieco carcere vai per altezza d’ingegno, mio figlio ov’è? e perché non è teco?"
Translate: "And when he ceased to observe, he cried to me, "If you go to this blind prison for your intellectual merits, where is my son? And why is he not here with you?"

Original: E io a lui: "Da me stesso non vegno: colui ch’attende là, per qui mi mena forse cui Guido vostro ebbe a disdegno"
Translate: "And I to him: "I am not here for my own merit: he who waits there leads me through hell to her whom your son Guido perhaps had disdained."

Original: Le sue parole e ’l modo de la pena m’avean di costui già letto il nome
Translate: His words and the fact that he was among the Epicureans made me understand this man's name

Original: però fu la risposta così piena
Translate: So I answered so quickly.

Original: Di sùbito drizzato gridò: "Come? dicesti "elli ebbe"? non viv’elli ancora? non fiere li occhi suoi lo dolce lume?"
Translate: "And he suddenly rose up and cried out, "How? Did you say, "He had"? Guido doesn't live yet? The sweet light of the sun doesn't strike his eyes anymore?"

Original: Quando s’accorse d’alcuna dimora ch’io facëa dinanzi a la risposta, supin ricadde e più non parve fora
Translate: "When he saw that I hesitated to answer, he fell back underneath and never came back out of the grave."

Original: Ma quell’altro magnanimo, a cui posta restato m’era, non mutò aspetto, né mosse collo, né piegò sua costa
Translate: "But the other noble damned, whose question I had stopped, did not change appearance, nor did he seem at all impressed by the event:"

Original: e sé continüando al primo detto, "S’elli han quell’arte", disse, "male appresa, ciò mi tormenta più che questo letto
Translate: "and continuing the speech begun, he said: "If my ancestors have learned badly the art of returning to Florence, this gives me more suffering than this tomb."

Original: Ma non cinquanta volte fia raccesa la faccia de la donna che qui regge, che tu saprai quanto quell’arte pesa
Translate: But there won't be fifty moon phases that you'll know how painful that art is.

Original: E se tu mai nel dolce mondo regge, dimmi: perché quel popolo è sì empio incontr’a’ miei in ciascuna sua legge?"
Translate: And now tell me: why are the Florentines so hard in their every provision against my family?

Original: Ond’io a lui: "Lo strazio e ’l grande scempio che fece l’Arbia colorata in rosso, tal orazion fa far nel nostro tempio"
Translate: "And I to him: "The torment and the horrendous slaughter of Montaperti, which colored the river Arbia with red, causes us to issue these laws"

Original: Poi ch’ebbe sospirando il capo mosso, "A ciò non fu’ io sol", disse, "né certo sanza cagion con li altri sarei mosso
Translate: "After he shook his head sighing, he said, "I was not the only one to fight that battle, nor would I have gone there for no good reason."

Original: Ma fu’ io solo, là dove sofferto fu per ciascun di tòrre via Fiorenza, colui che la difesi a viso aperto"
Translate: "In return I was the only one to defend Florence with an open face, when each Ghibelline head was ready to shave it to the ground"

Original: "Deh, se riposi mai vostra semenza", prega’ io lui, "solvetemi quel nodo che qui ha ’nviluppata mia sentenza
Translate: "Then I begged him, "Now may your descendants find peace: solve to me the doubt that tangles my reasonings."

Original: El par che voi veggiate, se ben odo, dinanzi quel che ’l tempo seco adduce, e nel presente tenete altro modo"
Translate: "It seems to me that you damned people see, if I have understood correctly, the future events, while you have other knowledge of the present"

Original: "Noi veggiam, come quei c’ ha mala luce, le cose", disse, "che ne son lontano
Translate: "He said, "We, like those who have a lack of sight, see the things that are far away in time."

Original: cotanto ancor ne splende il sommo duce
Translate: only this allows us God

Original: Quando s’appressano o son, tutto è vano nostro intelletto e s’altri non ci apporta,
Translate: "When things come near or happen, our intellect is vain and if others bring us no news, "

Original: nulla sapem di vostro stato umano
Translate: We don't know anything about your human condition.

Original: Però comprender puoi che tutta morta fia nostra conoscenza da quel punto che del futuro fia chiusa la porta"
Translate: "Therefore you can understand that our knowledge will be totally cancelled from the moment the door of the future is closed, that is, the Day of Judgment"

Original: Allor, come di mia colpa compunto, dissi: "Or direte dunque a quel caduto che ’l suo nato è co’ vivi ancor congiunto
Translate: "Then, as I repented of my guilt, I said, "Then you shall say to the damned man that his son is still alive."

Original: e s’i’ fui, dianzi, a la risposta muto, fate i saper che ’l fei perché pensava già ne l’error che m’avete soluto"
Translate: "And if I didn't answer him immediately, tell him that I did it because I was in the error that you explained to me"

Original: E già ’l maestro mio mi richiamava
Translate: And by now Virgil would call me back

Original: per ch’i’ pregai lo spirto più avaccio che mi dicesse chi con lu’ istava
Translate: So I prayed quickly to the spirit that would tell me who his companions were.

Original: Dissemi: "Qui con più di mille giaccio: qua dentro è ’l secondo Federico e ’l Cardinale
Translate: "He said to me: "Here I lie with more than a thousand damned: here it is Frederick II of Swabia, as well as Cardinal Ottaviano of the Ubaldini."

Original: e de li altri mi taccio"
Translate: I tell you nothing about the others.

Original: Indi s’ascose
Translate: Then he went back to the grave

Original: e io inver’ l’antico poeta volsi i passi, ripensando a quel parlar che mi parea nemico
Translate: "and I walked toward the ancient poet, rethinking those words that seemed hostile to me."

Original: Elli si mosse
Translate: Virgil Moved

Original: e poi, così andando, mi disse: "Perché se’ tu sì smarrito?"
Translate: " And then, as he walked, he said to me, "Why are you so upset? "

Original: E io li sodisfeci al suo dimando
Translate: And I explained it to her.

Original: "La mente tua conservi quel ch’udito hai contra te", mi comandò quel saggio
Translate: The wise man commanded me, saying, "Your mind remembers what you have heard against you.

Original: "e ora attendi qui", e drizzò ’l dito:  "quando sarai dinanzi al dolce raggio di quella il cui bell’occhio tutto vede, da lei saprai di tua vita il vïaggio"
Translate: "And now listen, and he straightened his finger: "When you are before the sweet ray of her who with her beautiful eyes sees everything, you will know from her your future destiny."

Original: Appresso mosse a man sinistra il piede: lasciammo il muro e gimmo inver’ lo mezzo per un sentier ch’a una valle fiede,  che ’nfin là sù facea spiacer suo lezzo
Translate: "So he turned to the left: we went away from the wall and headed towards the outer edge of the circle, on a path that leads to a valley from which a great smell came up there."

Original: In su l’estremità d’un’alta ripa che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio, venimmo sopra più crudele stipa
Translate: "On the edge of a high bank where there were many rocks piled up in a circle, we came near the next circle"

Original: e quivi, per l’orribile soperchio del puzzo che ’l profondo abisso gitta, ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio  d’un grand’avello,
Translate: "and here, for the horrible excess of the stench that the infernal abyss emanates, we sheltered behind the lid of a great grave, "

Original: ov’io vidi una scritta che dicea: ’Anastasio papa guardo, lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta’
Translate: "where I read a script that said: "Custodisco papa Anastasio, who was misled from the straight path by Fotino"""

Original: "Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo, sì che s’ausi un poco in prima il senso al tristo fiato
Translate: "It is better to wait a little before going down, so that our smell gets used to the bad smell, "

Original: e poi no i fia riguardo"
Translate: then there will be no need for any further consideration.

Original: Così ’l maestro
Translate: So said Virgil.

Original: e io "Alcun compenso", dissi lui, "trova che ’l tempo non passi perduto"
Translate: And I said to him, "Find a way not to pass the time unnecessarily."

Original: Ed elli: "Vedi ch’a ciò penso"
Translate: He's like, "I'm thinking about this guy."

Original: "Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi", cominciò poi a dir, "son tre cerchietti di grado in grado, come que’ che lassi
Translate: "Then he began to say, "My son, beneath these stones are three Circles, one below the other like the others you have seen."

Original: Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti
Translate: They're all full of goddamn spirits.

Original: ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista, intendi come e perché son costretti
Translate: "but in order for you to see them afterwards, hear how and for what reason they are together."

Original: D'ogne malizia, ch'odio in cielo acquista, ingiuria è 'l fine, ed ogne fin cotale o con forza o con frode altrui contrista
Translate: "The end of every malice that attracts the hatred of Heaven is wickedness, and this purpose is achieved by violence or fraud"

Original: Ma perché frode è de l’uom proprio male, più spiace a Dio
Translate: "And since fraud is a sin proper to man, it is more unwelcome to God."

Original: e però stan di sotto li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale
Translate: And the frauds are lower, and they are more punished.

Original: Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto
Translate: The first circle is reserved for violent people

Original: ma perché si fa forza a tre persone, in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto
Translate: "and since violence can be done to three different targets, it is divided into three groups"

Original: A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose, come udirai con aperta ragione
Translate: "You can use violence to God, to yourself, to your neighbor, in people and in their things, as I will explain rationally"

Original: Morte per forza e ferute dogliose nel prossimo si danno, e nel suo avere ruine, incendi e tollette dannose
Translate: "You can give the next death by force, painful wounds, and in his property ruins, fires and robberies."

Original: onde omicide e ciascun che mal fiere, guastatori e predon, tutti tormenta lo giron primo per diverse schiere
Translate: "So the murderers and those who viciously wound, destroyers and raiders, are all tormented in different groups in the first group"

Original: Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta e ne’ suoi beni
Translate: Man can be violent against himself and his patrimony

Original: e però nel secondo giron convien che sanza pro si penta  qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo, biscazza e fonde la sua facultade, e piange là dov’esser de’ giocondo
Translate: "and therefore in the second circle he repents in vain everyone who committed suicide and who squanders and dissipates his money, and regrets his goods on earth when he should live happily."

Original: Puossi far forza ne la deïtade, col cor negando e bestemmiando quella, e spregiando natura e sua bontade
Translate: "You can be violent against God, denying him in your heart and blaspheming his name, or despising nature and his goodness "

Original: e però lo minor giron suggella del segno suo e Soddoma e Caorsa e chi, spregiando Dio col cor, favella
Translate: "Therefore the third group punishes the sodomites and the usurers, as well as those who speak in contempt of God in their hearts."

Original: La frode, ond'ogne coscïenza è morsa, può l'omo usare in colui che 'n lui fida e in quel che fidanza non imborsa
Translate: "The fraud, from which every conscience is remorseful, can be exercised by man towards those who trust and those who do not trust"

Original: Questo modo di retro par ch’incida pur lo vinco d’amor che fa natura
Translate: This second way seems to violate only the bond of love that nature holds

Original: onde nel cerchio secondo s’annida  ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura, falsità, ladroneccio e simonia, ruffian, baratti e simile lordura
Translate: "Therefore in the second circle are punished hypocrites, flatterers, magicians, forgers, thieves, simonians, pimps, barterers and other similar sinners."

Original: Per l’altro modo quell’amor s’oblia che fa natura, e quel ch’è poi aggiunto, di che la fede spezïal si cria
Translate: In the other way one forgets instead that natural love and also the special bond of fidelity that is created among people

Original: onde nel cerchio minore, ov’è ’l punto de l’universo in su che Dite siede, qualunque trade in etterno è consunto"
Translate: "Therefore in the Circle less wide, where Lucifer has its headquarters, is punished eternally those who have committed treason"

Original: E io: "Maestro, assai chiara procede la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue questo baràtro e ’l popol ch’e’ possiede
Translate: "And I: "Master, your reasoning is very clear and very well distinguishes this abyss and the damned who are punished"

Original: Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue, che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia, e che s’incontran con sì aspre lingue,
Translate: "But tell me: those of the muddy swamp , the others who are dragged by the storm , those who are beaten by the rain and who turn abusive words , "

Original: perché non dentro da la città roggia sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira? e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?"
Translate: "Why are they not punished within the city of Say if God hates them? And if not, why am I in Hell?"

Original: Ed elli a me "Perché tanto delira", disse, "lo ’ngegno tuo da quel che sòle?
Translate: "And he said to me, 'Because your ingenuity deviates so much from the path that it usually travels,'

Original: o ver la mente dove altrove mira?
Translate: or where else do you look at your mind?

Original: Non ti rimembra di quelle parole con le quai la tua Etica pertratta le tre disposizion che ’l ciel non vole,
Translate: "You do not remember those words with which Aristotle's Ethics treats the three sins that Heaven condemns, "

Original: incontenenza, malizia e la matta bestialitade?
Translate: "excess, malice and crazy beastliness? "

Original: e come incontenenza men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?
Translate: and how does excess offend less God and thus is condemned less harshly?

Original: Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza, e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,  tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata la divina vendetta li martelli"
Translate: "If you reflect well on this statement and think of those damned who are punished outside of this city, you will see well why they are separated from these sinners and why they are less punished by divine justice."

Original: "O sol che sani ogne vista turbata, tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi, che, non men che saver, dubbiar m'aggrata
Translate: "I said, "O sun that heals every troubled gaze, you satisfied me so much, when you solve my doubt, that doubt gives me pleasure as wisdom."

Original: Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi", diss’io, "là dove di’ ch’usura offende la divina bontade, e ’l groppo solvi"
Translate: "Go back a little more, where you said that wear offends divine goodness, and solve this uncertainty for me"

Original: "Filosofia", mi disse, "a chi la ’ntende, nota, non pure in una sola parte, come natura lo suo corso prende  dal divino ’ntelletto e da sua arte
Translate: "He said to me: "Philosophy, for those who understand it, explains in several books that nature takes its course from the divine intellect and its industriousness."

Original: e se tu ben la tua Fisica note, tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,  che l’arte vostra quella, quanto pote, segue, come ’l maestro fa ’l discente
Translate: "and if you read the Physics well, you will find almost at the beginning that your industriousness follows that of God as he can, as the disciple follows the teacher."

Original: sì che vostr’arte a Dio quasi è nepote
Translate: so that this activity of yours is almost descended from God

Original: Da queste due, se tu ti rechi a mente lo Genesì dal principio, convene prender sua vita e avanzar la gente
Translate: "And if you think of what the book of Genesis says, you will see that men must gain sustenance and advance from these two industriousnesses."

Original: e perché l’usuriere altra via tene, per sé natura e per la sua seguace dispregia, poi ch’in altro pon la spene
Translate: "and because the usurer walks another way, he despises nature as such and with regard to industriousness, since he puts his hope in another."

Original: Ma seguimi oramai che ’l gir mi piace
Translate: "But follow me now, for I think we must go."

Original: ché i Pesci guizzan su per l’orizzonta, e ’l Carro tutto sovra ’l Coro giace,  e ’l balzo via là oltra si dismonta"
Translate: "In fact the Pisces flow on the horizon, and the Chariot lies all over the Choir, and we have to go further before the passage to the Circle below"

Original: Era lo loco ov’a scender la riva venimmo, alpestro e, per quel che v’er’anco, tal, ch’ogne vista ne sarebbe schiva
Translate: "The place where we came down to the next circle was impervious, and, even for what was there, so that no one would want to see it."

Original: Qual è quella ruina che nel fianco di qua da Trento l’Adice percosse, o per tremoto o per sostegno manco,
Translate: "Like that landslide that hit the Adige bed south of Trento, due to an earthquake or lack of support, "

Original: che da cima del monte, onde si mosse, al piano è sì la roccia discoscesa, ch’alcuna via darebbe a chi sù fosse:
Translate: "so that from the top of the mountain from which it moved to the plain the rock has broken down, but it would give access to someone coming down from above:"

Original: cotal di quel burrato era la scesa
Translate: So was the descent of that hellish ravine

Original: e ’n su la punta de la rotta lacca l’infamïa di Creti era distesa  che fu concetta ne la falsa vacca
Translate: "and at the very beginning of the cliff was the shame of Crete, which was conceived in the fake cow"

Original: e quando vide noi, sé stesso morse, sì come quei cui l’ira dentro fiacca
Translate: "And when he saw us, he bit himself like he who is overwhelmed with wrath."

Original: Lo savio mio inver’ lui gridò: "Forse tu credi che qui sia ’l duca d’Atene, che sù nel mondo la morte ti porse?
Translate: "My teacher cried out to him, "Maybe you think there is the Duke of Athens here, who caused you to die in the world?"

Original: Pàrtiti, bestia, ché questi non vene ammaestrato da la tua sorella, ma vassi per veder le vostre pene"
Translate: "Go away, you beast: for he is not following your sister's instructions, but go and see your sorrows."

Original: Qual è quel toro che si slaccia in quella c’ ha ricevuto già ’l colpo mortale, che gir non sa, ma qua e là saltella,  vid’io lo Minotauro far cotale
Translate: "Like the bull that gets rid of the laces at the moment he received the fatal blow, and can't walk but crawls here and there, so I saw that he was doing the Minotaur."

Original: e quello accorto gridò: "Corri al varco
Translate: And the wise Virgil cried, Run to the passage:

Original: mentre ch’e’ ’nfuria, è buon che tu ti cale"
Translate: "It is good for you to come down, while the monster is in fury"

Original: Così prendemmo via giù per lo scarco di quelle pietre, che spesso moviensi sotto i miei piedi per lo novo carco
Translate: "So we walked down the cliff of those stones, which often moved under my feet because of the weight they were not used to."

Original: Io gia pensando
Translate: "I was thinking, "

Original: e quei disse: "Tu pensi forse a questa ruina, ch’è guardata da quell’ira bestial ch’i’ ora spensi
Translate: "And Virgilio said, 'You may think of this landslide, which is watched over by that angry monster that I have now engulfed.'

Original: Or vo’ che sappi che l’altra fïata ch’i’ discesi qua giù nel basso inferno, questa roccia non era ancor cascata
Translate: "Now I want you to know that the last time I went down here to Hell, that rock hadn't collapsed yet."

Original: Ma certo poco pria, se ben discerno, che venisse colui che la gran preda levò a Dite del cerchio superno,  da tutte parti l’alta valle feda tremò sì, ch’i’ pensai che l’universo sentisse amor, per lo qual è chi creda  più volte il mondo in caòsso converso
Translate: "But shortly before, if I understand correctly, that the One who drew from the First Circle the spirits of the patriarchs came, the deep fetid valley trembled from all sides, so that I thought that the Universe felt love, for which some believe that the world has repeatedly converted into chaos."

Original: e in quel punto questa vecchia roccia, qui e altrove, tal fece riverso
Translate: "and in that moment this old rock, here and elsewhere, collapsed"

Original: Ma ficca li occhi a valle, ché s’approccia la riviera del sangue in la qual bolle qual che per vïolenza in altrui noccia"
Translate: "But turn your eyes to the valley, for the river of blood is approaching in which the one who harms others is boiling out of violence."

Original: Oh cieca cupidigia e ira folle, che sì ci sproni ne la vita corta, e ne l’etterna poi sì mal c’immolle
Translate: "Oh blind greed and mad anger, that drives us so much into our short life and then into that eternal immerse us so atrociously"

Original: Io vidi un’ampia fossa in arco torta, come quella che tutto ’l piano abbraccia, secondo ch’avea detto la mia scorta
Translate: "I saw a large semicircular moat, for it surrounds the whole flat area, just as my guide had told me."

Original: e tra ’l piè de la ripa ed essa, in traccia corrien centauri, armati di saette, come solien nel mondo andare a caccia
Translate: "and between the base of the rock and the moat ran in a row of centaurs, armed with bows and arrows, just as they used to go hunting in the world."

Original: Veggendoci calar, ciascun ristette, e de la schiera tre si dipartiro con archi e asticciuole prima elette
Translate: And when they saw us going down, every one of them stood still, and three came out of the host, with the bows and arrows which they had chosen before.

Original: e l’un gridò da lungi: "A qual martiro venite voi che scendete la costa? Ditel costinci se non, l’arco tiro"
Translate: "And one cried out from afar, "What pain do you come down from down the bow? Tell us from there, or else I will throw an arrow."

Original: Lo mio maestro disse: "La risposta farem noi a Chirón costà di presso: mal fu la voglia tua sempre sì tosta"
Translate: "My teacher said to him, "We will give the answer to Chiron, when we are near him: your desire was always so impulsive and to your detriment."

Original: Poi mi tentò, e disse: "Quelli è Nesso, che morì per la bella Deianira, e fé di sé la vendetta elli stesso
Translate: "Then Virgil took me by the arm and said, "That's Nesso, who died for the beautiful Deianira and took vengeance from himself."

Original: E quel di mezzo, ch’al petto si mira, è il gran Chirón, il qual nodrì Achille
Translate: "And the one in the middle, who looks at his chest, is the great Chiron, who was the tutor of Achilles."

Original: quell’altro è Folo, che fu sì pien d’ira
Translate: "The other is Folo, who was so full of anger"

Original: Dintorno al fosso vanno a mille a mille, saettando qual anima si svelle del sangue più che sua colpa sortille"
Translate: "Around the river they go thousands, hitting with arrows every soul that comes out of the blood more than its guilt has given it"

Original: Noi ci appressammo a quelle fiere isnelle: Chirón prese uno strale, e con la cocca fece la barba in dietro a le mascelle
Translate: We drew near to those agile beasts: Chiron took an arrow, and thrust his beard back on his jaws with his cush.

Original: Quando s’ebbe scoperta la gran bocca, disse a’ compagni: "Siete voi accorti che quel di retro move ciò ch’el tocca?  Così non soglion far li piè d’i morti"
Translate: "After he discovered his great mouth, he said to his companions: "Did you realize that the one behind moves what he touches?The feet of the dead do not usually do so."

Original: E ’l mio buon duca, che già li er’al petto, dove le due nature son consorti,  rispuose: "Ben è vivo, e sì soletto mostrar li mi convien la valle buia
Translate: "And my good teacher, who was already near his chest where the two natures are united, answered, "Surely, Dante is alive, and I must show him only the dark valley."

Original: necessità ’l ci ’nduce, e non diletto
Translate: " necessity pushes him here, not pleasure"

Original: Tal si partì da cantare alleluia che mi commise quest’officio novo: non è ladron, né io anima fuia
Translate: "A person who left his cell in Paradise entrusted me with this new task: he is not a thief, nor I am an evildoer."

Original: Ma per quella virtù per cu’ io movo li passi miei per sì selvaggia strada, danne un de’ tuoi, a cui noi siamo a provo,
Translate: "But by that power that I move my steps on such an arduous path, give us one of your centaurs to which we can stand close, "

Original: e che ne mostri là dove si guada, e che porti costui in su la groppa, ché non è spirto che per l’aere vada"
Translate: "Because you show us the point where you take the river and why you take Dante on the back, since he is not a spirit that can fly in mid-air"

Original: Chirón si volse in su la destra poppa, e disse a Nesso: "Torna, e sì li guida, e fa cansar s’altra schiera v’intoppa"
Translate: And Chiron turned to his right hand, and said unto Nessus, Turn back, and guide them, and move them that hinder them.

Original: Or ci movemmo con la scorta fida lungo la proda del bollor vermiglio, dove i bolliti facieno alte strida
Translate: "Then we moved along that trusted guide, along the banks of the bloody river where the damned shouted out loud."

Original: Io vidi gente sotto infino al ciglio
Translate: I saw souls dipped to the eyelashes

Original: e ’l gran centauro disse: "E’ son tiranni che dier nel sangue e ne l’aver di piglio
Translate: "And the great centaur said, "They are tyrants, who offended others in the person and in the possessions."

Original: Quivi si piangon li spietati danni
Translate: Here we regret the ruthlessly inflicted damage

Original: quivi è Alessandro, e Dïonisio fero che fé Cicilia aver dolorosi anni
Translate: "Here is Alexander, and the fierce Dionysus who gave painful years to Sicily"

Original: E quella fronte c’ ha ’l pel così nero, è Azzolino
Translate: And that damn guy who has such black hair is Ezzelino.

Original: e quell’altro ch’è biondo, è Opizzo da Esti, il qual per vero  fu spento dal figliastro sù nel mondo"
Translate: "The other who is blond is Òbizzo d'Este, who was truly killed by his stepson in the earthly world"

Original: Allor mi volsi al poeta, e quei disse: "Questi ti sia or primo, e io secondo"
Translate: " Then I turned to the poet, and he said, "This is your first guide, I will be the second guide."

Original: Poco più oltre il centauro s’affisse sovr’una gente che ’nfino a la gola parea che di quel bulicame uscisse
Translate: Soon afterward the centaur stood by the damned who seemed to come out of the bulicame to the throat

Original: Mostrocci un’ombra da l’un canto sola, dicendo: "Colui fesse in grembo a Dio lo cor che ’n su Tamisi ancor si cola"
Translate: "He showed us a shadow isolated from one side, saying, "That pierced the heart in the church that still today is venerated on the Thames."

Original: Poi vidi gente che di fuor del rio tenean la testa e ancor tutto ’l casso
Translate: Then I saw damned men holding their heads out of the river, and all their breasts out of the river.

Original: e di costoro assai riconobb’io
Translate: and of these I recognized some of them

Original: Così a più a più si facea basso quel sangue, sì che cocea pur li piedi
Translate: "At that point the blood was getting lower and lower, so that he would only cook the feet of the damned."

Original: e quindi fu del fosso il nostro passo
Translate: And we forsook the river that way.

Original: "Sì come tu da questa parte vedi lo bulicame che sempre si scema", disse ’l centauro,
Translate: "The centaur said, "As you see, on this side, that the bulicame gradually descends, "

Original: "voglio che tu credi  che da quest’altra a più a più giù prema lo fondo suo, infin ch’el si raggiunge ove la tirannia convien che gema
Translate: "I want you to believe that on the other side the river gradually lowers the bottom, until it reaches the point where the tyrants groan."

Original: La divina giustizia di qua punge quell’Attila che fu flagello in terra, e Pirro e Sesto
Translate: "Divine justice on that side punishes Attila, who was scourge on Earth, and Pyrrhus and Sixth "

Original: e in etterno munge  le lagrime, che col bollor diserra, a Rinier da Corneto, a Rinier Pazzo, che fecero a le strade tanta guerra"
Translate: "and forever squeezed out the tears, hatched by the boil, of Rinieri da Corneto, of Rinieri dei Pazzi, who made so much war on the streets "

Original: Poi si rivolse e ripassossi ’l guazzo
Translate: Then he turned around and went over the moth.

Original: Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato, quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco che da neun sentiero era segnato
Translate: "Now he had not yet arrived on the other side, when we walked through a forest where there was no path."

Original: Non fronda verde, ma di color fosco
Translate: "The leaves were not green, but dark in color"

Original: non rami schietti, ma nodosi e ’nvolti
Translate: "The branches were not smooth, but knotted and twisted."

Original: non pomi v’eran, ma stecchi con tòsco
Translate: "There were no fruits, but poisonous thorns."

Original: Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti quelle fiere selvagge che ’n odio hanno tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti
Translate: "Those wild beasts that in Maremma, between Cecina and Corneto, avoid the inhabited places, do not have so harsh and so intricate dungeons"

Original: Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno, che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani con tristo annunzio di futuro danno
Translate: "Here they nidify the filthy Harpies, who chased the Trojans out of the Strophad Islands and told them sad misfortunes."

Original: Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani, piè con artigli, e pennuto ’l gran ventre
Translate: "They have large wings, necks and human faces, clawed legs and a large feathered belly."

Original: fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani
Translate: They shed lamentations on strange trees

Original: E ’l buon maestro "Prima che più entre, sappi che se’ nel secondo girone", mi cominciò a dire, "e sarai mentre  che tu verrai ne l’orribil sabbione
Translate: "And the good teacher began to say to me, "Before you go into the forest, know that you are in the second circle, and you will remain there until we enter the fiery sand."

Original: Però riguarda ben sì vederai cose che torrien fede al mio sermone"
Translate: "So look carefully, for you will see things that would not have been believed if I just told you"

Original: Io sentia d’ogne parte trarre guai e non vedea persona che ’l facesse
Translate: "I could hear complaints coming from all sides, but I couldn't see anyone making them out."

Original: per ch’io tutto smarrito m’arrestai
Translate: "So I stopped, confused."

Original: Cred’ïo ch’ei credette ch’io credesse che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi, da gente che per noi si nascondesse
Translate: "I believe that Virgilio believed that I believed that among those bushes came out so many voices, issued by souls who were hiding from us."

Original: Però disse ’l maestro: "Se tu tronchi qualche fraschetta d’una d’este piante, li pensier c’ hai si faran tutti monchi"
Translate: "Therefore the teacher said, "If you break any twig from one of these plants, your thoughts will no longer have reason to be."

Original: Allor porsi la mano un poco avante e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno
Translate: And I stretched out my hand a little, and plucked a twig out of a great thorn.

Original: e ’l tronco suo gridò: "Perché mi schiante?"
Translate: And his trunk cried out, "Why do you break me?"

Original: Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno, ricominciò a dir: "Perché mi scerpi? non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
Translate: "After she had lost black blood, she began again to say, "Why do you tear me? Do you have no spirit of mercy?"

Original: Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi: ben dovrebb’esser la tua man più pia, se state fossimo anime di serpi"
Translate: "I smoke men, and now we have become bushes: your hand would certainly be more pitiful, even if we had been souls of serpents"

Original: Come d’un stizzo verde ch’arso sia da l’un de’ capi, che da l’altro geme e cigola per vento che va via,
Translate: "Like when you burn a green twig from one end, and on the other you drip the sap and you hear a squeal as it comes out of the air, "

Original: sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme parole e sangue
Translate: So words and blood came out of the broken branch together.

Original: ond’io lasciai la cima cadere, e stetti come l’uom che teme
Translate: Then I let down the broken branch, and stood there full of fear.

Original: "S’elli avesse potuto creder prima", rispuose ’l savio mio, "anima lesa, ciò c’ ha veduto pur con la mia rima,  non averebbe in te la man distesa
Translate: "My teacher answered, "If he could have believed what he read only in my verses, an offended soul, he would not have lifted up his hand against you."

Original: ma la cosa incredibile mi fece indurlo ad ovra ch’a me stesso pesa
Translate: But the incredible thing forced me to lead him to an action that weighs on me, too.

Original: Ma dilli chi tu fosti, sì che ’n vece d’alcun’ammenda tua fama rinfreschi nel mondo sù, dove tornar li lece"
Translate: "But tell him who you were alive, so that he can restore your fame in the earthly world, where he can return"

Original: E ’l tronco: "Sì col dolce dir m’adeschi, ch’i’ non posso tacere
Translate: And the trunk: "With your sweet words I lure myself so that I cannot shut up."

Original: e voi non gravi perch’ïo un poco a ragionar m’inveschi
Translate: And it's not annoying to you if I hold back a little bit and talk about myself.

Original: Io son colui che tenni ambo le chiavi del cor di Federigo, e che le volsi, serrando e diserrando, sì soavi,  che dal secreto suo quasi ogn’uom tolsi
Translate: "I am the one who held both the keys of Frederick II's heart, and who used them so well in closing and opening that almost everyone excluded from his secrets: "

Original: fede portai al glorïoso offizio, tanto ch’i’ ne perde’ li sonni e ’ polsi
Translate: "I was faithful to my high office, so much so that I lost peace and life"

Original: La meretrice che mai da l’ospizio di Cesare non torse li occhi putti, morte comune e de le corti vizio,  infiammò contra me li animi tutti
Translate: "The prostitute who never turned her dishonest eyes from the emperor's palace, and who died of all and vice of the courts, inflame all souls against me."

Original: e li ’nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto, che ’ lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti
Translate: " and they in turn inflamed the emperor, to the point that my honors turned into mourning "

Original: L’animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto, credendo col morir fuggir disdegno, ingiusto fece me contra me giusto
Translate: "My soul, driven by bitter pleasure, believing to escape dishonor with death, made me unjust against myself, even though I had no fault"

Original: Per le nove radici d’esto legno vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede al mio segnor, che fu d’onor sì degno
Translate: "By the new roots of this tree, I swear to you that I was never unfaithful to my lord, who was so worthy of honor."

Original: E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede, conforti la memoria mia, che giace ancor del colpo che ’nvidia le diede"
Translate: "And if any of you return to the earthly world, rehabilitate my memory, which still suffers from the blow suffered because of envy"

Original: Un poco attese, e poi "Da ch’el si tace", disse ’l poeta a me, "non perder l’ora
Translate: "Virgilio remained a little in silence, then said to me, "Since he is silent, do not waste time."

Original: ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace"
Translate: Speak and ask him what you want.

Original: Ond’ïo a lui: "Domandal tu ancora di quel che credi ch’a me satisfaccia
Translate: And I to him: "Ask him again about those arguments that you think may interest me

Original: ch’i’ non potrei, tanta pietà m’accora"
Translate: "I couldn't, so much is the disturbance I feel"

Original: Perciò ricominciò: "Se l’om ti faccia liberamente ciò che ’l tuo dir priega, spirito incarcerato, ancor ti piaccia  di dirne come l’anima si lega in questi nocchi
Translate: "Then Virgilio resumed: "May what your words required be accomplished through spontaneous action, or imprisoned spirit: I ask you again to tell us how the soul binds itself to these trunks, "

Original: e dinne, se tu puoi, s’alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega"
Translate: "and tell us, if you can, if anyone ever gets rid of these plants"

Original: Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi si convertì quel vento in cotal voce: "Brievemente sarà risposto a voi
Translate: Then the trunk blew loudly, and then the air turned into these words, saying, "I will answer you shortly."

Original: Quando si parte l’anima feroce dal corpo ond’ella stessa s’è disvelta, Minòs la manda a la settima foce
Translate: "When the ferocious soul separates itself from the body from which it is detached, Minos sends it to the seventh circle."

Original: Cade in la selva, e non l’è parte scelta
Translate: He falls into the forest and doesn't end up at a pre-defined point.

Original: ma là dove fortuna la balestra, quivi germoglia come gran di spelta
Translate: "but where the case hurles it, there it sprouts like a seed of spelt."

Original: Surge in vermena e in pianta silvestra: l’Arpie, pascendo poi de le sue foglie, fanno dolore, e al dolor fenestra
Translate: "It grows like a shrub and a wild plant: the Harpies, then, feeding on its leaves cause pain, and open a way through which the pain comes out."

Original: Come l’altre verrem per nostre spoglie, ma non però ch’alcuna sen rivesta, ché non è giusto aver ciò ch’om si toglie
Translate: "Like the other souls, we will go and take back our bodies, but not to clothe them: for it is not right to have what has been taken away from us."

Original: Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi, ciascuno al prun de l’ombra sua molesta"
Translate: "We will drag them here and our bodies will be hung by the sad forest, each to the tree of his enemy shadow"

Original: Noi eravamo ancora al tronco attesi, credendo ch’altro ne volesse dire,
Translate: "We were still waiting next to the tree, believing that he wanted to add more, "

Original: quando noi fummo d’un romor sorpresi,  similemente a colui che venire sente ’l porco e la caccia a la sua posta, ch’ode le bestie, e le frasche stormire
Translate: "when we were surprised by a noise, like the one who hears the boar and the dog's mute coming on his tracks, and who listens to the beasts and the foliage that stumbles"

Original: Ed ecco due da la sinistra costa, nudi e graffiati, fuggendo sì forte, che de la selva rompieno ogne rosta
Translate: "And behold, there came from the left two damned, naked and scratched, that fled so fast that they broke every branch of the forest."

Original: Quel dinanzi: "Or accorri, accorri, morte"
Translate: "The one in front was screaming: "Soon, come to help, come, or die"

Original: E l’altro, cui pareva tardar troppo, gridava: "Lano, sì non furo accorte  le gambe tue a le giostre dal Toppo"
Translate: "And the other, to whom it seemed to go too slow, cried out: "Lano, your legs were not so agile at the rides of Pieve del Toppo"

Original: E poi che forse li fallia la lena, di sé e d’un cespuglio fece un groppo
Translate: "And because he might have missed his breath, he hid himself beside a bush."

Original: Di rietro a loro era la selva piena di nere cagne, bramose e correnti come veltri ch’uscisser di catena
Translate: "Behind them the forest was full of black bitches, running hungry like wild hunting dogs."

Original: In quel che s’appiattò miser li denti, e quel dilaceraro a brano a brano
Translate: And they bewitched the damned man that hid himself, and tore him to shreds.

Original: poi sen portar quelle membra dolenti
Translate: Then they took away his still sore flesh.

Original: Presemi allor la mia scorta per mano, e menommi al cespuglio che piangea per le rotture sanguinenti in vano
Translate: "Then my guide took me by the hand and led me to the bush crying, unnecessarily, through the broken and bleeding branches."

Original: "O Iacopo", dicea, "da Santo Andrea, che t’è giovato di me fare schermo? che colpa ho io de la tua vita rea?"
Translate: "He said, "O Iacopo from St. Andrew, what use did you use me as a shield? What fault do I have in your sinful life?"

Original: Quando ’l maestro fu sovr’esso fermo, disse: "Chi fosti, che per tante punte soffi con sangue doloroso sermo?"
Translate: "When my teacher stood over him, he said, "Who have you been alive, you who breathe painful words and blood through so many broken branches?"

Original: Ed elli a noi: "O anime che giunte siete a veder lo strazio disonesto c’ ha le mie fronde sì da me disgiunte,  raccoglietele al piè del tristo cesto
Translate: "And he said, "O souls who have come to see the dishonest mess that has separated my fronds from me, gather them at the foot of the sad bush."

Original: I’ fui de la città che nel Batista mutò ’l primo padrone
Translate: I was of the city that changed to St. John the Baptist the first protector

Original: ond’ei per questo  sempre con l’arte sua la farà trista
Translate: And for this he will always sadden her with his art

Original: e se non fosse che ’n sul passo d’Arno rimane ancor di lui alcuna vista,  que’ cittadin che poi la rifondarno sovra ’l cener che d’Attila rimase, avrebber fatto lavorare indarno
Translate: "and if it were not that on a bridge of the Arno remains a fragment of his statue, those citizens who rebuilt it on the ashes left by Attila, would have worked unnecessarily"

Original: Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case"
Translate: I hung myself in my house.

Original: Poi che la carità del natio loco mi strinse, raunai le fronde sparte e rende’ le a colui, ch’era già fioco
Translate: "For my love for the common homeland moved me, and I gathered the scattered branches, and laid them at the roots of the tree, where the soul was now exhausted."

Original: Indi venimmo al fine ove si parte lo secondo giron dal terzo, e dove si vede di giustizia orribil arte
Translate: "So we came to the point where the second group divides from the third, and where we see the terrible divine punishment"

Original: A ben manifestar le cose nove, dico che arrivammo ad una landa che dal suo letto ogne pianta rimove
Translate: "To explain the novelty of the place well, I say that we arrived at a flat place that does not allow any plant to grow in it."

Original: La dolorosa selva l’è ghirlanda intorno, come ’l fosso tristo ad essa
Translate: "The forest of suicides crowns them all around, like the Flegeton with it: "

Original: quivi fermammo i passi a randa a randa
Translate: Here we stopped the step right on the edge

Original: Lo spazzo era una rena arida e spessa, non d’altra foggia fatta che colei che fu da’ piè di Caton già soppressa
Translate: "The ground was made of thick and dry sand, very similar to that which was already trodden by the feet of Cato Uticense"

Original: O vendetta di Dio, quanto tu dei esser temuta da ciascun che legge ciò che fu manifesto a li occhi mei
Translate: "O divine vengeance, how much you must be feared by every reader who learns what I saw with my eyes"

Original: D’anime nude vidi molte gregge che piangean tutte assai miseramente, e parea posta lor diversa legge
Translate: "I saw many groups of naked souls, all crying very painfully, and it seemed that each one obeyed different rules"

Original: Supin giacea in terra alcuna gente, alcuna si sedea tutta raccolta, e altra andava continüamente
Translate: "Some souls lay on the ground supine, others sat gathered, still others walked continually"

Original: Quella che giva ’ntorno era più molta, e quella men che giacëa al tormento, ma più al duolo avea la lingua sciolta
Translate: "The souls running around in circles were more numerous, but the ones lying down were less, but they were more ready to complain."

Original: Sovra tutto ’l sabbion, d’un cader lento, piovean di foco dilatate falde, come di neve in alpe sanza vento
Translate: "Over all the sand, there was a slow rain of the broad layers of fire, like snowflakes falling into a mountain where the wind does not blow."

Original: Quali Alessandro in quelle parti calde d’Indïa vide sopra ’l süo stuolo fiamme cadere infino a terra salde,
Translate: "As Alexander the Great in the warm regions of India saw flames fall unto the ground on his troops, "

Original: per ch’ei provide a scalpitar lo suolo con le sue schiere, acciò che lo vapore mei si stingueva mentre ch’era solo:
Translate: So he gave orders to the soldiers to chisel the ground because the steam was better extinguished before propagating:

Original: tale scendeva l’etternale ardore
Translate: So those eternal flames came down.

Original: onde la rena s’accendea, com’esca sotto focile, a doppiar lo dolore
Translate: " so that the sand would light up, just like the bait with theacciarino, to increase the pain"

Original: Sanza riposo mai era la tresca de le misere mani, or quindi or quinci escotendo da sé l’arsura fresca
Translate: "The dance of the wretched hands was without pause, while they were shaking the new fire on one side and on the other."

Original: I’ cominciai: "Maestro, tu che vinci tutte le cose, fuor che ’ demon duri ch’a l’intrar de la porta incontra uscinci,
Translate: "I began: "Master, you who overcome all things except the stubborn devils who came out to meet us on the threshold of the gate, "

Original: chi è quel grande che non par che curi lo ’ncendio e giace dispettoso e torto, sì che la pioggia non par che ’l marturi?"
Translate: "Who is the great one who does not seem to worry about the fire and lies contemptuous and twisting, so that the rain of fire does not seem to cause him pain?"

Original: E quel medesmo, che si fu accorto ch’io domandava il mio duca di lui, gridò: "Qual io fui vivo, tal son morto
Translate: "And the same damned one, who knew that I asked of him to my guide, cried out, "I am dead, which I was alive."

Original: Se Giove stanchi ’l suo fabbro da cui crucciato prese la folgore aguta onde l’ultimo dì percosso fui
Translate: "If also Jupiter wearied his blacksmith from whom, angry, he took the sharp lightning that struck me on the day of my death."

Original: o s’elli stanchi li altri a muta a muta in Mongibello a la focina negra, chiamando "Buon Vulcano, aiuta, aiuta",
Translate: "or if he tires the other Cyclops without rest in Etna, near the black forge, shouting "Good Volcano, help, help, "

Original: sì com’el fece a la pugna di Flegra, e me saetti con tutta sua forza: non ne potrebbe aver vendetta allegra"
Translate: "Just as he did in the battle of Flegra, and struck me with all his might, he could not avenge me"

Original: Allora il duca mio parlò di forza tanto, ch’i’ non l’avea sì forte udito:
Translate: Then my teacher spoke with his voice so altered as I had never heard it:

Original: "O Capaneo, in ciò che non s’ammorza  la tua superbia, se’ tu più punito
Translate: "O Capaneo, in the fact that your pride does not diminish you are more punished: "

Original: nullo martiro, fuor che la tua rabbia, sarebbe al tuo furor dolor compito"
Translate: "No punishment would be appropriate to your fury, except your own anger"

Original: Poi si rivolse a me con miglior labbia, dicendo: "Quei fu l’un d’i sette regi ch’assiser Tebe
Translate: "Then he turned to me with a calmer face, saying, "That was one of the seven kings who besieged Thebes."

Original: ed ebbe e par ch’elli abbia  Dio in disdegno, e poco par che ’l pregi
Translate: "and despised God, and it seems that he still does, and it seems that he does not consider his power."

Original: ma, com’io dissi lui, li suoi dispetti sono al suo petto assai debiti fregi
Translate: "but, as I told him, his anger is worthy adornment to his chest."

Original: Or mi vien dietro, e guarda che non metti, ancor, li piedi ne la rena arsiccia
Translate: "Now follow me and be careful not to put your feet in the fiery sand,"

Original: ma sempre al bosco tien li piedi stretti"
Translate: but always keep them close to the forest

Original: Tacendo divenimmo là ’ve spiccia fuor de la selva un picciol fiumicello, lo cui rossore ancor mi raccapriccia
Translate: "We went in silence where a small river flows out of the forest, and I am still disgusted by the blush."

Original: Quale del Bulicame esce ruscello che parton poi tra lor le peccatrici, tal per la rena giù sen giva quello
Translate: "As a brook comes out of the Bulicame, and the harlots divide themselves, so the brook flowed down the sand."

Original: Lo fondo suo e ambo le pendici fatt’era ’n pietra, e ’ margini dallato
