Translate: "The backdrop and both embankments were made of stone, "

Original: per ch’io m’accorsi che ’l passo era lici
Translate: So I realized there was a passage there.

Original: "Tra tutto l’altro ch’i’ t’ ho dimostrato, poscia che noi intrammo per la porta lo cui sogliare a nessuno è negato,
Translate: "Among all that I have shown you after crossing the infernal threshold whose passage is not denied to anyone, "

Original: cosa non fu da li tuoi occhi scorta notabile com’è ’l presente rio, che sovra sé tutte fiammelle ammorta"
Translate: "Your eyes have never seen anything as interesting as this river, which extinguishes in itself all the layers of fire"

Original: Queste parole fuor del duca mio
Translate: These words were spoken to me by my guide

Original: per ch’io ’l pregai che mi largisse ’l pasto di cui largito m’avëa il disio
Translate: Then I begged him to bestow upon me the food of which he had given me desire.

Original: "In mezzo mar siede un paese guasto", diss’elli allora, "che s’appella Creta, sotto ’l cui rege fu già ’l mondo casto
Translate: "Then he said, "In the midst of the Mediterranean there is a land that has been destroyed, called Crete, under whose ancient king the world was once innocent. "

Original: Una montagna v’è che già fu lieta d’acqua e di fronde, che si chiamò Ida
Translate: "There is a mountain called Ida, once rich in streams and woods, "

Original: or è diserta come cosa vieta
Translate: now abandoned as an old thing

Original: Rëa la scelse già per cuna fida del suo figliuolo, e per celarlo meglio, quando piangea, vi facea far le grida
Translate: "Rea chose it as a safe hiding place for her son, and to hide it better, when he wept, made you cry."

Original: Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio, che tien volte le spalle inver’ Dammiata e Roma guarda come süo speglio
Translate: "Inside the mountain stands an old man, who turns his back to Damietta and looks at Rome as if it were his mirror."

Original: La sua testa è di fin oro formata, e puro argento son le braccia e ’l petto, poi è di rame infino a la forcata
Translate: "The top is made of pure gold, the arms and the chest are made of pure silver, then it is made of copper to the groin."

Original: da indi in giuso è tutto ferro eletto, salvo che ’l destro piede è terra cotta
Translate: "From here down is all made of iron, except the right foot that is terracotta"

Original: e sta ’n su quel, più che ’n su l’altro, eretto
Translate: and is based on that more than on the other

Original: Ciascuna parte, fuor che l’oro, è rotta d’una fessura che lagrime goccia, le quali, accolte, fóran quella grotta
Translate: "Every part of the statue, except the head, is broken by a crack that makes tears flow, which gather at the feet and pierce the rock below."

Original: lor corso in questa valle si diroccia
Translate: They form a stream of water that descends into the hell's chasm:

Original: fanno Acheronte, Stige e Flegetonta
Translate: They feed the Acheron, the Stige and the Flegetonte.

Original: poi sen van giù per questa stretta doccia,  infin, là ove più non si dismonta, fanno Cocito
Translate: "then they go down again through this narrow canal, even where you no longer go down and where they form Cocytus."

Original: e qual sia quello stagno tu lo vedrai, però qui non si conta"
Translate: "and what that lake is you'll see, so let's not talk about it here"

Original: E io a lui: "Se ’l presente rigagno si diriva così dal nostro mondo, perché ci appar pur a questo vivagno?"
Translate: "And I to him: "If this little river is born so from the earthly world, why then do we see it only now on the edge of the Circle?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tu sai che ’l loco è tondo
Translate: And he said to me, "You know this chasm is round."

Original: e tutto che tu sie venuto molto, pur a sinistra, giù calando al fondo,  non se’ ancor per tutto ’l cerchio vòlto
Translate: "and even if you have walked a good stretch, going down always to the left, you have not yet crossed the entire circumference: "

Original: per che, se cosa n’apparisce nova, non de’ addur maraviglia al tuo volto"
Translate: "so if you see something new, you don't have to be surprised at it"

Original: E io ancor: "Maestro, ove si trova Flegetonta e Letè? ché de l’un taci, e l’altro di’ che si fa d’esta piova"
Translate: "And I said again: "Master, where are the Flegeton and the Lete? of the second silence, while of the first you say it is produced by this rain of tears"

Original: "In tutte tue question certo mi piaci", rispuose, "ma ’l bollor de l’acqua rossa dovea ben solver l’una che tu faci
Translate: "He replied: "I like all your questions, but the boiling of the red water of blood had to solve one of your doubts."

Original: Letè vedrai, ma fuor di questa fossa, là dove vanno l’anime a lavarsi quando la colpa pentuta è rimossa"
Translate: "You will see the Lete, but out of Hell, where souls go to wash themselves when they have repented of their sins and have wiped them out"

Original: Poi disse: "Omai è tempo da scostarsi dal bosco
Translate: Then he added: "It's time to get away from the woods.

Original: fa che di retro a me vegne: li margini fan via, che non son arsi,  e sopra loro ogne vapor si spegne"
Translate: " Follow me along the banks of the river, for they are not burned by the fiery rain, and all fiery steam is quenched upon them."

Original: Ora cen porta l’un de’ duri margini
Translate: Now one of the rocky banks takes us away from the forest

Original: e ’l fummo del ruscel di sopra aduggia, sì che dal foco salva l’acqua e li argini
Translate: "and the smoke of the Flegeton shades above, so that it protects from fire the water and the embankments themselves."

Original: Quali Fiamminghi tra Guizzante e Bruggia, temendo ’l fiotto che ’nver’ lor s’avventa, fanno lo schermo perché ’l mar si fuggia
Translate: "Like the Flemish between Wissant and Bruges, they build dams to keep the tide away, fearing that the waves will come upon them."

Original: e quali Padoan lungo la Brenta, per difender lor ville e lor castelli, anzi che Carentana il caldo senta:
Translate: and as the Paduans do along the Brenta to defend their cities and castles before Carinthia feels the heat:

Original: a tale imagine eran fatti quelli, tutto che né sì alti né sì grossi, qual che si fosse, lo maestro félli
Translate: "so were those embankments built, even if the builder, whoever he was, had not erected them so high and so large."

Original: Già eravam da la selva rimossi tanto, ch’i’ non avrei visto dov’era, perch’io in dietro rivolto mi fossi,
Translate: "We'd gone so far from the forest that I wouldn't have seen her again if I turned around,"

Original: quando incontrammo d’anime una schiera che venian lungo l’argine, e ciascuna ci riguardava come suol da sera  guardare uno altro sotto nuova luna
Translate: When we met a host of souls who came along the bank, and each of them looked at us as if we were looking at someone on a new moon night.

Original: e sì ver’ noi aguzzavan le ciglia come ’l vecchio sartor fa ne la cruna
Translate: And they wrinkled their eyes toward us, as the old tailor does, to put the needle into the eye.

Original: Così adocchiato da cotal famiglia, fui conosciuto da un, che mi prese per lo lembo e gridò: "Qual maraviglia"
Translate: "While the damned were looking at me in this way, I was recognized by one who took me by the skirt of the garment and cried out, "What a marvel!"

Original: E io, quando ’l suo braccio a me distese, ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto, sì che ’l viso abbrusciato non difese  la conoscenza süa al mio ’ntelletto
Translate: "And I, when he stretched out his arm toward me, stared at his face so that I could not fail to recognize him, though all was burned, "

Original: e chinando la mano a la sua faccia, rispuosi: "Siete voi qui, ser Brunetto?"
Translate: "And when I drew my hand closer to his face, I said, "Would you be here, Ser Brunetto?"

Original: E quelli: "O figliuol mio, non ti dispiaccia se Brunetto Latino un poco teco ritorna ’n dietro e lascia andar la traccia"
Translate: "And he: "My son, don't be sorry if Brunetto Latini goes back a little bit with you and lets the line continue "

Original: I’ dissi lui: "Quanto posso, ven preco
Translate: And I said unto him, I pray thee with all my might.

Original: e se volete che con voi m’asseggia, faròl, se piace a costui che vo seco"
Translate: "and if you want me to stay with you, I will do so, as long as you consent to him who leads me."

Original: "O figliuol", disse, "qual di questa greggia s’arresta punto, giace poi cent’anni sanz’arrostarsi quando ’l foco il feggia
Translate: "He said, "Son, if a damned man of this group stops for a moment, then he must lie down a hundred years without being able to repair himself when the fire hurts him."

Original: Però va oltre: i’ ti verrò a’ panni
Translate: Therefore go on, I will follow you.

Original: e poi rigiugnerò la mia masnada, che va piangendo i suoi etterni danni"
Translate: "and then I will join my army, which is weeping its eternal damnation"

Original: Io non osava scender de la strada per andar par di lui
Translate: I dared not go down from the bank to go with him.

Original: ma ’l capo chino tenea com’uom che reverente vada
Translate: "but I kept my head bow, like a man who showed his deference."

Original: El cominciò: "Qual fortuna o destino anzi l’ultimo dì qua giù ti mena? e chi è questi che mostra ’l cammino?"
Translate: He began: "What luck or destiny brings you down here before your death?" and who is this one who guides you?

Original: "Là sù di sopra, in la vita serena", rispuos’io lui, "mi smarri’ in una valle, avanti che l’età mia fosse piena
Translate: "I said to him, "There, in the serene life, I was lost in a valley before my life reached its climax."

Original: Pur ier mattina le volsi le spalle: questi m’apparve, tornand’ïo in quella, e reducemi a ca per questo calle"
Translate: "Only yesterday morning I came out: he appeared to me, as I was going back, and he takes me home on this path."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Se tu segui tua stella, non puoi fallire a glorïoso porto, se ben m’accorsi ne la vita bella
Translate: "And he to me: "If you follow your star, you cannot fail to achieve your literary and political goals, if I understood correctly when I was alive."

Original: e s’io non fossi sì per tempo morto, veggendo il cielo a te così benigno, dato t’avrei a l’opera conforto
Translate: "And if I had not died early, seeing that heaven was so well disposed toward you, I would have helped you to do your work."

Original: Ma quello ingrato popolo maligno che discese di Fiesole ab antico, e tiene ancor del monte e del macigno,  ti si farà, per tuo ben far, nimico
Translate: "But that ungrateful and evil people who descended from Fiesole in ancient times and still preserves the roughness of the mountaineers, will become your enemy for your good deeds: "

Original: ed è ragion, ché tra li lazzi sorbi si disconvien fruttare al dolce fico
Translate: "and has it well from whence, for it is not appropriate for the sweet fig tree to be born among the fruits of the field."

Original: Vecchia fama nel mondo li chiama orbi
Translate: An old proverb calls them blind

Original: gent’è avara, invidiosa e superba: dai lor costumi fa che tu ti forbi
Translate: "They are greedy, envious and proud people: try to keep you from their costumes."

Original: La tua fortuna tanto onor ti serba, che l’una parte e l’altra avranno fame di te
Translate: "Your luck is so honorable to you that both sides will want to vent their hatred against you, "

Original: ma lungi fia dal becco l’erba
Translate: But the grass will be far from the goat

Original: Faccian le bestie fiesolane strame di lor medesme, e non tocchin la pianta, s’alcuna surge ancora in lor letame,
Translate: "The beasts of Fiesole eat among themselves and do not touch the plant, if they are born again in their dung, "

Original: in cui riviva la sementa santa di que’ Roman che vi rimaser quando fu fatto il nido di malizia tanta"
Translate: in which the holy seed of those Romans who remained in Florence was revived when the nest of so much wickedness was founded.

Original: "Se fosse tutto pieno il mio dimando", rispuos’io lui, "voi non sareste ancora de l’umana natura posto in bando
Translate: "I said to him, "If I could fulfill all my desires, you would still be among the living."

Original: ché ’n la mente m’è fitta, e or m’accora, la cara e buona imagine paterna di voi quando nel mondo ad ora ad ora  m’insegnavate come l’uom s’etterna:
Translate: "for in my mind is well present, and now I am moved, the dear and good fatherly image of you when in the world you taught me from time to time how man acquires eternal fame: "

Original: e quant’io l’abbia in grado, mentr’io vivo convien che ne la mia lingua si scerna
Translate: And as long as I live my tongue, he will express how much I am pleased with it.

Original: Ciò che narrate di mio corso scrivo, e serbolo a chiosar con altro testo a donna che saprà, s’a lei arrivo
Translate: "I take note of what you tell of my life, and I reserve the right to have it explained together with another prophecy by a woman who will know how to do it, if I come to her."

Original: Tanto vogl’io che vi sia manifesto, pur che mia coscïenza non mi garra, ch’a la Fortuna, come vuol, son presto
Translate: "I want to make it clear to you that I am ready for what luck reserves for me, as long as my conscience does not remorse me."

Original: Non è nuova a li orecchi miei tal arra: però giri Fortuna la sua rota come le piace, e ’l villan la sua marra"
Translate: "Such a prophecy is not new to my ear: therefore good fortune turns its wheel as it pleases, and the peasant turns his hoe"

Original: Lo mio maestro allora in su la gota destra si volse in dietro e riguardommi
Translate: "My teacher then turned back to the right and looked at me, "

Original: poi disse: "Bene ascolta chi la nota"
Translate: Then he said, "It is a good listener who takes note of what is said to him."

Original: Né per tanto di men parlando vommi con ser Brunetto, e dimando chi sono li suoi compagni più noti e più sommi
Translate: "I didn't stop talking to Ser Brunetto, and I asked him who his most important companions were."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Saper d’alcuno è buono
Translate: And he to me: "It is good to know some of them:

Original: de li altri fia laudabile tacerci, ché ’l tempo saria corto a tanto suono
Translate: "Of the others it will be preferable to keep quiet, because it would take too long to list them all."

Original: In somma sappi che tutti fur cherci e litterati grandi e di gran fama, d’un peccato medesmo al mondo lerci
Translate: "Know in short that they were all clerics and important scholars of great fame, whose life was filthy of the same sin "

Original: Priscian sen va con quella turba grama, e Francesco d’Accorso anche
Translate: "Prisciano goes with that ugly army, and also Francesco d'Accorso"

Original: e vedervi, s’avessi avuto di tal tigna brama,  colui potei che dal servo de’ servi fu trasmutato d’Arno in Bacchiglione, dove lasciò li mal protesi nervi
Translate: "and if you wanted to see such filth, you could see the man whom the servant of servants moved from Florence to Vicenza, where he died and left his senses prosthetic to vice."

Original: Di più direi
Translate: "I'd say more, "

Original: ma ’l venire e ’l sermone più lungo esser non può, però ch’i’ veggio là surger nuovo fummo del sabbione
Translate: "but the way and the discourse cannot be prolonged, for there I see new smoke rising from the sandbell."

Original: Gente vien con la quale esser non deggio
Translate: Here come souls whose ranks I don't have to mingle with

Original: Sieti raccomandato il mio Tesoro, nel qual io vivo ancora, e più non cheggio"
Translate: "Let my Trésor be recommended to you, in whom I still have fame, and I ask no more."

Original: Poi si rivolse, e parve di coloro che corrono a Verona il drappo verde per la campagna
Translate: "Then he turned and looked like one of those who ran the palio to Verona for the green cloth, in the countryside."

Original: e parve di costoro  quelli che vince, non colui che perde
Translate: "and he seemed to be the winner, not the loser"

Original: Già era in loco onde s’udia ’l rimbombo de l’acqua che cadea ne l’altro giro, simile a quel che l’arnie fanno rombo,
Translate: "I was already in a place where you could hear the rumble of the water that was thrown into the Circle below, similar to the buzzing of the bees inside the arnia,\"

Original: quando tre ombre insieme si partiro, correndo, d’una torma che passava sotto la pioggia de l’aspro martiro
Translate: "when three souls separated together, running, from a host that passed through the rain of fire that tormented them."

Original: Venian ver’ noi, e ciascuna gridava: "Sòstati tu ch’a l’abito ne sembri essere alcun di nostra terra prava"
Translate: "They came to us, and each one cried out, "Stop, you who seem to be a citizen of our evil homeland from your habit."

Original: Ahimè, che piaghe vidi ne’ lor membri, ricenti e vecchie, da le fiamme incese
Translate: "Alas, what plagues I saw on their bodies, recent and old, caused by the fiery layers"

Original: Ancor men duol pur ch’i’ me ne rimembri
Translate: "I still regret it today, just think about it"

Original: A le lor grida il mio dottor s’attese
Translate: At their cries my master stopped

Original: volse ’l viso ver’ me, e "Or aspetta", disse, "a costor si vuole esser cortese
Translate: "He turned his face to me and said, "Wait, you must be courteous with these damned."

Original: E se non fosse il foco che saetta la natura del loco, i’ dicerei che meglio stesse a te che a lor la fretta"
Translate: "And if it were not for the rain that makes this place fiery, I would tell you that haste is better for you than for them."

Original: Ricominciar, come noi restammo, ei l’antico verso
Translate: "As we stopped, they began to speak as before."

Original: e quando a noi fuor giunti, fenno una rota di sé tutti e trei
Translate: "And when they reached us, they began to walk all three in a circle."

Original: Qual sogliono i campion far nudi e unti, avvisando lor presa e lor vantaggio, prima che sien tra lor battuti e punti,
Translate: "As they used to do the naked wrestlers and sprinkled with oil, studying the opponent to try a grip before beating and hurting each other, "

Original: così rotando, ciascuno il visaggio drizzava a me, sì che ’n contraro il collo faceva ai piè continüo vïaggio
Translate: "so, while turning his head, each of the three damned stared at me, so that he would twist his neck in the opposite direction to his steps."

Original: E "Se miseria d’esto loco sollo rende in dispetto noi e nostri prieghi", cominciò l’uno, "e ’l tinto aspetto e brollo,
Translate: "And one began: "If the misery of this sandy place and our skinned and skinned appearance lead us to despise us and our prayers, "

Original: la fama nostra il tuo animo pieghi a dirne chi tu se’, che i vivi piedi così sicuro per lo ’nferno freghi
Translate: "but our fame drives your soul to tell us who you are, since you walk so safe in Hell."

Original: Questi, l’orme di cui pestar mi vedi, tutto che nudo e dipelato vada, fu di grado maggior che tu non credi:
Translate: "This man, of whom you see me treading in my footsteps, even though he walks naked and skinned, had a higher condition than you think:"

Original: nepote fu de la buona Gualdrada
Translate: was grandson of the valiant Gualdrada

Original: Guido Guerra ebbe nome, e in sua vita fece col senno assai e con la spada
Translate: "And he was named Guido Guerra: in his life he did great works, with understanding and with the sword."

Original: L’altro, ch’appresso me la rena trita, è Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, la cui voce nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita
Translate: "The other, who tramples the sand behind me, is Tiggiaio Aldobrandi, whose voice must have been more pleasing in the world"

Original: E io, che posto son con loro in croce, Iacopo Rusticucci fui,
Translate: "And I, who share their punishment, was Iacopo Rusticucci"

Original: e certo la fiera moglie più ch’altro mi nuoce"
Translate: And of course my intractable wife has harmed me more than anything else.

Original: S’i’ fossi stato dal foco coperto, gittato mi sarei tra lor di sotto, e credo che ’l dottor l’avria sofferto
Translate: "If I had been protected from fire, I would have thrown myself into the sandbox and I believe the master would have tolerated it."

Original: ma perch’io mi sarei brusciato e cotto, vinse paura la mia buona voglia che di loro abbracciar mi facea ghiotto
Translate: "but because I would burn myself and burn myself, fear prevailed over my desire to embrace them."

Original: Poi cominciai: "Non dispetto, ma doglia la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse, tanta che tardi tutta si dispoglia,
Translate: "Then I began: "Your condition inspired me not contempt but pain, to the point that it will cease in a long time, "

Original: tosto che questo mio segnor mi disse parole per le quali i’ mi pensai che qual voi siete, tal gente venisse
Translate: from the moment my teacher told me words that I thought noble people would come which you actually are

Original: Di vostra terra sono, e sempre mai l’ovra di voi e li onorati nomi con affezion ritrassi e ascoltai
Translate: "I am from Florence and I have always learned by listening to your works and your honorable names, with great affection"

Original: Lascio lo fele e vo per dolci pomi promessi a me per lo verace duca
Translate: "I leave a bitter life and go in search of salvation, promise me by my sincere guidance"

Original: ma ’nfino al centro pria convien ch’i’ tomi"
Translate: But first I have to go down to the end of Hell.

Original: "Se lungamente l’anima conduca le membra tue", rispuose quelli ancora, "e se la fama tua dopo te luca,
Translate: "That one then answered, "May your soul remain still attached to the body for a long time, and you have long fame after death."

Original: cortesia e valor dì se dimora ne la nostra città sì come suole, o se del tutto se n’è gita fora
Translate: "Tell us if in our city they still lodge the courtesy and the value, or if these virtues have completely abandoned it"

Original: ché Guiglielmo Borsiere, il qual si duole con noi per poco e va là coi compagni, assai ne cruccia con le sue parole"
Translate: "In fact Guglielmo Borsiere, who has been our companion of pain for a short time and walks there with the others, we are not a little angry talking about Florence"

Original: "La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni orgoglio e dismisura han generata, Fiorenza, in te, sì che tu già ten piagni"
Translate: "The new citizens and the sudden gains have created haughtiness and excess within you, or Florence, so that you already mourn the consequences"

Original: Così gridai con la faccia levata
Translate: So I cried out and lifted my face up.

Original: e i tre, che ciò inteser per risposta, guardar l’un l’altro com’al ver si guata
Translate: "and the three, who interpreted this as my answer, looked at one another as in the face of an unwelcome truth."

Original: "Se l’altre volte sì poco ti costa", rispuoser tutti, "il satisfare altrui, felice te se sì parli a tua posta
Translate: "Everyone answered, "If even the other times it costs you so little to answer the questions of others, happy are you who speak so bluntly."

Original: Però, se campi d’esti luoghi bui e torni a riveder le belle stelle, quando ti gioverà dicere "I’ fui",  fa che di noi a la gente favelle"
Translate: "Therefore, if you come out of these dark places and return to see the stars, when you will be pleased to say, "I was in hell," speak of us to the living."

Original: Indi rupper la rota, e a fuggirsi ali sembiar le gambe loro isnelle
Translate: So they stopped turning around in circles, and if they went so fast, their slender legs looked like wings.

Original: Un amen non saria possuto dirsi tosto così com’e’ fuoro spariti
Translate: "It wouldn't have been possible to say an "amen" in the short time they disappeared"

Original: per ch’al maestro parve di partirsi
Translate: So it seemed to the teacher that we should leave.

Original: Io lo seguiva, e poco eravam iti, che ’l suon de l’acqua n’era sì vicino, che per parlar saremmo a pena uditi
Translate: "I followed him, and we had traveled little way when the sound of the water seemed so close that, speaking, we would hardly hear"

Original: Come quel fiume c’ ha proprio cammino prima dal Monte Viso ’nver’ levante, da la sinistra costa d’Apennino,
Translate: "Like that river, which first has its own course starting from the Monviso towards the east, from the right slope of the Apennines, "

Original: che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante che si divalli giù nel basso letto, e a Forlì di quel nome è vacante,
Translate: "that on the top is called Acquacheta before going down to the plain and to Forlì changes name, "

Original: rimbomba là sovra San Benedetto de l’Alpe per cadere ad una scesa ove dovea per mille esser recetto
Translate: he bounces over San Benedetto dell'Alpe to fall into a single waterfall where it should be received in a thousand waterfalls

Original: così, giù d’una ripa discoscesa, trovammo risonar quell’acqua tinta, sì che ’n poc’ora avria l’orecchia offesa
Translate: "so we saw that the red river fell down a steep ravine, making so much noise that in a short time it would damage the hearing"

Original: Io avea una corda intorno cinta, e con essa pensai alcuna volta prender la lonza a la pelle dipinta
Translate: "I had a rope around my hips, with which I had previously thought to catch the lion from the spotted skin."

Original: Poscia ch’io l’ebbi tutta da me sciolta, sì come ’l duca m’avea comandato, porsila a lui aggroppata e ravvolta
Translate: "After I loosen it completely, as Virgil had commanded me, to place it tied to him and tangled"

Original: Ond’ei si volse inver’ lo destro lato, e alquanto di lunge da la sponda la gittò giuso in quell’alto burrato
Translate: "So he turned to his right hand and threw it into that deep ravine, standing far from the edge."

Original: ’E’ pur convien che novità risponda’, dicea fra me medesmo, ’al novo cenno che ’l maestro con l’occhio sì seconda’
Translate: "I said between me and myself: 'But it is necessary that something new respond to the new nod, that my teacher follows with such attention'"

Original: Ahi quanto cauti li uomini esser dienno presso a color che non veggion pur l'ovra, ma per entro i pensier miran col senno
Translate: "Alas, how careful men must be when they are beside those who see not only the outward acts, but in their own wisdom they search inside the thoughts."

Original: El disse a me: "Tosto verrà di sovra ciò ch’io attendo e che il tuo pensier sogna
Translate: He said to me: "Well soon will come here above what I expect and that you imagine with the thought:

Original: tosto convien ch’al tuo viso si scovra"
Translate: it is inevitable that you will soon show yourself to your eyes

Original: Sempre a quel ver c' ha faccia di menzogna de' l'uom chiuder le labbra fin ch'el puote, però che sanza colpa fa vergogna
Translate: "Man must always avoid telling a truth that seems false, so as not to be unfairly denied to be a liar"

Original: ma qui tacer nol posso
Translate: But I can't shut up here.

Original: e per le note di questa comedìa, lettor, ti giuro, s’elle non sien di lunga grazia vòte,
Translate: "and I, the reader, swear by the words of this Comedy "

Original: ch’i’ vidi per quell’ aere grosso e scuro venir notando una figura in suso, maravigliosa ad ogne cor sicuro,
Translate: "that I saw a figure approaching upwards, swimming in that dark and thick air, which marveled even the bravest heart,"

Original: sì come torna colui che va giuso talora a solver l’àncora ch’aggrappa o scoglio o altro che nel mare è chiuso,  che ’n sù si stende e da piè si rattrappa
Translate: " just like the sailor going under water to loosen the anchor that got caught or to remove another obstacle within the sea, and stretching out his arms upward and retracting his legs "

Original: "Ecco la fiera con la coda aguzza, che passa i monti e rompe i muri e l'armi
Translate: "Here is the beast with its pointed tail, passing through the mountains and breaking walls and defenses."

Original: Ecco colei che tutto 'l mondo appuzza"
Translate: Behold, she that softeneth the whole world with her stench.

Original: Sì cominciò lo mio duca a parlarmi
Translate: So my teacher started talking to me.

Original: e accennolle che venisse a proda, vicino al fin d’i passeggiati marmi
Translate: "and hinted at the monster to come to the rim of the Circle, near the end of the stone embankment."

Original: E quella sozza imagine di froda sen venne, e arrivò la testa e ’l busto, ma ’n su la riva non trasse la coda
Translate: "And that filthy image of fraud came near, protruding the head and the torso but keeping the tail away from the hem."

Original: La faccia sua era faccia d’uom giusto, tanto benigna avea di fuor la pelle, e d’un serpente tutto l’altro fusto
Translate: "He had the face of a righteous man, so reassuring was his appearance, while the rest of the body was a serpent."

Original: due branche avea pilose insin l’ascelle
Translate: He had two hairy legs that came to the armpits

Original: lo dosso e ’l petto e ambedue le coste dipinti avea di nodi e di rotelle
Translate: the back and chest and both sides were painted with knots and wheels

Original: Con più color, sommesse e sovraposte non fer mai drappi Tartari né Turchi, né fuor tai tele per Aragne imposte
Translate: "Neither the Tartars nor the Turks ever produced fabrics with more colors, embroideries of background and relief, nor did Aracne ever make such canvases"

Original: Come talvolta stanno a riva i burchi, che parte sono in acqua e parte in terra, e come là tra li Tedeschi lurchi  lo bivero s’assetta a far sua guerra,
Translate: "As the small caterpillars sometimes stand on the shore and hold part of the hull in water and part on the ground, and as there among the German beaver prepares to capture the prey, "

Original: così la fiera pessima si stava su l’orlo ch’è di pietra e ’l sabbion serra
Translate: "so the horrible beast stood on the edge, which is made of stone and surrounds the sand."

Original: Nel vano tutta sua coda guizzava, torcendo in sù la venenosa forca ch’a guisa di scorpion la punta armava
Translate: "His tail ran all into the void, turning the poisonous scissor that had a sting similar to that of the scorpion"

Original: Lo duca disse: "Or convien che si torca la nostra via un poco insino a quella bestia malvagia che colà si corca"
Translate: "The teacher said to me, "Now it is necessary for our journey to go a little to that evil beast, lying there."

Original: Però scendemmo a la destra mammella, e diece passi femmo in su lo stremo, per ben cessar la rena e la fiammella
Translate: "Therefore we went down from the bank on the right side, and took ten steps on the edge of the Circle, being careful to avoid the sand and the rain of fire."

Original: E quando noi a lei venuti semo, poco più oltre veggio in su la rena gente seder propinqua al loco scemo
Translate: "And when we came to her, I saw a little further than the damned ones sitting in the sand, near the edge of the abyss."

Original: Quivi ’l maestro "Acciò che tutta piena esperïenza d’esto giron porti", mi disse, "va, e vedi la lor mena
Translate: "Here the master said to me, "That your experience in this circle may be complete, go and observe their pain."

Original: Li tuoi ragionamenti sian là corti
Translate: Your speeches there are not long:

Original: mentre che torni, parlerò con questa, che ne conceda i suoi omeri forti"
Translate: "Waiting for your return, I will speak with this beast to convince her to give us her strong shoulders "

Original: Così ancor su per la strema testa di quel settimo cerchio tutto solo andai, dove sedea la gente mesta
Translate: "So I left all alone on the edge of that VII Circle, where the damned medals sat."

Original: Per li occhi fora scoppiava lor duolo
Translate: The pain burst out of their eyes

Original: di qua, di là soccorrien con le mani quando a’ vapori, e quando al caldo suolo:
Translate: "and on one side and on the other they tried to give themselves relief with their hands, to shelter themselves from the burning rain and the burning sand:"

Original: non altrimenti fan di state i cani or col ceffo or col piè, quando son morsi o da pulci o da mosche o da tafani
Translate: "not unlike dogs in the summer, with their snouts and paws, when they are bitten by fleas, flies or tafani."

Original: Poi che nel viso a certi li occhi porsi, ne’ quali ’l doloroso foco casca, non ne conobbi alcun
Translate: "After I looked at the face of some of them, upon whom the painful fire fell, I recognized none of them."

Original: ma io m’accorsi  che dal collo a ciascun pendea una tasca ch’avea certo colore e certo segno, e quindi par che ’l loro occhio si pasca
Translate: "But I realized that each one hung a bag from his neck, bearing a certain colour and a certain coat of arms, and it seemed that their eye drew nourishment from it."

Original: E com’io riguardando tra lor vegno, in una borsa gialla vidi azzurro che d’un leone avea faccia e contegno
Translate: "And as I looked among them, I saw on a yellow bag a blue figure that looked like a lion with appearance and posture."

Original: Poi, procedendo di mio sguardo il curro, vidine un’altra come sangue rossa, mostrando un’oca bianca più che burro
Translate: "Then, pushing beyond the course of my gaze, I saw another one of blood-red colour, bearing the shape of a goose whiter than butter "

Original: E un che d’una scrofa azzurra e grossa segnato avea lo suo sacchetto bianco, mi disse: "Che fai tu in questa fossa?  Or te ne va
Translate: "And a damned man, who had a white bag with the image of a big blue sow, said to me, "What do you do in this Hell?"

Original: e perché se’ vivo anco, sappi che ’l mio vicin Vitalïano sederà qui dal mio sinistro fianco
Translate: "and since you are still alive, know that my fellow Vitalian of the Tooth will soon sit here on my left."

Original: Con questi Fiorentin son padoano: spesse fïate mi ’ntronan li orecchi gridando: "Vegna ’l cavalier sovrano,  che recherà la tasca con tre becchi"
Translate: "I am from Padua and I am here with these Florentines: many times they scream in my ears, shouting: ""Come the noble knight, who will bring here the bag with the symbol of the three goats"" "" ""

Original: Qui distorse la bocca e di fuor trasse la lingua, come bue che ’l naso lecchi
Translate: "At that point he twisted his mouth and pulled out his tongue, like an ox licking his nose."

Original: E io, temendo no ’l più star crucciasse lui che di poco star m’avea ’mmonito, torna’ mi in dietro da l’anime lasse
Translate: "And I, fearing that keeping myself beyond angered the one who warned me to stay there for a little while, turned away from the sad souls."

Original: Trova’ il duca mio ch’era salito già su la groppa del fiero animale, e disse a me: "Or sie forte e ardito
Translate: "I found my master who was already mounted on the back of the fierce animal, and said to me, "Now be strong and courageous."

Original: Omai si scende per sì fatte scale
Translate: Now we have to go down like this:

Original: monta dinanzi, ch’i’ voglio esser mezzo, sì che la coda non possa far male"
Translate: "Go up before me, for I will be between you and the tail, that it may not harm you."

Original: Qual è colui che sì presso ha ’l riprezzo de la quartana, c’ ha già l’unghie smorte, e triema tutto pur guardando ’l rezzo,  tal divenn’io a le parole porte
Translate: "As he who is so close to the rebuke of the fourth fever that already has his nails vivid, and trembles all by looking at the shadow, so I became in hearing those words."

Original: ma vergogna mi fé le sue minacce, che innanzi a buon segnor fa servo forte
Translate: "but the shame, which makes the servant brave before the good master, made me his threats."

Original: I’ m’assettai in su quelle spallacce
Translate: I sat on those horrible shoulders

Original: sì volli dir, ma la voce non venne com’io credetti: ’Fa che tu m’abbracce’
Translate: "I wanted to say to Virgil 'Hug me strong', but the voice didn't come out as I thought it would."

Original: Ma esso, ch’altra volta mi sovvenne ad altro forse, tosto ch’i’ montai con le braccia m’avvinse e mi sostenne
Translate: "Instead, Virgil, who at other times rescued me in other doubtful situations, as soon as I mounted him he girded me with his arms and held me strong."

Original: e disse: "Gerïon, moviti omai: le rote larghe, e lo scender sia poco
Translate: "And he said, "Jerion, it is time for you to move: slowly go down, making wide turns in the air: "

Original: pensa la nova soma che tu hai"
Translate: Take care of the weight you carry and are not used to it.

Original: Come la navicella esce di loco in dietro in dietro, sì quindi si tolse
Translate: "As the ship leaves the ship going backwards, so did Gerion depart from the hem."

Original: e poi ch’al tutto si sentì a gioco,  là ’v’era ’l petto, la coda rivolse, e quella tesa, come anguilla, mosse, e con le branche l’aere a sé raccolse
Translate: "And when he was fully at ease, he turned his tail where his breast was, and moved it, like an eel, and began to give armies in the air with furry legs."

Original: Maggior paura non credo che fosse quando Fetonte abbandonò li freni, per che ’l ciel, come pare ancor, si cosse
Translate: "I don't think Fetus was more afraid when he left the reins, so - as it still appears - the sky burned"

Original: né quando Icaro misero le reni sentì spennar per la scaldata cera, gridando il padre a lui "Mala via tieni",
Translate: " neither did the miserable Icarus, when he heard his back plucked from the overheated wax, while his father shouted to him, "You're making a mistake."

Original: che fu la mia, quando vidi ch’i’ era ne l’aere d’ogne parte, e vidi spenta ogne veduta fuor che de la fera
Translate: "with respect to the fear that I had, when I saw that I was in the air on every side and saw nothing but the beast."

Original: Ella sen va notando lenta lenta
Translate: "It proceeded, swimming slowly: "

Original: rota e discende, ma non me n’accorgo se non che al viso e di sotto mi venta
Translate: "He turned and went down, but I couldn't see it except for the fact that I felt the wind on my face and under my legs."

Original: Io sentia già da la man destra il gorgo far sotto noi un orribile scroscio, per che con li occhi ’n giù la testa sporgo
Translate: "I already heard on my right hand the waterfall that made a horrible overflow underneath us, so I sprinkled his head down and looked."

Original: Allor fu’ io più timido a lo stoscio, però ch’i’ vidi fuochi e senti’ pianti
Translate: "Then I was more afraid to fall, because I saw fires and heard lamentations."

Original: ond’io tremando tutto mi raccoscio
Translate: "So, shaking, I tightened my thighs more"

Original: E vidi poi, ché nol vedea davanti, lo scendere e ’l girar per li gran mali che s’appressavan da diversi canti
Translate: "And I saw what I didn't see before, that we were going down and turning, because the great torments of the damned came from different sides."

Original: Come ’l falcon ch’è stato assai su l’ali, che sanza veder logoro o uccello fa dire al falconiere "Omè, tu cali",
Translate: "As the falcon that has flew for a long time, and that having seen neither the worn out nor a bird induces the falconer to say: "Alas, you must go down."

Original: discende lasso onde si move isnello, per cento rote, e da lunge si pone dal suo maestro, disdegnoso e fello
Translate: "and he goes down weary to the place from which he moves agile, making a hundred turns in the air and resting away from his master, disdainful and reckless."

Original: così ne puose al fondo Gerïone al piè al piè de la stagliata rocca, e, discarcate le nostre persone,  si dileguò come da corda cocca
Translate: "so Gerion laid us on the ground, right at the bottom of that overhanging abyss, and once he had discharged our bodies, he vanished like an arrow struck by an arch."

Original: Luogo è in inferno detto Malebolge, tutto di pietra di color ferrigno, come la cerchia che dintorno il volge
Translate: "In Hell there is a place called Malebolge, all made of stone of the color of iron as the rocky wall that surrounds it"

Original: Nel dritto mezzo del campo maligno vaneggia un pozzo assai largo e profondo, di cui suo loco dicerò l’ordigno
Translate: "Just in the middle of the evil plain a very wide and deep well opens in the void, of which in due time I will explain the conformation"

Original: Quel cinghio che rimane adunque è tondo tra ’l pozzo e ’l piè de l’alta ripa dura, e ha distinto in dieci valli il fondo
Translate: That strip that remains between the well and the rocky wall is therefore round and is divided into ten valleys.

Original: Quale, dove per guardia de le mura più e più fossi cingon li castelli, la parte dove son rende figura,  tale imagine quivi facean quelli
Translate: "There where many moats surround the castles to guard their walls, the image they make is quite similar to those of Bolge."

Original: e come a tai fortezze da’ lor sogli a la ripa di fuor son ponticelli,
Translate: "and as in those fortresses there are wooden bridges that join their thresholds to the shore of the ditches, "

Original: così da imo de la roccia scogli movien che ricidien li argini e ’ fossi infino al pozzo che i tronca e raccogli
Translate: "So from the base of the rock began stone bridges that crossed the banks and ditches, to the central well that breaks them and brings them together."

Original: In questo luogo, de la schiena scossi di Gerïon, trovammoci
Translate: "We found ourselves in this place, once Gerion had laid us from his back."

Original: e ’l poeta tenne a sinistra, e io dietro mi mossi
Translate: "and Virgilio moved to the left, so I followed him."

Original: A la man destra vidi nova pieta, novo tormento e novi frustatori, di che la prima bolgia era repleta
Translate: "To our right I saw a new anguish, a new punishment and new devils whiskers of which the I Bolgia was full"

Original: Nel fondo erano ignudi i peccatori
Translate: "The sinners were at the bottom of the Bolgia, naked"

Original: dal mezzo in qua ci venien verso ’l volto, di là con noi, ma con passi maggiori,
Translate: "in the part near the outer edge of the moat they walked toward us, in the inner one they proceeded in the opposite direction, but faster than we,"

Original: come i Roman per l’essercito molto, l’anno del giubileo, su per lo ponte hanno a passar la gente modo colto,
Translate: "as the Romans have found a way to get people on the bridge in the year of the Jubilee, because of the great influx, "

Original: che da l’un lato tutti hanno la fronte verso ’l castello e vanno a Santo Pietro, da l’altra sponda vanno verso ’l monte
Translate: "on the one hand they go to St. Peter, on the other side they go to Mount Jordan."

Original: Di qua, di là, su per lo sasso tetro vidi demon cornuti con gran ferze, che li battien crudelmente di retro
Translate: "On one side and on the other in that dark rock I saw devils with whips, who beat them cruelly on the bottom of their backs."

Original: Ahi come facean lor levar le berze a le prime percosse
Translate: "Ah, how did they get their heels up at the first beatings"

Original: già nessuno le seconde aspettava né le terze
Translate: no damned man was waiting to be hit a second or a third time

Original: Mentr’io andava, li occhi miei in uno furo scontrati
Translate: "As I walked, my gaze crossed with one of the damned."

Original: e io sì tosto dissi: "Già di veder costui non son digiuno"
Translate: And I said at once, "This is not the first time I have seen this man."

Original: Per ch’ïo a figurarlo i piedi affissi
Translate: Then I stopped to look at him better

Original: e ’l dolce duca meco si ristette, e assentio ch’alquanto in dietro gissi
Translate: And my gentle guide stood with me, and consented that I should return a little.

Original: E quel frustato celar si credette bassando ’l viso
Translate: "And that whip thought of hiding by lowering his face, "

Original: ma poco li valse, ch’io dissi: "O tu che l’occhio a terra gette,  se le fazion che porti non son false, Venedico se’ tu Caccianemico
Translate: "But he did little for me to say, "O you who look down on the ground, if your features are not false, you are Venedic Hunting."

Original: Ma che ti mena a sì pungenti salse?"
Translate: But what sin has led you to this bitter sorrow?

Original: Ed elli a me: "Mal volontier lo dico
Translate: And he said to me, "I'll say it wrong."

Original: ma sforzami la tua chiara favella, che mi fa sovvenir del mondo antico
Translate: "but I am moved by your clear speech, which reminds me of the earthly world"

Original: I’ fui colui che la Ghisolabella condussi a far la voglia del marchese, come che suoni la sconcia novella
Translate: "I am the one who led my sister Ghisolabella to satisfy the wishes of the Marquis, however tell this filthy news"

Original: E non pur io qui piango bolognese
Translate: And I'm not the only Bolognese crying here.

Original: anzi n’è questo loco tanto pieno, che tante lingue non son ora apprese  a dicer ’sipa’ tra Sàvena e Reno
Translate: "In fact, this Bolgia is so full of them that as many languages have not yet learned to say 'sipa' between Savena and Reno"

Original: e se di ciò vuoi fede o testimonio, rècati a mente il nostro avaro seno"
Translate: "and if you wish to bear witness of this, think of our miserable nature"

Original: Così parlando il percosse un demonio de la sua scurïada, e disse: "Via, ruffian
Translate: "While he was speaking, a devil struck him with his shield and said to him, "Go away, roar."

Original: qui non son femmine da conio"
Translate: There are no women to market here.

Original: I’ mi raggiunsi con la scorta mia
Translate: I reunited myself with my guide

Original: poscia con pochi passi divenimmo là ’v’uno scoglio de la ripa uscia
Translate: "After, in a few steps, we reached the point where a stone bridge came out of the rock"

Original: Assai leggeramente quel salimmo
Translate: We climbed on it very easily

Original: e vòlti a destra su per la sua scheggia, da quelle cerchie etterne ci partimmo
Translate: "And turning to the right We turned away from that eternal turning, going up along it."

Original: Quando noi fummo là dov’el vaneggia di sotto per dar passo a li sferzati, lo duca disse:
Translate: "When we were there where the bridge formed a void to give space to the whips, the master said: "

Original: "Attienti, e fa che feggia  lo viso in te di quest’altri mal nati, ai quali ancor non vedesti la faccia però che son con noi insieme andati"
Translate: "Be careful and make sure to look at these other damned ones, whose face you have not yet seen because they were moving in our same direction."

Original: Del vecchio ponte guardavam la traccia che venìa verso noi da l’altra banda, e che la ferza similmente scaccia
Translate: From that ancient bridge we looked at the line that came to us on the other side and was similarly pushed by the lashes

Original: E ’l buon maestro, sanza mia dimanda, mi disse: "Guarda quel grande che vene, e per dolor non par lagrime spanda:
Translate: "And the good teacher, without whom I asked for anything, said to me, "Look at the great one who is advancing and who does not seem to shed tears for the pain:"

Original: quanto aspetto reale ancor ritene
Translate: which royal aspect still preserves

Original: Quelli è Iasón, che per cuore e per senno li Colchi del monton privati féne
Translate: "That is Jason, who with courage and cunning deprived the Colks of the golden fleece."

Original: Ello passò per l’isola di Lenno poi che l’ardite femmine spietate tutti li maschi loro a morte dienno
Translate: "He passed through the island of Lemno, after the daring and ruthless women had put all their men to death."

Original: Ivi con segni e con parole ornate Isifile ingannò, la giovinetta che prima avea tutte l’altre ingannate
Translate: "Here, with elegant gestures and words, Isifile deceived, the young woman who had first deceived all the others"

Original: Lasciolla quivi, gravida, soletta
Translate: "He left her here, alone and pregnant: "

Original: tal colpa a tal martiro lui condanna
Translate: this guilt condemns him to such penalty

Original: e anche di Medea si fa vendetta
Translate: and is also punished for deception against Medea

Original: Con lui sen va chi da tal parte inganna
Translate: With him proceeds those who deceive in this way:

Original: e questo basti de la prima valle sapere e di color che ’n sé assanna"
Translate: And it sufficeth thee to know this of the Bolgiah, and of the damned, which it punisheth.

Original: Già eravam là ’ve lo stretto calle con l’argine secondo s’incrocicchia, e fa di quello ad un altr’arco spalle
Translate: "Now we have come to the point where the narrow rock bridge joins with the second embankment, from where another starts."

Original: Quindi sentimmo gente che si nicchia ne l’altra bolgia e che col muso scuffa, e sé medesma con le palme picchia
Translate: "From here we heard people complaining in the other Bolgia and blowing loudly with their noses and mouths, hitting themselves with their own hands."

Original: Le ripe eran grommate d’una muffa, per l’alito di giù che vi s’appasta, che con li occhi e col naso facea zuffa
Translate: "The walls of Bolgia were encrusted by a mold, for the miasmas that come from below and stick to it kneading, such as to cause irritation to the eyes and nose."

Original: Lo fondo è cupo sì, che non ci basta loco a veder sanza montare al dosso de l’arco, ove lo scoglio più sovrasta
Translate: "The bottom was so dark that we had no way to see it without climbing to the highest point of the arch, where the bridge above the moat"

Original: Quivi venimmo
Translate: We came here

Original: e quindi giù nel fosso vidi gente attuffata in uno sterco che da li uman privadi parea mosso
Translate: And I saw on the bottom of the damned, dipped in a dung that seemed to come out of the latrines of men.

Original: E mentre ch’io là giù con l’occhio cerco, vidi un col capo sì di merda lordo, che non parëa s’era laico o cherco
Translate: "And as I looked down with my eyes, I saw a damned man whose head was so full of excrement that one could not tell whether he was a cleric or a layman. "

Original: Quei mi sgridò: "Perché se’ tu sì gordo di riguardar più me che li altri brutti?"
Translate: He cried out to me, "Why do you wait to look at me more than the other damned?"

Original: E io a lui: "Perché, se ben ricordo,  già t’ ho veduto coi capelli asciutti, e se’ Alessio Interminei da Lucca: però t’adocchio più che li altri tutti"
Translate: "And I to him: "Because, if I remember correctly, I have already seen you with dry hair and you are Alessio Terminelli from Lucca: for this reason I stare at you more than all the others."

Original: Ed elli allor, battendosi la zucca: "Qua giù m’ hanno sommerso le lusinghe ond’io non ebbi mai la lingua stucca"
Translate: "And he struck his head, and said, 'They have covered me down here with the flattery of which my tongue was never tired.'"

Original: Appresso ciò lo duca "Fa che pinghe", mi disse, "il viso un poco più avante,
Translate: "Then my guide said to me, "Make sure to look a little further."

Original: sì che la faccia ben con l’occhio attinghe  di quella sozza e scapigliata fante che là si graffia con l’unghie merdose, e or s’accoscia e ora è in piedi stante
Translate: "so that you can see with your eye the face of that filthy, hurled woman who scratches there with her nails full of dung, and now she leans on her thighs and is now standing."

Original: Taïde è, la puttana che rispuose al drudo suo quando disse "Ho io grazie grandi apo te?": "Anzi maravigliose"
Translate: "It is Taide, the prostitute who to her lover, when she asked her ""Do I deserve great things with you?," she replied: "Before, great things."

Original: E quinci sian le nostre viste sazie"
Translate: ""And that's what our looks are satisfied with"

Original: O Simon mago, o miseri seguaci che le cose di Dio, che di bontate deon essere spose, e voi rapaci per oro e per argento avolterate,
Translate: "O Simon the Wizard, O his wretched followers who, greedy, prostitute in exchange for gold and silver the things of God that are to be married to goodness, "

Original: or convien che per voi suoni la tromba, però che ne la terza bolgia state
Translate: "Now it is necessary for you to play the trumpet, since you are in the III Bolgia"

Original: Già eravamo, a la seguente tomba, montati de lo scoglio in quella parte ch’a punto sovra mezzo ’l fosso piomba
Translate: "Now we had climbed to the bridge in the following Bolagia to the point where the perpendicular falls exactly in the middle of the pit."

Original: O somma sapïenza, quanta è l'arte che mostri in cielo, in terra e nel mal mondo, e quanto giusto tua virtù comparte
Translate: "O supreme wisdom, how much perfection do you prove in heaven, on earth, and in hell, and with how much righteousness your virtue bestows rewards and punishments"

Original: Io vidi per le coste e per lo fondo piena la pietra livida di fóri, d’un largo tutti e ciascun era tondo
Translate: "I saw the dark rock, along the walls and at the bottom of the pit, full of holes, all of the same width and circular shape."

Original: Non mi parean men ampi né maggiori che que’ che son nel mio bel San Giovanni, fatti per loco d’i battezzatori
Translate: They did not seem to me to be less extensive nor greater than those who serve as baptismal sources in the beautiful Florentine baptistery of St. John.

Original: l’un de li quali, ancor non è molt’anni, rupp’io per un che dentro v’annegava: e questo sia suggel ch’ogn’omo sganni
Translate: "Not many years ago I broke one to save a person who was drowning you, and this is the testimony that corrects the error of the ill-informed."

Original: Fuor de la bocca a ciascun soperchiava d’un peccator li piedi e de le gambe infino al grosso, e l’altro dentro stava
Translate: "Out of the edge of every hole stood the feet and legs of a sinner, to the thighs, while the rest of the body was in."

Original: Le piante erano a tutti accese intrambe
Translate: "The soles of the feet were both on, "

Original: per che sì forte guizzavan le giunte, che spezzate averien ritorte e strambe
Translate: so that the damned kicked with the joints with such force that they would break the strongest ropes

Original: Qual suole il fiammeggiar de le cose unte muoversi pur su per la strema buccia, tal era lì dai calcagni a le punte
Translate: "As a flame usually languishes only the surface of the anointed things, moving on the extremity, so did those flames from the heel to the tip of the feet."

Original: "Chi è colui, maestro, che si cruccia guizzando più che li altri suoi consorti", diss’io, "e cui più roggia fiamma succia?"
Translate: "I said, "Teacher, who is the damned one who suffers and kicks more than his fellow painmen, and who is consumed by a reddier flame?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Se tu vuo’ ch’i’ ti porti là giù per quella ripa che più giace, da lui saprai di sé e de’ suoi torti"
Translate: "And he to me: "If you want me to take you there, going down along the less steep wall, you will know from him who he is and what fault he has committed."

Original: E io: "Tanto m'è bel, quanto a te piace: tu se' segnore, e sai ch'i' non mi parto dal tuo volere, e sai quel che si tace"
Translate: And I said, "What you like for me is fine: you are my guide, and you know that my will is according to yours, and you know also what I do not say."

Original: Allor venimmo in su l’argine quarto
Translate: Then we came to the fourth bank:

Original: volgemmo e discendemmo a mano stanca là giù nel fondo foracchiato e arto
Translate: "We turned and went down to the left, to the bottom of the Bolgia, full of holes and narrow."

Original: Lo buon maestro ancor de la sua anca non mi dipuose, sì mi giunse al rotto di quel che si piangeva con la zanca
Translate: "The good teacher didn't let me down from his side until he took me to the hole where the damned man complained with his legs."

Original: "O qual che se’ che ’l di sù tien di sotto, anima trista come pal commessa", comincia’ io a dir, "se puoi, fa motto"
Translate: "I began to say, "Whoever you are, you who are upside down, sad soul like a stake stuck in the ground, if you can, talk to me."

Original: Io stava come ’l frate che confessa lo perfido assessin, che, poi ch’è fitto, richiama lui per che la morte cessa
Translate: "I was there like the friar who confessed to the perfidious killer, who, after being put in the hole, called him to delay execution"

Original: Ed el gridò: "Se' tu già costì ritto, se' tu già costì ritto, Bonifazio? Di parecchi anni mi mentì lo scritto
Translate: "And he shouted, "Are you standing there already, are you standing there already, Bonifacio? The book of the future has lied to me for several years."

Original: Se’ tu sì tosto di quell’aver sazio per lo qual non temesti tòrre a ’nganno la bella donna, e poi di farne strazio?"
Translate: Have you already filled yourself with those riches for which you had no scruples to deceive the beautiful woman and then make her a mess?

Original: Tal mi fec’io, quai son color che stanno, per non intender ciò ch’è lor risposto, quasi scornati, e risponder non sanno
Translate: "I became then like those who do not understand what has been answered to them, so they are confused and do not know what to say"

Original: Allor Virgilio disse: "Dilli tosto: "Non son colui, non son colui che credi""
Translate: Then said Virgil, Tell him now, I am not he whom thou believest.

Original: e io rispuosi come a me fu imposto
Translate: And I answered as I was commanded.

Original: Per che lo spirto tutti storse i piedi
Translate: Then the spirit twisted its feet completely

Original: poi, sospirando e con voce di pianto, mi disse: "Dunque che a me richiedi?
Translate: "Then, sighing and with a whining voice, he said to me, "So what do you want to know from me?"

Original: Se di saper ch’i’ sia ti cal cotanto, che tu abbi però la ripa corsa, sappi ch’i’ fui vestito del gran manto
Translate: "If you want to know who I am to the point of getting down here, know that I dressed the papal cloak."

Original: e veramente fui figliuol de l’orsa, cupido sì per avanzar li orsatti, che sù l’avere e qui me misi in borsa
Translate: "and I was the rightful son of the bear, so greedy to benefit my relatives that in life I put money in the purse, here I put myself in the purse."

Original: Di sotto al capo mio son li altri tratti che precedetter me simoneggiando, per le fessure de la pietra piatti
Translate: "Under my head are stuck the others who preceded me practicing simony, all flattened in the cracks of the rock"

Original: Là giù cascherò io altresì quando verrà colui ch’i’ credea che tu fossi, allor ch’i’ feci ’l sùbito dimando
Translate: "I'll end up there when the one I thought you were coming when I asked you that sudden question."

Original: Ma più è ’l tempo già che i piè mi cossi e ch’i’ son stato così sottosopra, ch’el non starà piantato coi piè rossi:
Translate: But the time I spent cooking my feet and in which I was so turned upside down is greater than what he will pass with red feet:

Original: ché dopo lui verrà di più laida opra, di ver’ ponente, un pastor sanza legge, tal che convien che lui e me ricuopra
Translate: "For after him another pope will come from the west without law, who will do even more infamous and so that he will cover me and him."

Original: Nuovo Iasón sarà, di cui si legge ne’ Maccabei
Translate: "It will be a new Jason, of which we read in the book of Maccabees."

Original: e come a quel fu molle suo re, così fia lui chi Francia regge"
Translate: "And as his king was condescending with him, so shall the king of France be toward the pope."

Original: Io non so s’i’ mi fui qui troppo folle, ch’i’ pur rispuosi lui a questo metro:
Translate: "I don't know if at this point I was too irreverent, for I answered him in this tone: "

Original: "Deh, or mi dì: quanto tesoro volle  Nostro Segnore in prima da san Pietro ch’ei ponesse le chiavi in sua balìa?
Translate: Now tell me, how much money did our Lord want from St Peter before he entrusted him with the keys to the kingdom of heaven?

Original: Certo non chiese se non "Viemmi retro"
Translate: Sure, he just said, "Follow me."

Original: Né Pier né li altri tolsero a Matia oro od argento, quando fu sortito al loco che perdé l’anima ria
Translate: "Neither Peter nor the others took gold or silver from Matthias, when he was drawn to take the lost place of Judah."

Original: Però ti sta, ché tu se’ ben punito
Translate: "So stay here, because you're well punished."

Original: e guarda ben la mal tolta moneta ch’esser ti fece contra Carlo ardito
Translate: "and keep the money taken with deceit, which made you bold against Charles of Anjou."

Original: E se non fosse ch’ancor lo mi vieta la reverenza de le somme chiavi che tu tenesti ne la vita lieta,  io userei parole ancor più gravi
Translate: "And if it were not for the respect that I owe to the key sums that you held in earthly life and that hold me back, I would use even stricter words: "

Original: ché la vostra avarizia il mondo attrista, calcando i buoni e sollevando i pravi
Translate: "For your avarice grieves the world, trampling upon the good, and lifting up the wicked."

Original: Di voi pastor s’accorse il Vangelista, quando colei che siede sopra l’acque puttaneggiar coi regi a lui fu vista
Translate: And the Evangelist saw of you bad shepherds when he saw the harlot sitting upon the waters, being a harlot with kings.

Original: quella che con le sette teste nacque, e da le diece corna ebbe argomento, fin che virtute al suo marito piacque
Translate: "the one who was born with seven heads and took strength from the ten horns, until the husband liked virtue."

Original: Fatto v’avete dio d’oro e d’argento
Translate: You have made yourselves a god of gold and silver:

Original: e che altro è da voi a l’idolatre, se non ch’elli uno, e voi ne orate cento?
Translate: "and what difference is there between you and the pagan, except that he worships one god and you worship a hundred?"

Original: Ahi, Costantin, di quanto mal fu matre, non la tua conversion, ma quella dote che da te prese il primo ricco patre"
Translate: "Alas, Constantine, how evil it has caused, not your conversion, but the gift that the first rich pope had from you."

Original: E mentr’io li cantava cotai note, o ira o coscïenza che ’l mordesse, forte spingava con ambo le piote
Translate: "And as I spoke these words to him, the damned one kicked hard with both legs, or because he was angry or out of remorse of conscience."

Original: I’ credo ben ch’al mio duca piacesse, con sì contenta labbia sempre attese lo suon de le parole vere espresse
Translate: "I believe that my teacher approved, since he listened to my truthful speech with a serene face"

Original: Però con ambo le braccia mi prese
Translate: Then he took me with both arms

Original: e poi che tutto su mi s’ebbe al petto, rimontò per la via onde discese
Translate: "and then he shook everything in my chest, and went up the way from which he had come."

Original: Né si stancò d’avermi a sé distretto, sì men portò sovra ’l colmo de l’arco che dal quarto al quinto argine è tragetto
Translate: "He did not tire of holding on to me until he took me to the highest point of the bridge, which joins the fourth to the fifth bank."

Original: Quivi soavemente spuose il carco, soave per lo scoglio sconcio ed erto che sarebbe a le capre duro varco
Translate: "Here he gently laid the load on the ground, which was sweet to carry through the steep and steep rock and which would be a hard path even for the goats"

Original: Indi un altro vallon mi fu scoperto
Translate: From there another Bolgia was shown to me

Original: Di nova pena mi conven far versi e dar matera al ventesimo canto de la prima canzon, ch’è d’i sommersi
Translate: "I am obliged to compose verses on a new sentence and thus give matter to the twentieth Song of the First Song, which is dedicated to the damned"

Original: Io era già disposto tutto quanto a riguardar ne lo scoperto fondo, che si bagnava d’angoscioso pianto
Translate: "I was already totally ready to look into the bottom of the Bolgia, which was wet with anguish crying."

Original: e vidi gente per lo vallon tondo venir, tacendo e lagrimando, al passo che fanno le letane in questo mondo
Translate: "And I saw the damned going into the round ditch, silent and weeping, with a slow pace like that of the processions."

Original: Come ’l viso mi scese in lor più basso, mirabilmente apparve esser travolto ciascun tra ’l mento e ’l principio del casso,
Translate: "As soon as I looked down on them, it seemed to me that everyone had the neck incredibly overwhelmed between the chin and the beginning of the chest."

Original: ché da le reni era tornato ’l volto, e in dietro venir li convenia, perché ’l veder dinanzi era lor tolto
Translate: "in fact the face was turned from the back and they were forced to go backwards, because they couldn't look forward"

Original: Forse per forza già di parlasia si travolse così alcun del tutto
Translate: "Maybe someone was disfigured in this way by a paralysis, "

Original: ma io nol vidi, né credo che sia
Translate: But I've never seen it, and I don't think it ever happened.

Original: Se Dio ti lasci, lettor, prender frutto di tua lezione,
Translate: "May God, O reader, let you take the fruit of this lesson: "

Original: or pensa per te stesso com'io potea tener lo viso asciutto,
Translate: "think of yourself how I could avoid crying, "

Original: quando la nostra imagine di presso vidi sì torta, che ’l pianto de li occhi le natiche bagnava per lo fesso
Translate: "when I saw closely the human figure so upset, while the damned wept with tears the buttocks along the crack"

Original: Certo io piangea, poggiato a un de’ rocchi del duro scoglio, sì che la mia scorta mi disse:
Translate: "Of course I was weeping, leaning on one of the bosses of the rock, until my guide said to me: "

Original: "Ancor se' tu de li altri sciocchi?  Qui vive la pietà quand’è ben morta
Translate: Are you also part of the other snaps?Here piety is worth only when it is completely dead.

Original: chi è più scellerato che colui che al giudicio divin passion comporta?
Translate: "Who is more wicked than the one who seeks to force divine judgment, foretelling the future?"

Original: Drizza la testa, drizza, e vedi a cui s’aperse a li occhi d’i Teban la terra
Translate: " Lift up your head, lift it up, and look at him under whom the earth opened before the eyes of the Thebans, "

Original: per ch’ei gridavan tutti: "Dove rui,  Anfïarao? perché lasci la guerra?"
Translate: "to whom all shouted, "Where are you going, Amphiaraus? Why are you leaving the war?" "

Original: E non restò di ruinare a valle fino a Minòs che ciascheduno afferra
Translate: And he did not cease to rush until he came to Minos, who grabbed every damned soul.

Original: Mira c' ha fatto petto de le spalle
Translate: Look how now his shoulders have become his chest:

Original: perché volse veder troppo davante, di retro guarda e fa retroso calle
Translate: "you want to see too far ahead, so now look back and walk backwards"

Original: Vedi Tiresia, che mutò sembiante quando di maschio femmina divenne, cangiandosi le membra tutte quante
Translate: "See Tyresiah, who turned from male to female changing all the members"

Original: e prima, poi, ribatter li convenne li duo serpenti avvolti, con la verga, che rïavesse le maschili penne
Translate: and to get back the male attributes he had to fight with the same rod the two snakes wrapped

Original: Aronta è quel ch’al ventre li s’atterga, che ne’ monti di Luni, dove ronca lo Carrarese che di sotto alberga, ebbe tra ’ bianchi marmi la spelonca per sua dimora
Translate: "What has its back close to its belly is Arunte, who had a cave as its home among the white rocks in the mountains of Luni, where the Carraresi who live in the plain below are cleared."

Original: onde a guardar le stelle e ’l mar non li era la veduta tronca
Translate: and from there he could see widely the stars and the sea

Original: E quella che ricuopre le mammelle, che tu non vedi, con le trecce sciolte, e ha di là ogne pilosa pelle,  Manto fu, che cercò per terre molte
Translate: "And the one that covers with the braids loose the breasts, which you do not see, and has every hairy part on the other side, is Manto, who wandered for many lands."

Original: poscia si puose là dove nacqu’ io
Translate: Then he settled where I was born.

Original: onde un poco mi piace che m’ascolte
Translate: And now I want you to listen to me for a few moments.

Original: Poscia che ’l padre suo di vita uscìo e venne serva la città di Baco, questa gran tempo per lo mondo gio
Translate: "After her father died and her city became sacred to Bacchus, she wandered a long time to the world"

Original: Suso in Italia bella giace un laco, a piè de l’Alpe che serra Lamagna sovra Tiralli, c’ ha nome Benaco
Translate: "In northern Italy stands a lake at the foot of the Alps that divide from Germany near Tyrol, called Benaco"

Original: Per mille fonti, credo, e più si bagna tra Garda e Val Camonica e Pennino de l’acqua che nel detto laco stagna
Translate: "The territory between Garda, Valcamonica and the Pennine Alps is bathed by a thousand and more sources, I believe, than that water that stagnates in this lake"

Original: Loco è nel mezzo là dove ’l trentino pastore e quel di Brescia e ’l veronese segnar poria, s’e’ fesse quel cammino
Translate: "In the center of it there is a place where they could bless the bishop of Trento, Brescia and Verona, if they made that path"

Original: Siede Peschiera, bello e forte arnese da fronteggiar Bresciani e Bergamaschi, ove la riva ’ntorno più discese
Translate: "Where the shore is lower rises Peschiera, beautiful and solid fortress with which to face the Bresciani and Bergamaschi"

Original: Ivi convien che tutto quanto caschi ciò che ’n grembo a Benaco star non può, e fassi fiume giù per verdi paschi
Translate: "Here it is inevitable that all the water that cannot be in the basin of the lake, which becomes river along green pastures"

Original: Tosto che l’acqua a correr mette co, non più Benaco, ma Mencio si chiama fino a Governol, dove cade in Po
Translate: "As soon as the water begins to flow, it takes the name of Mincio and preserves it up to Govèrnolo, where it is thrown into the Po"

Original: Non molto ha corso, ch’el trova una lama, ne la qual si distende e la ’mpaluda
Translate: "In his high course he finds a ridge, in which he forms a swamp"

Original: e suol di state talor esser grama
Translate: in summer sometimes is dry

Original: Quindi passando la vergine cruda vide terra, nel mezzo del pantano, sanza coltura e d’abitanti nuda
Translate: "The cruel virgin, passing through here, saw a land in the midst of the marshes, uncultivated and uninhabited."

Original: Lì, per fuggire ogne consorzio umano, ristette con suoi servi a far sue arti,
Translate: He settled there to escape all human contact and to dedicate himself to his magical arts with his servants.

Original: e visse, e vi lasciò suo corpo vano
Translate: lived there and was buried there after his death

Original: Li uomini poi che ’ntorno erano sparti s’accolsero a quel loco, ch’era forte per lo pantan ch’avea da tutte parti
Translate: "Afterwards, the men who lived all around gathered together in that place, which was well defended by the swamp that surrounded it."

Original: Fer la città sovra quell’ossa morte
Translate: And they built a city above his tomb.

Original: e per colei che ’l loco prima elesse, Mantüa l’appellar sanz’altra sorte
Translate: "They called it Mantua by the name of the one who first chose the place, without resorting to other spells."

Original: Già fuor le genti sue dentro più spesse, prima che la mattia da Casalodi da Pinamonte inganno ricevesse
Translate: "Once upon a time the city was more populated, before the madness of the Count of Casalodi was deceived by Pinamonte"

Original: Però t’assenno che, se tu mai odi originar la mia terra altrimenti, la verità nulla menzogna frodi"
Translate: "Therefore I warn thee, if thou shouldst hear any other saying concerning the origin of my land, that no lie may pervert the truth."

Original: E io: "Maestro, i tuoi ragionamenti mi son sì certi e prendon sì mia fede, che li altri mi sarien carboni spenti
Translate: "And I: "Teacher, your reasonings are so sure and they win my confidence to the point that the others would be for me extinguished coals"

Original: Ma dimmi, de la gente che procede, se tu ne vedi alcun degno di nota
Translate: But tell me if you see anyone else worthy of note among the bloody marchers

Original: ché solo a ciò la mia mente rifiede"
Translate: For my mind is only directed to this

Original: Allor mi disse: "Quel che da la gota porge la barba in su le spalle brune, fu - quando Grecia fu di maschi vòta,  sì ch’a pena rimaser per le cune -
Translate: "Then he said to me, "What makes the beard come down from the cheeks on the dark shoulders, when Greece was depopulated with males to the point that they barely remained in the cradles."

Original: augure, e diede ’l punto con Calcanta in Aulide a tagliar la prima fune
Translate: it was a wish and it indicated with Calcante the propitious moment in Aulide to set sail the Greek fleet

Original: Euripilo ebbe nome, e così ’l canta l’alta mia tragedìa in alcun loco: ben lo sai tu che la sai tutta quanta
Translate: "It was called Euripilo, and so my high poem mentions it somewhere: you know it well, since you have read it all."

Original: Quell’altro che ne’ fianchi è così poco, Michele Scotto fu, che veramente de le magiche frode seppe ’l gioco
Translate: "What else is so thin in the hips was Michele Scotto, who fully knew the game of magic fraud"

Original: Vedi Guido Bonatti
Translate: See Guido Bonatti

Original: vedi Asdente, ch’avere inteso al cuoio e a lo spago ora vorrebbe, ma tardi si pente
Translate: "See Asdent, who now would like to have dedicated himself to leather and string but repents too late"

Original: Vedi le triste che lasciaron l’ago, la spuola e ’l fuso, e fecersi ’ndivine
Translate: "You see the sad women who left the needle, the spola and the spindle, to become guesses."

Original: fecer malie con erbe e con imago
Translate: made spells with magical herbs and images

Original: Ma vienne omai, ché già tiene ’l confine d’amendue li emisperi e tocca l’onda sotto Sobilia Caino e le spine
Translate: "But now come away, for the moon touches the border of both hemispheres and is about to set beneath the sea of Seville."

Original: e già iernotte fu la luna tonda: ben ten de’ ricordar, ché non ti nocque alcuna volta per la selva fonda"
Translate: "and already last night there was full moon: you should remember it, for it helped you sometimes in the dark forest"

Original: Sì mi parlava, e andavamo introcque
Translate: "So he spoke to me, and in the meantime we didn't stop walking."

Original: Così di ponte in ponte, altro parlando che la mia comedìa cantar non cura, venimmo
Translate: "So, speaking of other things that my Comedy doesn't care to report, we came to the other bridge"

Original: e tenavamo ’l colmo, quando restammo per veder l’altra fessura di Malebolge e li altri pianti vani
Translate: "and we were on the highest point, when we stopped to see the other Bolgia and the other useless cries of the damned."

Original: e vidila mirabilmente oscura
Translate: and I saw it incredibly dark

Original: Quale ne l’arzanà de’ Viniziani bolle l’inverno la tenace pece a rimpalmare i legni lor non sani, ché navicar non ponno
Translate: "As in the Arsenale of the Venetians in winter boils the pitch viscous to repair their damaged ships, because they cannot navigate"

Original: - in quella vece chi fa suo legno novo e chi ristoppa le coste a quel che più vïaggi fece
Translate: Meanwhile some build a new hull and others repair the flanks to the ships that made many voyages at sea;

Original: chi ribatte da proda e chi da poppa
Translate: some beat the nails from the bow or stern;

Original: altri fa remi e altri volge sarte
Translate: others repair the oars and wrap the tailors;

Original: chi terzeruolo e artimon rintoppa -:
Translate: Other patch the terfurol and the artimon

Original: tal, non per foco ma per divin’arte, bollia là giuso una pegola spessa, che ’nviscava la ripa d’ogne parte
Translate: "so there boiled a thick pitch, not for a fire but for divine art, which invaded every side of the walls of Bolgia"

Original: I’ vedea lei, ma non vedëa in essa mai che le bolle che ’l bollor levava, e gonfiar tutta, e riseder compressa
Translate: "I saw the pitch, but within it I saw nothing but the bubbles that appeared on the surface, and I saw it swelling up and then falling down."

Original: Mentr’io là giù fisamente mirava, lo duca mio, dicendo "Guarda, guarda", mi trasse a sé del loco dov’io stava
Translate: "While I looked down carefully, my teacher pulled me to himself from where I was, saying, "Look, look."

Original: Allor mi volsi come l’uom cui tarda di veder quel che li convien fuggire e cui paura sùbita sgagliarda,
Translate: "So I turned, as he who lingers to see what must escape and whose fear immediately takes away garland, "

Original: che, per veder, non indugia ’l partire: e vidi dietro a noi un diavol nero correndo su per lo scoglio venire
Translate: And as he watched, he did not hesitate to flee: and I saw behind us a black devil running up the bridge.

Original: Ahi quant’elli era ne l’aspetto fero
Translate: "Ah, how fierce he looked to me."

Original: e quanto mi parea ne l’atto acerbo, con l’ali aperte e sovra i piè leggero
Translate: "and how cruel he seemed in his actions, as he ran agilely with his feet and wings wide open"

Original: L’omero suo, ch’era aguto e superbo, carcava un peccator con ambo l’anche, e quei tenea de’ piè ghermito ’l nerbo
Translate: "His shoulder, sharp and raised up, charged a sinner who lay facing with both sides, of whom the devil held his ankles tightly."

Original: Del nostro ponte disse: "O Malebranche, ecco un de li anzïan di Santa Zita
Translate: "The devil from the bridge where we were said: "O Malebranche, here is one of the elders of Saint Zita "

Original: Mettetel sotto, ch'i' torno per anche  a quella terra, che n’è ben fornita: ogn’uom v’è barattier, fuor che Bonturo
Translate: " Throw it in the pitch, while I return again to that city that is full of barter: they are all except Bonturo Dati"

Original: del no, per li denar, vi si fa ita"
Translate: "there, for money, every 'no' becomes 'yes'"

Original: Là giù ’l buttò, e per lo scoglio duro si volse
Translate: He threw him into the pitch and turned on the rock of the bridge

Original: e mai non fu mastino sciolto con tanta fretta a seguitar lo furo
Translate: and no loose hound was so quick to chase after the thief

Original: Quel s’attuffò, e tornò sù convolto
Translate: The damned fell down and came back to the surface all smeared
