Original: ma i demon che del ponte avean coperchio, gridar: "Qui non ha loco il Santo Volto
Translate: But the devils who were hidden behind the bridge cried out, "There is no Holy Face here."

Original: qui si nuota altrimenti che nel Serchio
Translate: Here you swim differently than in the river Serchio

Original: Però, se tu non vuo’ di nostri graffi, non far sopra la pegola soverchio"
Translate: "So, if you want to prevent us from tearing you apart, don't emerge above the pitch"

Original: Poi l’addentar con più di cento raffi, disser: "Coverto convien che qui balli, sì che, se puoi, nascosamente accaffi"
Translate: "Then they grabbed him with more than a hundred hooks and said, "Here you have to dance covered with pitch, so, if you can, sneak up on it."

Original: Non altrimenti i cuoci a’ lor vassalli fanno attuffare in mezzo la caldaia la carne con li uncin, perché non galli
Translate: "Not unlike them, the cooks cause their maids to immerse the meat with the hooks in the middle of the pot, so that it does not come to the surface."

Original: Lo buon maestro "Acciò che non si paia che tu ci sia", mi disse, "giù t’acquatta dopo uno scheggio, ch’alcun schermo t’aia
Translate: "The good teacher said to me, "So that you do not seem to be there, hide behind a rocky ledge, that you may be sheltered."

Original: e per nulla offension che mi sia fatta, non temer tu, ch’i’ ho le cose conte, perch’altra volta fui a tal baratta"
Translate: "and don't worry, whatever offense I've been facing, because I know what I have to do as I once again took part in such a dispute"

Original: Poscia passò di là dal co del ponte
Translate: Then he came to the other end of the bridge

Original: e com’el giunse in su la ripa sesta, mestier li fu d’aver sicura fronte
Translate: "and as soon as he arrived on the bank of the next Bolgia, he served to show him a safe air."

Original: Con quel furore e con quella tempesta ch’escono i cani a dosso al poverello che di sùbito chiede ove s’arresta,
Translate: "With the same rage and noise with which dogs go out against the beggar who stops and asks for charity from that point, "

Original: usciron quei di sotto al ponticello, e volser contra lui tutt’i runcigli
Translate: The devils came out from under the bridge and turned all the hooked sticks against Virgil.

Original: ma el gridò: "Nessun di voi sia fello
Translate: And he cried out, saying, Let none of you do me wrong.

Original: Innanzi che l’uncin vostro mi pigli, traggasi avante l’un di voi che m’oda, e poi d’arruncigliarmi si consigli"
Translate: "Before your hooks hit me, come forward with one of you who listens to me, and then decide whether or not to hook me."

Original: Tutti gridaron: "Vada Malacoda"
Translate: Everyone shouted, "Vada Malacoda"

Original: per ch’un si mosse - e li altri stetter fermi - e venne a lui dicendo: "Che li approda?"
Translate: "Then a devil went up, while the others stood still, and came to Virgil, saying to him, "That he may profit him," My teacher said: "

Original: "Credi tu, Malacoda, qui vedermi esser venuto", disse ’l mio maestro, "sicuro già da tutti vostri schermi,  sanza voler divino e fato destro?
Translate: " Do you believe, Malacoda, to see me here, safe from all your threats, without divine will and a favorable destiny to me? "

Original: Lascian’andar, ché nel cielo è voluto ch’i’ mostri altrui questo cammin silvestro"
Translate: " Let us go, for heaven wants me to show someone else this arduous path"

Original: Allor li fu l’orgoglio sì caduto, ch’e’ si lasciò cascar l’uncino a’ piedi, e disse a li altri: "Omai non sia feruto"
Translate: "Then the devil fell his pride, so that he let the hook fall to his feet and said to the others, "Do him no harm."

Original: E ’l duca mio a me: "O tu che siedi tra li scheggion del ponte quatto quatto, sicuramente omai a me ti riedi"
Translate: "And my teacher said unto me, Thou that hidest four in the rocks of the bridge, canst return unto me without danger."

Original: Per ch’io mi mossi e a lui venni ratto
Translate: Then I moved and reached him quickly.

Original: e i diavoli si fecer tutti avanti, sì ch’io temetti ch’ei tenesser patto
Translate: "and the devils all came forward, so that I feared that they would not respect the covenants"

Original: così vid’ïo già temer li fanti ch’uscivan patteggiati di Caprona, veggendo sé tra nemici cotanti
Translate: "In the same way I saw fear of the footmen who came out of the castle of Caprona according to the terms of surrender, seeing themselves among many enemies"

Original: I’ m’accostai con tutta la persona lungo ’l mio duca, e non torceva li occhi da la sembianza lor ch’era non buona
Translate: "I squeezed everything into my guide, and I didn't take my eyes off the uncomfortable look of the devils."

Original: Ei chinavan li raffi e "Vuo’ che ’l tocchi", diceva l’un con l’altro, "in sul groppone?"
Translate: They bowed their hooks, and they said to one another, "Do you want me to hit him on the crotch?"

Original: E rispondien: "Sì, fa che gliel’accocchi"
Translate: "And they said, "Yes, make sure he gets a shot."

Original: Ma quel demonio che tenea sermone col duca mio, si volse tutto presto e disse: "Posa, posa, Scarmiglione"
Translate: "But the devil who spoke to my teacher turned quickly and said, "Stay still, Scarmiglione."

Original: Poi disse a noi: "Più oltre andar per questo iscoglio non si può, però che giace tutto spezzato al fondo l’arco sesto
Translate: "Then he said to us, "You can't go any further on this bridge, since it lies collapsed at the bottom of the sixth Bolgia."

Original: E se l’andare avante pur vi piace, andatevene su per questa grotta
Translate: "And if you want to go on anyway, go along this embankment"

Original: presso è un altro scoglio che via face
Translate: Not far away there is another bridge that allows the passage

Original: Ier, più oltre cinqu’ ore che quest’otta, mille dugento con sessanta sei anni compié che qui la via fu rotta
Translate: "Yesterday, five hours later than the present hour, 1266 years have passed since the bridge collapsed."

Original: Io mando verso là di questi miei a riguardar s’alcun se ne sciorina
Translate: I'll send my devils in that direction to check that no damn thing gets out of the pitch.

Original: gite con lor, che non saranno rei"
Translate: "Go with them, they will behave well"

Original: "Tra’ ti avante, Alichino, e Calcabrina", cominciò elli a dire, "e tu, Cagnazzo
Translate: "He began to say, "Go forward, Alichino and Calcabrina, and you, Slut."

Original: e Barbariccia guidi la decina
Translate: and Barbariccia is the leader of the ten devils

Original: Libicocco vegn’oltre e Draghignazzo, Cirïatto sannuto e Graffiacane e Farfarello e Rubicante pazzo
Translate: "They also come Libyan and Draghignazzo, Cyriatto with long tusks and Graffiacane, Farfarello and Rubicante mad"

Original: Cercate ’ntorno le boglienti pane
Translate: Search around the boiling pitch viscous

Original: costor sian salvi infino a l’altro scheggio che tutto intero va sovra le tane"
Translate: "These two are safe and sound to the other bridge that, intact, gives access to the next Bolgia"

Original: "Omè, maestro, che è quel ch’i’ veggio?", diss’io, "deh, sanza scorta andianci soli, se tu sa’ ir
Translate: "So I said, 'Alas, Master, what do I ever see? Please, let's go down there without a guide, if you know the way."

Original: ch’i’ per me non la cheggio
Translate: I don't ask for it.

Original: Se tu se’ sì accorto come suoli, non vedi tu ch’e’ digrignan li denti e con le ciglia ne minaccian duoli?"
Translate: "If you are as wise as usual, don't you see that the devils grind their teeth and throw at us menacing glances?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Non vo’ che tu paventi
Translate: He said to me, "I don't want you to be afraid."

Original: lasciali digrignar pur a lor senno, ch’e’ fanno ciò per li lessi dolenti"
Translate: "Let them grind their teeth as they please, for they do so for the damned immersed in pitch."

Original: Per l’argine sinistro volta dienno
Translate: The devils turned to the left on the bank

Original: ma prima avea ciascun la lingua stretta coi denti, verso lor duca, per cenno
Translate: "but before that each one of them had held his tongue between his teeth, turning to their guidance as a sign agreed"

Original: ed elli avea del cul fatto trombetta
Translate: and he had uttered a filthy noise with his butt

Original: Io vidi già cavalier muover campo, e cominciare stormo e far lor mostra, e talvolta partir per loro scampo
Translate: "I have seen on other occasions of the knights march, attack battle and parade, sometimes beating in retreat"

Original: corridor vidi per la terra vostra, o Aretini, e vidi gir gualdane, fedir torneamenti e correr giostra
Translate: "I've seen soldiers horseback riding in your land, or Aretini, and I've seen them make raids, participate in team and individual tournaments."

Original: quando con trombe, e quando con campane, con tamburi e con cenni di castella, e con cose nostrali e con istrane
Translate: "I have seen them obeying trumpet rings, bells, drums and signals from castles, with domestic and foreign instruments."

Original: né già con sì diversa cennamella cavalier vidi muover né pedoni, né nave a segno di terra o di stella
Translate: "but I have never seen riders or infantry move at the sound of such a bizarre wind instrument, nor have I seen a ship move for a similar signal coming from earth or from heaven."

Original: Noi andavam con li diece demoni
Translate: We walked with the ten devils:

Original: Ahi fiera compagnia
Translate: "Firious company, alas, "

Original: ma ne la chiesa coi santi, e in taverna coi ghiottoni
Translate: But in the church you have to stay with the saints and the tavern with the drunkards

Original: Pur a la pegola era la mia ’ntesa, per veder de la bolgia ogne contegno e de la gente ch’entro v’era incesa
Translate: "I had eyes only at pitch, to see everything contained in the Bolgia and the people who had burned inside"

Original: Come i dalfini, quando fanno segno a’ marinar con l’arco de la schiena che s’argomentin di campar lor legno,
Translate: "Like dolphins, when they emerge with their backs and indicate to the sailors that they must save their ship, "

Original: talor così, ad alleggiar la pena, mostrav’alcun de’ peccatori ’l dosso e nascondea in men che non balena
Translate: "so sometimes, to ease their pain, some sinners showed their backs outside of the pitch, and hid themselves in no time."

Original: E come a l’orlo de l’acqua d’un fosso stanno i ranocchi pur col muso fuori, sì che celano i piedi e l’altro grosso,
Translate: "And as frogs stand by the belly of water in a ditch, with their snouts out and hiding their legs and the rest of their bodies,

Original: sì stavan d’ogne parte i peccatori
Translate: So were the sinners on every side.

Original: ma come s’appressava Barbariccia, così si ritraén sotto i bollori
Translate: "but as soon as Barbariccia approached, they would come back under boiling pitch"

Original: I’ vidi, e anco il cor me n’accapriccia, uno aspettar così, com’elli ’ncontra ch’una rana rimane e l’altra spiccia
Translate: "I saw, and still I feel horror in my heart, a damned one who hesitated, just as when a frog remains out of water and another dives"

Original: e Graffiacan, che li era più di contra, li arruncigliò le ’mpegolate chiome e trassel sù, che mi parve una lontra
Translate: "and Graffiacane, who was right in front of him, grabbed his hair with a hook smeared with pitch and pulled it up as if it were an otter."

Original: I’ sapea già di tutti quanti ’l nome, sì li notai quando fuorono eletti, e poi ch’e’ si chiamaro, attesi come
Translate: "I knew the name of all the demons, because I noticed them when they were chosen and paid attention when they were called one another."

Original: "O Rubicante, fa che tu li metti li unghioni a dosso, sì che tu lo scuoi", gridavan tutti insieme i maladetti
Translate: "The cursed cried with one voice, "Rubicante, put your claws on him and skin him."

Original: E io: "Maestro mio, fa, se tu puoi, che tu sappi chi è lo sciagurato venuto a man de li avversari suoi"
Translate: "And I: "My teacher, if you can, make sure that I know who is the wretched one who has fallen into the hands of his adversaries."

Original: Lo duca mio li s’accostò allato
Translate: My teacher approached him on the side

Original: domandollo ond’ei fosse, e quei rispuose: "I’ fui del regno di Navarra nato
Translate: And he asked him who he was, and he said, I was born in the kingdom of Navarre.

Original: Mia madre a servo d’un segnor mi puose, che m’avea generato d’un ribaldo, distruggitor di sé e di sue cose
Translate: "My mother put me at the service of a lord, after having begotten me with a rebald who was a slanderer and a suicide."

Original: Poi fui famiglia del buon re Tebaldo
Translate: Then I served the good king Thebald second:

Original: quivi mi misi a far baratteria, di ch’io rendo ragione in questo caldo"
Translate: "here I began to make barteries, of which I discount the penalty in this heat"

Original: E Cirïatto, a cui di bocca uscia d’ogne parte una sanna come a porco, li fé sentir come l’una sdruscia
Translate: "And Cyriath, who went out from every side of the mouth a tusk like a wild boar, made him feel like one torn the flesh."

Original: Tra male gatte era venuto ’l sorco
Translate: The mouse had ended up in the clutches of evil cats

Original: ma Barbariccia il chiuse con le braccia e disse: "State in là, mentr’io lo ’nforco"
Translate: "But Barbariccia protected him with his arms, saying, "Stay away, while I stab him."

Original: E al maestro mio volse la faccia
Translate: "And then the demon turned to Virgil, saying to him: "

Original: "Domanda", disse, "ancor, se più disii saper da lui, prima ch’altri ’l disfaccia"
Translate: "Ask him again, if you wish to know anything else about him, before someone breaks him to pieces"

Original: Lo duca dunque: "Or dì: de li altri rii conosci tu alcun che sia latino sotto la pece?"
Translate: Then the master: "Tell me: do you know if among the others damned under the pitch there are Italians?"

Original: E quelli: "I’ mi partii,  poco è, da un che fu di là vicino
Translate: And that: "I separated myself just now from one who came from a neighboring country."

Original: Così foss’io ancor con lui coperto, ch’i’ non temerei unghia né uncino"
Translate: " If I were still with him covered with pitch, as I would not be afraid of the claws or the hooks of the Malebranche"

Original: E Libicocco "Troppo avem sofferto", disse
Translate: And Libicocco said, "We've been too patient."

Original: e preseli ’l braccio col runciglio, sì che, stracciando, ne portò un lacerto
Translate: "and took his arm with his hook, so that he took away a chop of meat."

Original: Draghignazzo anco i volle dar di piglio giuso a le gambe
Translate: "Even Draghignazzo wanted to hurt his legs, "

Original: onde ’l decurio loro si volse intorno intorno con mal piglio
Translate: But their head turned to them all a severe look.

Original: Quand’elli un poco rappaciati fuoro, a lui, ch’ancor mirava sua ferita, domandò ’l duca mio sanza dimoro:
Translate: "When they had calmed down a little, my teacher immediately asked the damned man, who still looked at his wound:"

Original: "Chi fu colui da cui mala partita di’ che facesti per venire a proda?"
Translate: "Who was he from whom you said you were badly separated to come to shore?"

Original: Ed ei rispuose: "Fu frate Gomita, quel di Gallura, vasel d’ogne froda, ch’ebbe i nemici di suo donno in mano, e fé sì lor, che ciascun se ne loda
Translate: And he said, He was a Friar of Gomith, of Gallura, the keeper of all deceit, who had in his power the enemies of his lord, and behaved with them, so that every man had the advantage of it.

Original: Danar si tolse e lasciolli di piano, sì com’e’ dice
Translate: "He took the money and delivered them easily, as he tells us."

Original: e ne li altri offici anche barattier fu non picciol, ma sovrano
Translate: "and also in the other assignments he was a barter not mediocre, but superffino"

Original: Usa con esso donno Michel Zanche di Logodoro
Translate: It is usual to be with him Sir Michele Zanche of Logudoro

Original: e a dir di Sardigna le lingue lor non si sentono stanche
Translate: and their languages never tire of talking about Sardinia

Original: Omè, vedete l’altro che digrigna
Translate: "Alas, you see the devil grinding his teeth: "

Original: i’ direi anche, ma i’ temo ch’ello non s’apparecchi a grattarmi la tigna"
Translate: "I would say something else, but I'm afraid that's ready to cause me suffering"

Original: E ’l gran proposto, vòlto a Farfarello che stralunava li occhi per fedire, disse: "Fatti ’n costà, malvagio uccello"
Translate: "And the great head, turning to Farfarello, who was waving his eyes to strike, said, "Go in there, you evil bird."

Original: "Se voi volete vedere o udire", ricominciò lo spaürato appresso, "Toschi o Lombardi, io ne farò venire
Translate: "Then the damned, frightened, began again: "If you want to see or hear Tuscans or Lombards, I will bring them here."

Original: ma stieno i Malebranche un poco in cesso, sì ch’ei non teman de le lor vendette
Translate: "but the Malebranches stand a little behind, so that the damned do not fear their reprisals."

Original: e io, seggendo in questo loco stesso,  per un ch’io son, ne farò venir sette quand’io suffolerò, com’è nostro uso di fare allor che fori alcun si mette"
Translate: "and I, standing at this point aside, in exchange for one like me, will bring out seven whistling, as we used to do when some of us emerge from the pitch"

Original: Cagnazzo a cotal motto levò ’l muso, crollando ’l capo, e disse: "Odi malizia ch’elli ha pensata per gittarsi giuso"
Translate: "At those words Skank raised his snout, shaking his head, and said: "Listen that deception he has devised to throw himself under the pitch"

Original: Ond’ei, ch’avea lacciuoli a gran divizia, rispuose: "Malizioso son io troppo, quand’io procuro a’ mia maggior trestizia"
Translate: "Then the damned man, who knew every cunning to cheat, answered, "I would be too clever if I would bring my fellow criminals new torments."

Original: Alichin non si tenne e, di rintoppo a li altri, disse a lui: "Se tu ti cali, io non ti verrò dietro di gualoppo,  ma batterò sovra la pece l’ali
Translate: "Alichino didn't hold back and said to the damned man, "If you dive, I will not pursue you on foot but flying on the pitch."

Original: Lascisi ’l collo, e sia la ripa scudo, a veder se tu sol più di noi vali"
Translate: "Leave his neck and let's repair behind the embankment, so we'll see if you alone are worth more than all of us."

Original: O tu che leggi, udirai nuovo ludo: ciascun da l’altra costa li occhi volse, quel prima, ch’a ciò fare era più crudo
Translate: "O reader, now you will hear a new charade: every devil looked at the opposite bank, starting with the one who was most reluctant to do this."

Original: Lo Navarrese ben suo tempo colse
Translate: Navarrese quickly seized the opportunity

Original: fermò le piante a terra, e in un punto saltò e dal proposto lor si sciolse
Translate: And he set his feet on the rock, and in an instant jumped, and divided himself from their head.

Original: Di che ciascun di colpa fu compunto, ma quei più che cagion fu del difetto
Translate: "Each one of them felt guilty about the matter, but above all what caused it. "

Original: però si mosse e gridò: "Tu se’ giunto"
Translate: And he moved, and cried unto the damned, saying, I have taken thee.

Original: Ma poco i valse: ché l’ali al sospetto non potero avanzar
Translate: "But it did not serve him much, for the wings were not swifter than the fear of the barter: "

Original: quelli andò sotto, e quei drizzò volando suso il petto:
Translate: And he dipped himself, and the demon flew high, and lifted up his breast:

Original: non altrimenti l’anitra di botto, quando ’l falcon s’appressa, giù s’attuffa, ed ei ritorna sù crucciato e rotto
Translate: "just as the duck suddenly does, when the falcon approaches and she dives into the water, so that the raptor returns to the high cringed and tired"

Original: Irato Calcabrina de la buffa, volando dietro li tenne, invaghito che quei campasse per aver la zuffa
Translate: Calabrina, furious at the mockery, chased him flying and wished that the damned man would run away to fight with his companion.

Original: e come ’l barattier fu disparito, così volse li artigli al suo compagno, e fu con lui sopra ’l fosso ghermito
Translate: "and as soon as the barter was gone, he turned his claws against Alichino and held him right above the moat."

Original: Ma l’altro fu bene sparvier grifagno ad artigliar ben lui, e amendue cadder nel mezzo del bogliente stagno
Translate: "But the other was ready to defend himself as an adult scatterer and to claw him in turn, and both fell in the midst of the boiling pitch pond."

Original: Lo caldo sghermitor sùbito fue
Translate: "The heat caused them to divide immediately, "

Original: ma però di levarsi era neente, sì avieno inviscate l’ali sue
Translate: "but getting up in the air was impossible, so they had wings smeared with pitch."

Original: Barbariccia, con li altri suoi dolente, quattro ne fé volar da l’altra costa con tutt’i raffi,
Translate: "Barbariccia, defiled with the others, made four of them fly on the other bank with all the hooks, "

Original: e assai prestamente  di qua, di là discesero a la posta
Translate: and they went down quickly on one side and on the other in the places assigned to them.

Original: porser li uncini verso li ’mpaniati, ch’eran già cotti dentro da la crosta
Translate: "they put hooks on the two impegulate companions, who were already cooked under the viscous surface of the pitch."

Original: E noi lasciammo lor così ’mpacciati
Translate: And we left them there in that trouble.

Original: Taciti, soli, sanza compagnia n’andavam l’un dinanzi e l’altro dopo, come frati minor vanno per via
Translate: "Silent and lonely, without others with us, we went one after the other, like the lesser friars who go on the street"

Original: Vòlt’era in su la favola d’Isopo lo mio pensier per la presente rissa, dov’el parlò de la rana e del topo
Translate: "I, about the fight we had witnessed, was thinking about the story of Esopus talking about the frog and the mouse."

Original: ché più non si pareggia ’mo’ e ’issa’ che l’un con l’altro fa, se ben s’accoppia principio e fine con la mente fissa
Translate: "In fact, the two episodes are very similar, almost like the words 'mo' and 'iss', if you compare the beginning and the end, reflecting carefully"

Original: E come l’un pensier de l’altro scoppia, così nacque di quello un altro poi, che la prima paura mi fé doppia
Translate: "And as from one thought comes suddenly another, so from that came another thought that doubled the first fear"

Original: Io pensava così: ’Questi per noi sono scherniti con danno e con beffa sì fatta, ch’assai credo che lor nòi
Translate: "I thought so: '"The devils because of us were ridiculed with the mockery as well as the damage, and I think this is very annoying to them"

Original: Se l’ira sovra ’l mal voler s’aggueffa, ei ne verranno dietro più crudeli che ’l cane a quella lievre ch’elli acceffa’
Translate: "If anger is added to wickedness, they will come after us more cruel than the dog against the hare who wants to beast"""

Original: Già mi sentia tutti arricciar li peli de la paura e stava in dietro intento, quand’io dissi: "Maestro, se non celi  te e me tostamente, i’ ho pavento d’i Malebranche
Translate: "I now felt all the hairs from fear and turned back with anxiety, when I said, "Master, if we don't both hide quickly, I'm afraid of the Malebranche."

Original: Noi li avem già dietro
Translate: We've already got 'em on our backs.

Original: io li ’magino sì, che già li sento"
Translate: I imagine them to the point that I already hear them.

Original: E quei: "S’i’ fossi di piombato vetro, l’imagine di fuor tua non trarrei più tosto a me, che quella dentro ’mpetro
Translate: "And he: "If I were a mirror, I would not reflect your outward image more quickly than the inner image I see within me"

Original: Pur mo venieno i tuo’ pensier tra ’ miei, con simile atto e con simile faccia, sì che d’intrambi un sol consiglio fei
Translate: "Just now your thoughts reached mine, with the same attitude and appearance, so that I matured with both a single decision"

Original: S’elli è che sì la destra costa giaccia, che noi possiam ne l’altra bolgia scendere, noi fuggirem l’imaginata caccia"
Translate: "If the right bank is less steep, so as to allow us to descend into the other Bolgia, we will escape the hunt that you imagine"

Original: Già non compié di tal consiglio rendere, ch’io li vidi venir con l’ali tese non molto lungi, per volerne prendere
Translate: "He didn't have time to complete the reasoning, because I saw the Malebranches coming to wings explained not far away, to capture us"

Original: Lo duca mio di sùbito mi prese, come la madre ch’al romore è desta e vede presso a sé le fiamme accese,
Translate: "My teacher quickly grabbed me, like the mother who is suddenly awakened from the noise and sees the fire near her,"

Original: che prende il figlio e fugge e non s’arresta, avendo più di lui che di sé cura, tanto che solo una camiscia vesta
Translate: "and he takes his son and runs without stopping, worrying more about him than herself, even if he only wears a shirt"

Original: e giù dal collo de la ripa dura supin si diede a la pendente roccia, che l’un de’ lati a l’altra bolgia tura
Translate: and let himself fall from the top of the bank along the slope of the rock that closes the Bolgia from one of the two sides

Original: Non corse mai sì tosto acqua per doccia a volger ruota di molin terragno, quand’ella più verso le pale approccia,
Translate: "Water never ran so fast along a conduit to move the wheel of a ground mill when it is closer to the shovels,"

Original: come ’l maestro mio per quel vivagno, portandosene me sovra ’l suo petto, come suo figlio, non come compagno
Translate: "as my teacher went down that bank, carrying me over his chest as if I were his son, not a companion."

Original: A pena fuoro i piè suoi giunti al letto del fondo giù, ch’e’ furon in sul colle sovresso noi
Translate: "As soon as his feet had touched the bottom of the Bolgia, the devils came to the bank above us, "

Original: ma non lì era sospetto:
Translate: but then there was no reason to fear

Original: ché l’alta provedenza che lor volle porre ministri de la fossa quinta, poder di partirs’indi a tutti tolle
Translate: "For high providence, placing them as guardians of the fifth Bolgia, prevented them from turning away from it."

Original: Là giù trovammo una gente dipinta che giva intorno assai con lenti passi, piangendo e nel sembiante stanca e vinta
Translate: "There we found bloody paintings going in the round with very slow steps, weeping and looking tired and prostrated"

Original: Elli avean cappe con cappucci bassi dinanzi a li occhi, fatte de la taglia che in Clugnì per li monaci fassi
Translate: "They had hoods with low hoods in front of their eyes, of the same shape as those of the Cluniac monks."

Original: Di fuor dorate son, sì ch’elli abbaglia
Translate: "Outside they are golden, to the point of dazzling"

Original: ma dentro tutte piombo, e gravi tanto, che Federigo le mettea di paglia
Translate: "but inside they are all lead, and so heavy that those of Frederick II in comparison were light as straw."

Original: Oh in etterno faticoso manto
Translate: O heavy coat for eternity

Original: Noi ci volgemmo ancor pur a man manca con loro insieme, intenti al tristo pianto
Translate: "We turned to the left with them again, attentive to their distressing weeping."

Original: ma per lo peso quella gente stanca venìa sì pian, che noi eravam nuovi di compagnia ad ogne mover d’anca
Translate: but those people because of the weight proceeded so slowly that we had new companions at every hip movement

Original: Per ch’io al duca mio: "Fa che tu trovi alcun ch’al fatto o al nome si conosca, e li occhi, sì andando, intorno movi"
Translate: "Then I said to the master, "Try to find someone who is known for deeds or for his name, and as we walk, look around."

Original: E un che ’ntese la parola tosca, di retro a noi gridò:
Translate: "And a damned man, who heard my Tuscan accent, cried behind our backs: "

Original: "Tenete i piedi, voi che correte sì per l’aura fosca
Translate: "Stop the step, you who run in this dark air"

Original: Forse ch’avrai da me quel che tu chiedi"
Translate: Maybe you'll get what you ask of me.

Original: Onde ’l duca si volse e disse: "Aspetta, e poi secondo il suo passo procedi"
Translate: Then the teacher turned and said, "Wait for them and then proceed by adjusting your step to their own."

Original: Ristetti, e vidi due mostrar gran fretta de l’animo, col viso, d’esser meco
Translate: "I stopped and I saw two damned people looking at me in such a hurry to reach me, "

Original: ma tardavali ’l carco e la via stretta
Translate: But the weight of the hoods and the narrow way hindered them

Original: Quando fuor giunti, assai con l’occhio bieco mi rimiraron sanza far parola
Translate: "When they reached us, they long looked at me with an oblique gaze, without speaking."

Original: poi si volsero in sé, e dicean seco:  "Costui par vivo a l’atto de la gola
Translate: Then they turned to one another, and said, He seems alive as his throat moves.

Original: e s’e’ son morti, per qual privilegio vanno scoperti de la grave stola?"
Translate: " And if they are dead, what privilege does it allow him not to wear the heavy cloak?"

Original: Poi disser me: "O Tosco, ch’al collegio de l’ipocriti tristi se’ venuto, dir chi tu se’ non avere in dispregio"
Translate: " Then they said to me, "O Tuscan, that you have come in the company of the sad hypocrites, do not disdain to tell us who you are."

Original: E io a loro: "I’ fui nato e cresciuto sovra ’l bel fiume d’Arno a la gran villa, e son col corpo ch’i’ ho sempre avuto
Translate: And I to them: "I was born and raised in the great city above the beautiful river of Arno and I still have my mortal body.

Original: Ma voi chi siete, a cui tanto distilla quant’i’ veggio dolor giù per le guance? e che pena è in voi che sì sfavilla?"
Translate: "But who are you, that grievous pain oppresses and pushes to shed tears along the cheeks? and what is your pain that sparks in this way?"

Original: E l’un rispuose a me: "Le cappe rance son di piombo sì grosse, che li pesi fan così cigolar le lor bilance
Translate: And one of the two answered, "The shiny hoods are made of lead, and they are so thick that the weight makes the scales squeal in the same way."

Original: Frati godenti fummo, e bolognesi
Translate: We were pleasant friars and we were born in Bologna

Original: io Catalano e questi Loderingo nomati, e da tua terra insieme presi  come suole esser tolto un uom solingo, per conservar sua pace
Translate: "My name is Catalano and this is Loderingo, together called by Florence as it is usually called a single magistrate to ensure peace"

Original: e fummo tali, ch’ancor si pare intorno dal Gardingo"
Translate: and we behaved in such a way that there is still evidence of it at the tower of the Gardingo

Original: Io cominciai: "O frati, i vostri mali"
Translate: "I began to say, "Brothers, your penises"

Original: ma più non dissi, ch’a l’occhio mi corse un, crucifisso in terra con tre pali
Translate: "but I said nothing else, because my gaze was drawn by a damned, crucified to the ground and tied to three poles."

Original: Quando mi vide, tutto si distorse, soffiando ne la barba con sospiri
Translate: "When he saw me, he wrinkled everything by blowing and sighing in the beard."

Original: e ’l frate Catalan, ch’a ciò s’accorse,  mi disse:
Translate: " and Brother Catalano, who noticed it, said to me: "

Original: "Quel confitto che tu miri, consigliò i Farisei che convenia porre un uom per lo popolo a’ martìri
Translate: The damned crucified one who looks counseled the Pharisees that it was preferable for the people to martyrize one man

Original: Attraversato è, nudo, ne la via, come tu vedi, ed è mestier ch’el senta qualunque passa, come pesa, pria
Translate: "It's naked across the street, as you can see, and you need to feel how heavy it is for anyone who passes over it before it gets to the other side."

Original: E a tal modo il socero si stenta in questa fossa, e li altri dal concilio che fu per li Giudei mala sementa"
Translate: "And in the same way he is punished in this pit his father-in-law, and all the other priests of the Sanhedrin who by their decision caused grave calamity to the people of the Jews."

Original: Allor vid’io maravigliar Virgilio sovra colui ch’era disteso in croce tanto vilmente ne l’etterno essilio
Translate: Then I saw Virgil marvel over him who was crucified to the ground so miserably in his eternal damnation.

Original: Poscia drizzò al frate cotal voce: "Non vi dispiaccia, se vi lece, dirci s’a la man destra giace alcuna foce
Translate: "Then he turned to the friar: "You don't mind, if you can, tell us if there is any passage to the right."

Original: onde noi amendue possiamo uscirci, sanza costrigner de li angeli neri che vegnan d’esto fondo a dipartirci"
Translate: "from which the two of us can get out of Bolgia, without forcing any of the Malebranches to come all the way down here to take us away"

Original: Rispuose adunque: "Più che tu non speri s’appressa un sasso che da la gran cerchia si move e varca tutt’i vallon feri,
Translate: "Then he replied: "Nearer than you hope there is an order of bridges that starts from the outer circle and overlooks all the cruel ditches,"

Original: salvo che ’n questo è rotto e nol coperchia
Translate: except that on this Bolgia has collapsed and does not overhang it:

Original: montar potrete su per la ruina, che giace in costa e nel fondo soperchia"
Translate: You can climb the ruin of rocks lying on the wall and pile up on the bottom of the wall.

Original: Lo duca stette un poco a testa china
Translate: "The teacher remained a little with his head down, "

Original: poi disse: "Mal contava la bisogna colui che i peccator di qua uncina"
Translate: Then he said, "He who joins the sinners of the other Bolgia told me the story in an untruthful way."

Original: E ’l frate: "Io udi’ già dire a Bologna del diavol vizi assai, tra ’ quali udi’ ch’elli è bugiardo e padre di menzogna"
Translate: "And the friar: "I have already heard in Bologna that the devil has many vices, including that he is a liar and a father of lies"

Original: Appresso il duca a gran passi sen gì, turbato un poco d’ira nel sembiante
Translate: "Then the teacher went away in great strides, a little troubled by the anger in his appearance."

Original: ond’io da li ’ncarcati mi parti’  dietro a le poste de le care piante
Translate: Then I separated myself from the damned burdened with the burden, and followed the dear footsteps of Virgil.

Original: In quella parte del giovanetto anno che ’l sole i crin sotto l’Aquario tempra e già le notti al mezzo dì sen vanno,
Translate: "In that season of the year recently begun, when the sun warms the rays under the constellation of the Aquarius and the duration of the nights approaches that of the days, "

Original: quando la brina in su la terra assempra l’imagine di sua sorella bianca, ma poco dura a la sua penna tempra,
Translate: "when the frost on earth remembers the image of her white sister, but her pen does not have much ink, "

Original: lo villanello a cui la roba manca, si leva, e guarda, e vede la campagna biancheggiar tutta
Translate: "the farmer who lacks the forage gets up and looks out, and sees the countryside all white: "

Original: ond’ei si batte l’anca,  ritorna in casa, e qua e là si lagna, come ’l tapin che non sa che si faccia
Translate: "then he beats his side, returns to the house, complains here and there, like the poor man who doesn't know what to do."

Original: poi riede, e la speranza ringavagna,  veggendo ’l mondo aver cangiata faccia in poco d’ora,
Translate: "then returns and regains hope, seeing that the world has changed face in a short time, "

Original: e prende suo vincastro e fuor le pecorelle a pascer caccia
Translate: And take his staff, and take the sheep out to the pasture.

Original: Così mi fece sbigottir lo mastro quand’io li vidi sì turbar la fronte, e così tosto al mal giunse lo ’mpiastro
Translate: "So the teacher made me pale when I saw him with his face so troubled, and just as quickly came the remedy to evil."

Original: ché, come noi venimmo al guasto ponte, lo duca a me si volse con quel piglio dolce ch’io vidi prima a piè del monte
Translate: "For as we came to the ruin of the bridge, my guidance turned to me with the sweet expression that I saw in him at the foot of the hill."

Original: Le braccia aperse, dopo alcun consiglio eletto seco riguardando prima ben la ruina, e diedemi di piglio
Translate: "He opened his arms and after considering for a while looking at the ruin, he lifted me up."

Original: E come quei ch’adopera ed estima, che sempre par che ’nnanzi si proveggia, così, levando me sù ver’ la cima  d’un ronchione,
Translate: "And as the one who acts and reflects on what to do, who always seems to think first of what to do, so, raising me to the boss of a rock, "

Original: avvisava un’altra scheggia dicendo: "Sovra quella poi t’aggrappa
Translate: he identified another spike and said to me, "Hang on to that."

Original: ma tenta pria s’è tal ch’ella ti reggia"
Translate: but first try to see if it holds you

Original: Non era via da vestito di cappa, ché noi a pena, ei lieve e io sospinto, potavam sù montar di chiappa in chiappa
Translate: "It was not a way for people to wear a cloak, for we could barely climb from spike to spike, Virgil without the mortal body and I pushed by him."

Original: E se non fosse che da quel precinto più che da l’altro era la costa corta, non so di lui, ma io sarei ben vinto
Translate: "And if it weren't that side of the bank the wall was shorter, I don't know him but I wouldn't have made it."

Original: Ma perché Malebolge inver’ la porta del bassissimo pozzo tutta pende, lo sito di ciascuna valle porta  che l’una costa surge e l’altra scende
Translate: "But since the Malebolges decline towards the edge of the deep well, the position of each Bolygia means that one wall is higher than the other."

Original: noi pur venimmo al fine in su la punta onde l’ultima pietra si scoscende
Translate: "In the end we reached the top of ruin, at the top of the bank."

Original: La lena m’era del polmon sì munta quand’io fui sù, ch’i’ non potea più oltre, anzi m’assisi ne la prima giunta
Translate: "I had no more breath in my lungs when I got to the top, to the point that I couldn't go any further, in fact, I sat down as soon as I arrived."

Original: "Omai convien che tu così ti spoltre", disse ’l maestro
Translate: "The teacher said to me, "Now it is better for you to work, "

Original: "ché, seggendo in piuma, in fama non si vien, né sotto coltre
Translate: for sitting on pillows, or lying under blankets, one does not acquire fame.

Original: sanza la qual chi sua vita consuma, cotal vestigio in terra di sé lascia, qual fummo in aere e in acqua la schiuma
Translate: "and who spends his life without it, leaves on Earth a trace of himself comparable to the smoke in the air and foam in the water."

Original: E però leva sù
Translate: So get up now.

Original: vinci l’ambascia con l’animo che vince ogne battaglia, se col suo grave corpo non s’accascia
Translate: "Win the trouble with the soul that overcomes every contrast, if the heavy body doesn't bring it down"

Original: Più lunga scala convien che si saglia
Translate: We have to climb a much harder ladder.

Original: non basta da costoro esser partito
Translate: It's not enough to be separated from these damned people.

Original: Se tu mi ’ntendi, or fa sì che ti vaglia"
Translate: And if you understand me, make it work for you.

Original: Leva’ mi allor, mostrandomi fornito meglio di lena ch’i’ non mi sentia, e dissi:
Translate: "So I got up, showing that I had more energy than it really was, and I said, "

Original: "Va, ch’i’ son forte e ardito"
Translate: "Go, that I am strong and full of courage"

Original: Su per lo scoglio prendemmo la via, ch’era ronchioso, stretto e malagevole, ed erto più assai che quel di pria
Translate: "We took the road up to the rocky bridge, which was impervious, narrow and difficult to walk, and much steeper than the previous one."

Original: Parlando andava per non parer fievole
Translate: To not seem tired I was going to talk

Original: onde una voce uscì de l’altro fosso, a parole formar disconvenevole
Translate: Suddenly, a voice was heard coming from Bolgia, uttering unconnected words.

Original: Non so che disse, ancor che sovra ’l dosso fossi de l’arco già che varca quivi
Translate: "I don't know what he said, even though I was already at the top of the bridge over the pit."

Original: ma chi parlava ad ire parea mosso
Translate: But the one who spoke seemed to be moving.

Original: Io era vòlto in giù, ma li occhi vivi non poteano ire al fondo per lo scuro
Translate: "I looked down, but my eyes as careful as they couldn't see the dark bottom."

Original: per ch’io: "Maestro, fa che tu arrivi  da l’altro cinghio e dismontiam lo muro
Translate: "So I said, "Master, let's try to reach the end of the bridge and get down to the embankment."

Original: ché, com’i’ odo quinci e non intendo, così giù veggio e neente affiguro"
Translate: "In fact from here I listen and I don't hear, and I look down and I don't see anything"

Original: "Altra risposta", disse, "non ti rendo se non lo far
Translate: He said to me, "I'll give you no answer but to act."

Original: ché la dimanda onesta si de’ seguir con l’opera tacendo"
Translate: In fact, the right question must follow the facts and not the words.

Original: Noi discendemmo il ponte da la testa dove s’aggiugne con l’ottava ripa, e poi mi fu la bolgia manifesta:
Translate: "We went down where the bridge joins the embankment of the eighth Bolgia, and from there I could see the seventh:"

Original: e vidivi entro terribile stipa di serpenti, e di sì diversa mena che la memoria il sangue ancor mi scipa
Translate: "and I saw inside a horrible tangle of snakes, of species so different that the only one remembering it spoils my blood"

Original: Più non si vanti Libia con sua rena
Translate: "Libya no longer boasts with its sand,"

Original: ché se chelidri, iaculi e faree produce, e cencri con anfisibena,
Translate: "For if he produces cheliders, hyacles, fareas, cencres, and anphysics,

Original: né tante pestilenzie né sì ree mostrò già mai con tutta l’Etïopia né con ciò che di sopra al Mar Rosso èe
Translate: never showed so many pestilence animals with all Ethiopia and the region up to the Red Sea

Original: Tra questa cruda e tristissima copia corrëan genti nude e spaventate, sanza sperar pertugio o elitropia:
Translate: "In the midst of this horrendous and very sad mold they ran naked and frightened, hopeless of a refuge or of the helipropy:"

Original: con serpi le man dietro avean legate
Translate: "they had their hands tied behind their backs like snakes, "

Original: quelle ficcavan per le ren la coda e ’l capo, ed eran dinanzi aggroppate
Translate: And they put their tail and their heads on their backs, and tied themselves in front of their belly.

Original: Ed ecco a un ch’era da nostra proda, s’avventò un serpente che ’l trafisse là dove ’l collo a le spalle s’annoda
Translate: "And behold, a serpent came against a damned man who was on our side, and bit him on the back of the head, between his neck and shoulders."

Original: Né O sì tosto mai né I si scrisse, com’el s’accese e arse, e cener tutto convenne che cascando divenisse
Translate: "They never wrote a ""or" or a ""i" as quickly as that one lit and burned, and it became all ashes falling to the ground"

Original: e poi che fu a terra sì distrutto, la polver si raccolse per sé stessa e ’n quel medesmo ritornò di butto
Translate: "and after falling to the ground so low, the ash picked itself up and the damned suddenly regained its appearance"

Original: Così per li gran savi si confessa che la fenice more e poi rinasce, quando al cinquecentesimo anno appressa
Translate: "So the wise men say that the phoenix dies and then is reborn, when it is near the five hundred years of age."

Original: erba né biado in sua vita non pasce, ma sol d’incenso lagrime e d’amomo, e nardo e mirra son l’ultime fasce
Translate: "In his life he nourishes not of grass nor of biada, but only of tears of incense and of amomo, and his last nest is made of leaves of nard and myrrh."

Original: E qual è quel che cade, e non sa como, per forza di demon ch’a terra il tira, o d’altra oppilazion che lega l’omo,
Translate: "And as he who falls without knowing the cause, by the force of a demon that pulls him to the ground or of a obstruction of the vital spirits,"

Original: quando si leva, che ’ntorno si mira tutto smarrito de la grande angoscia ch’elli ha sofferta, e guardando sospira:
Translate: "and when he gets up he looks around, all lost for the pain he has suffered and looks sighing"

Original: tal era ’l peccator levato poscia
Translate: So was the sinner after he rose up.

Original: Oh potenza di Dio, quant’è severa, che cotai colpi per vendetta croscia
Translate: "Oh, divine power, how severe you are since you strike such blows for your vengeance."

Original: Lo duca il domandò poi chi ello era
Translate: "The teacher then asked the damned who he was, p"

Original: per ch’ei rispuose: "Io piovvi di Toscana, poco tempo è, in questa gola fiera
Translate: And he said, I came from Tuscany into this cruel pit a short time ago.

Original: Vita bestial mi piacque e non umana, sì come a mul ch’i’ fui
Translate: "I liked the life of a beast and not of a man, just like the bastard I was."

Original: son Vanni Fucci bestia, e Pistoia mi fu degna tana"
Translate: "I am Vanni Fucci, called the beast, and Pistoia was the den where I lived"

Original: E ïo al duca: "Dilli che non mucci, e domanda che colpa qua giù ’l pinse
Translate: And I to Virgilio: "Tell him that you do not run away and ask him what guilt he brought down here."

Original: ch’io ’l vidi omo di sangue e di crucci"
Translate: For I knew him when he was still in the flesh.

Original: E ’l peccator, che ’ntese, non s’infinse, ma drizzò verso me l’animo e ’l volto, e di trista vergogna si dipinse
Translate: "And the damned man, which he heard, hid not himself, but raised his face to me, and painted himself sadly with shame."

Original: poi disse: "Più mi duol che tu m’ hai colto ne la miseria dove tu mi vedi, che quando fui de l’altra vita tolto
Translate: "He said, "I'm more sorry that you see me in this wretched condition than that you were torn from mortal life."

Original: Io non posso negar quel che tu chiedi
Translate: I can't deny what you're asking.

Original: in giù son messo tanto perch’io fui ladro a la sagrestia d’i belli arredi,  e falsamente già fu apposto altrui
Translate: "I am damned in this Bolgia because I committed the theft of the sacred furnishings in the sacristy, which was wrongly attributed to others."

Original: Ma perché di tal vista tu non godi, se mai sarai di fuor da’ luoghi bui,  apri li orecchi al mio annunzio, e odi
Translate: " But that you may not enjoy this vision, if you ever come out of these dark places, open your ears and listen to my prophecy: "

Original: Pistoia in pria d’i Neri si dimagra
Translate: "First Pistoia will exile the Black Guelphs, "

Original: poi Fiorenza rinova gente e modi
Translate: then Florence will be free of the Whites

Original: Tragge Marte vapor di Val di Magra ch’è di torbidi nuvoli involuto
Translate: Mars will attract from the Val di Magra a fiery steam that will be wrapped in black clouds

Original: e con tempesta impetüosa e agra  sovra Campo Picen fia combattuto
Translate: and with an impetuous and terrible storm will be fought in the territory of Pistoiese

Original: ond’ei repente spezzerà la nebbia, sì ch’ogne Bianco ne sarà feruto
Translate: Then the lightning will sweep away the fog, and every White Guelph will be wounded.

Original: E detto l’ ho perché doler ti debbia
Translate: And I said this to hurt you.

Original: "Al fine de le sue parole il ladro le mani alzò con amendue le fiche, gridando:
Translate: " When he had finished speaking, the thief raised both hands with his thumb between the index finger and the middle finger, shouting: "

Original: "Togli, Dio, ch’a te le squadro"
Translate: "Take, God, for I address them to you."

Original: Da indi in qua mi fuor le serpi amiche, perch’una li s’avvolse allora al collo, come dicesse ’Non vo’ che più diche’
Translate: "From that moment on, the snakes were my friends, because one of them twisted around his neck like, "I don't want you to say anything else."

Original: e un’altra a le braccia, e rilegollo, ribadendo sé stessa sì dinanzi, che non potea con esse dare un crollo
Translate: "and another tied him around his arms, knotting himself tightly in front of him, to the point that he could not make a single movement."

Original: Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi d'incenerarti sì che più non duri, poi che 'n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?
Translate: "Alas, Pistoia, why don't you decide to incinerate yourself so that it doesn't last any longer, since it overcomes your ancestors with your evil deeds?"

Original: Per tutt’i cerchi de lo ’nferno scuri non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo, non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da’ muri
Translate: "In all the dark Circles of Hell I never saw such a haughty spirit against God, not even that which fell down from the wall of Thebes "

Original: El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo
Translate: Vanni Fucci fled without saying anything else

Original: e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia venir chiamando:
Translate: "And I saw a centaur full of wrath, calling him,

Original: "Ov’è, ov’è l’acerbo?"
Translate: "Where is he, where is that wicked man?"

Original: Maremma non cred’io che tante n’abbia, quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa infin ove comincia nostra labbia
Translate: "I don't think the Maremma has as many snakes as he had on the back, where the human appearance begins."

Original: Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa, con l’ali aperte li giacea un draco
Translate: "On his shoulders, behind his neck, lay a dragon with open wings."

Original: e quello affuoca qualunque s’intoppa
Translate: and that inflames anyone you encounter

Original: Lo mio maestro disse: "Questi è Caco, che, sotto ’l sasso di monte Aventino, di sangue fece spesse volte laco
Translate: "My teacher said, "That's Caco, who under the cliff of Aventine often produced a lake of blood. "

Original: Non va co’ suoi fratei per un cammino, per lo furto che frodolente fece del grande armento ch’elli ebbe a vicino
Translate: It is not with the other centaurs his brothers for the theft that he carried out fraudulently against the great herd that he had neighbored

Original: onde cessar le sue opere biece sotto la mazza d’Ercule, che forse gliene diè cento, e non sentì le diece"
Translate: "So his evil works ended under the bat of Hercules, who perhaps struck him a hundred times, and he died before the tenth."

Original: Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse, e tre spiriti venner sotto noi, de’ quai né io né ’l duca mio s’accorse,
Translate: "While Virgil spoke this way, and Caco went away, three spirits came under us, and neither of us knew it."

Original: se non quando gridar: "Chi siete voi?"
Translate: except when they cried, "Who are you?"

Original: per che nostra novella si ristette, e intendemmo pur ad essi poi
Translate: Then we stopped speaking and paid attention to them.

Original: Io non li conoscea
Translate: I didn't recognize them.

Original: ma ei seguette, come suol seguitar per alcun caso, che l’un nomar un altro convenette,  dicendo: "Cianfa dove fia rimaso?"
Translate: "But then it happened, as it happens by chance, that one appointed another, saying, "Shican, where will it be left?"

Original: per ch’io, acciò che ’l duca stesse attento, mi puosi ’l dito su dal mento al naso
Translate: "So I put my index straight from the chin to the nose, to induce the teacher to be silent and attentive."

Original: Se tu se’ or, lettore, a creder lento ciò ch’io dirò, non sarà maraviglia, ché io che ’l vidi, a pena il mi consento
Translate: "If now, reader, you are reluctant to believe what I will tell you, you will not have to be surprised, since I myself hardly believe what I saw with my eyes."

Original: Com’io tenea levate in lor le ciglia, e un serpente con sei piè si lancia dinanzi a l’uno, e tutto a lui s’appiglia
Translate: "While I watched them carefully, a six-footed serpent attacked one of them and grabbed the damned."

Original: Co’ piè di mezzo li avvinse la pancia e con li anterïor le braccia prese
Translate: "With his feet in the middle he clinged to his belly, with his foreheads he grabbed his arms."

Original: poi li addentò e l’una e l’altra guancia
Translate: then bit him both cheeks

Original: li diretani a le cosce distese, e miseli la coda tra ’mbedue e dietro per le ren sù la ritese
Translate: "he stretched out his back feet on his thighs and put his tail in the middle of both, stretching it up along his back."

Original: Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue ad alber sì, come l’orribil fiera per l’altrui membra avviticchiò le sue
Translate: The ivy never clung to a tree like the horrible serpent was screwed to the members of the damned

Original: Poi s’appiccar, come di calda cera fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore, né l’un né l’altro già parea quel ch’era:
Translate: "Then they glued to each other, as if they had been of molten wax, and mixed their color, so neither of them seemed what it was before:"

Original: come procede innanzi da l’ardore, per lo papiro suso, un color bruno che non è nero ancora e ’l bianco more
Translate: "as when a white paper is set on fire, in front of the flame there is a brown colour that is no longer white and is not black yet."

Original: Li altri due ’l riguardavano, e ciascuno gridava: "Omè, Agnel, come ti muti
Translate: "The other two looked and each shouted, "Alas, Lamb, how you transform."

Original: Vedi che già non se’ né due né uno"
Translate: "You see that you are no longer a single individual, and not yet two"

Original: Già eran li due capi un divenuti, quando n’apparver due figure miste in una faccia, ov’eran due perduti
Translate: "By now the two heads had become one, when the two figures mingled in one face appeared to us, where the two sides had merged together."

Original: Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste
Translate: The four members took only two arms

Original: le cosce con le gambe e ’l ventre e ’l casso divenner membra che non fuor mai viste
Translate: "the thighs, legs, belly and chest became members that have never been seen."

Original: Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso: due e nessun l’imagine perversa parea
Translate: Every initial aspect was now erased: the horrible image seemed two and none

Original: e tal sen gio con lento passo
Translate: And that being went away in slow steps,

Original: Come 'l ramarro sotto la gran fersa dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe, folgore par se la via attraversa,
Translate: "Like ramarro, changing hedges under the summer sun, it looks like lightning when it crosses the street,"

Original: sì pareva, venendo verso l’epe de li altri due, un serpentello acceso, livido e nero come gran di pepe
Translate: "So it seemed like a serpent of anger that came to the belly of the other two, bruised and black like a grain of pepper."

Original: e quella parte onde prima è preso nostro alimento, a l’un di lor trafisse
Translate: and it bit one of the two in that part from where we take our first food

Original: poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso
Translate: And the serpent fell on the ground before him.

Original: Lo trafitto ’l mirò, ma nulla disse
Translate: "The damned, bitten, looked at him without saying anything."

Original: anzi, co’ piè fermati, sbadigliava pur come sonno o febbre l’assalisse
Translate: "On the contrary, holding his feet steady, he yawned as if he were affected by sleep or fever"

Original: Elli ’l serpente e quei lui riguardava
Translate: He looked at the serpent, and he looked at him.

Original: l’un per la piaga e l’altro per la bocca fummavan forte, e ’l fummo si scontrava
Translate: "They both emitted smoke, the damned one from the plague, and the serpent from the mouth, and the smoke stirred."

Original: Taccia Lucano omai là dov’e’ tocca del misero Sabello e di Nasidio, e attenda a udir quel ch’or si scocca
Translate: "Lucano would do better to keep quiet, where he writes about the miserable Sabello and Nasidio, and be careful what you are about to tell here."

Original: Taccia di Cadmo e d’Aretusa Ovidio, ché se quello in serpente e quella in fonte converte poetando, io non lo ’nvidio
Translate: "Ovidio no longer says anything about Cadmos and Aretusa, because if in his verses he transforms that into a serpent and that into a source, I certainly do not envy him."

Original: ché due nature mai a fronte a fronte non trasmutò sì ch’amendue le forme a cambiar lor matera fosser pronte
Translate: "In fact, he never transmuted two figures in front of each other, so that both forms were ready to change their matter"

Original: Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme, che ’l serpente la coda in forca fesse, e ’l feruto ristrinse insieme l’orme
Translate: "The two beings were transformed at the same time in this way, that the serpent divided the tail into two, and the man joined the feet together."

Original: Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse s’appiccar sì, che ’n poco la giuntura non facea segno alcun che si paresse
Translate: "The legs and thighs were joined in this way, that after a short time there was no sign of joint between the two."

Original: Togliea la coda fessa la figura che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle si facea molle, e quella di là dura
Translate: "The tail divided in two took the shape that man lost, and his skin softened while that of man hardened."

Original: Io vidi intrar le braccia per l’ascelle, e i due piè de la fiera, ch’eran corti, tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle
Translate: "I saw the man drawing his arms in his armpits, and the two legs of the animal, which were short, as long as his arms shortened."

Original: Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti, diventaron lo membro che l’uom cela, e ’l misero del suo n’avea due porti
Translate: "Then the hind legs of the serpent, twisted together, became the member that man hides, while the damned man had his divided in two."

Original: Mentre che ’l fummo l’uno e l’altro vela di color novo, e genera ’l pel suso per l’una parte e da l’altra il dipela,
Translate: "While the smoke covered both with a new color, generating hair on one of them and raising it to the other,"

Original: l’un si levò e l’altro cadde giuso, non torcendo però le lucerne empie, sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso
Translate: "One of them stood up and the other fell to the ground, but they both stopped staring at each other with the evil eyes under which everyone changed their snout"

Original: Quel ch’era dritto, il trasse ver’ le tempie, e di troppa matera ch’in là venne uscir li orecchi de le gote scempie
Translate: "Being standing withdrew the snout to the temples, and the matter in excess came out two ears on the cheeks that didn't have them."

Original: ciò che non corse in dietro e si ritenne di quel soverchio, fé naso a la faccia e le labbra ingrossò quanto convenne
Translate: that which did not portray that excess matter formed nose and lips in that face and grew as much as was necessary

Original: Quel che giacëa, il muso innanzi caccia, e li orecchi ritira per la testa come face le corna la lumaccia
Translate: "The being on the ground leaned forward the snout and withdrew the ears into the head, as the snail withdraws the horns."

Original: e la lingua, ch’avëa unita e presta prima a parlar, si fende, e la forcuta ne l’altro si richiude
Translate: "and the tongue, which had previously united and ready to speak, divided into two, while the forked tongue of the other closed."

Original: e ’l fummo resta
Translate: the smoke ceased

Original: L’anima ch’era fiera divenuta, suffolando si fugge per la valle, e l’altro dietro a lui parlando sputa
Translate: "The soul that had become a serpent fled through Bolgia, wheezing, while the other followed him by speaking and spitting."

Original: Poscia li volse le novelle spalle, e disse a l’altro: "I’ vo’ che Buoso corra, com’ ho fatt’io, carpon per questo calle"
Translate: "Then he turned his back on him as soon as he was formed and said to the other, "I want Buoso to run all the way to this place, as I did."

Original: Così vid’io la settima zavorra mutare e trasmutare
Translate: So I saw the thieves of the VII Bolgia change and change

Original: e qui mi scusi la novità se fior la penna abborra
Translate: "and here I apologize if my pen drafts a little, because of the absolute novelty"

Original: E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi fossero alquanto e l’animo smagato, non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,  ch’i’ non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato
Translate: "And even though my eyes were somewhat confused and my soul lost, those damned men could not escape secretly without me recognizing Puccio Sciancato."

Original: ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni che venner prima, non era mutato
Translate: And he was the only one who didn't turn into the three comrades who had come there before.

Original: l’altr’era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni
Translate: "The other one was the one you, Gaville, complain about."

Original: Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se' sì grande che per mare e per terra batti l'ali, e per lo 'nferno tuo nome si spande
Translate: "Rejoice, Florence, because you are so famous to travel the sea and the land, and your name is known even in Hell"

Original: Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna, e tu in grande orranza non ne sali
Translate: "Among the thieves I met five of your citizens, such that I am ashamed and you certainly do not gain honor."

Original: Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna, tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo, di quel che Prato, non ch’altri, t’agogna
Translate: "But if you have true dreams near the morning, you will soon receive the punishment that all the cities, even the small ones like Prato, wish you"

Original: E se già fosse, non saria per tempo
Translate: "And even if it happened already, it would still be late"

Original: Così foss’ei, da che pur esser dee
Translate: "It could then happen, since it is inevitable"

Original: ché più mi graverà, com’ più m’attempo
Translate: " The more I grow old, the more this punishment will be unbearable to me."

Original: Noi ci partimmo, e su per le scalee che n’avea fatto iborni a scender pria, rimontò ’l duca mio e trasse mee
Translate: "We went away, and the master went up to those rocks which, before, had made us pale to go down, and took me with him."

Original: e proseguendo la solinga via, tra le schegge e tra ’ rocchi de lo scoglio lo piè sanza la man non si spedia
Translate: "and continuing along the lonely way, the foot could not advance without the help of the hands between the spikes and the shards of the rock"

Original: Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch’io vidi, e più lo ’ngegno affreno ch’i’ non soglio,  perché non corra che virtù nol guidi
Translate: "So I felt pain, and I feel it even now thinking about what I saw, and I restrain my ingenuity more than usual so that it does not act without the guidance of virtue."

Original: sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa m’ ha dato ’l ben, ch’io stessi nol m’invidi
Translate: "so that, if a benign astral influence or something more important have given me good, I myself will not take it away from me."

Original: Quante ’l villan ch’al poggio si riposa, nel tempo che colui che ’l mondo schiara la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
Translate: "How many fireflies the farmer has, when he rests on the hill in the season when the sun keeps his face less hidden from us, "

Original: come la mosca cede a la zanzara, vede lucciole giù per la vallea, forse colà dov’e’ vendemmia e ara:
Translate: "In the hour when the fly gives way to the mosquito, it sees down in the valley where he harvests and plows."

Original: di tante fiamme tutta risplendea l’ottava bolgia, sì com’io m’accorsi tosto che fui là ’ve ’l fondo parea
Translate: "Often flames were shining in the eighth Bolgia, as I saw as soon as I was there from where the bottom was visible."

Original: E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi vide ’l carro d’Elia al dipartire, quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
Translate: "And as he that avenged himself with bears saw the chariot of Elijah leaving, when the horses rose up high in heaven,

Original: che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire, ch’el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola, sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
Translate: "and he could not follow him with his gaze without seeing anything but the flame, rising up like a cloud:"

Original: tal si move ciascuna per la gola del fosso, ché nessuna mostra ’l furto, e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola
Translate: "so on the bottom of the Bolgia every flame moves, so that no one shows the soul hidden inside, and every flame hides a sinner"

Original: Io stava sovra ’l ponte a veder surto, sì che s’io non avessi un ronchion preso, caduto sarei giù sanz’esser urto
Translate: "I stood above the bridge, protruding to see to the point that, if I had not clinged to a rocky ledge, I would have fallen down without being hit."

Original: E ’l duca, che mi vide tanto atteso, disse: "Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti
Translate: "And the master, who saw me so attentive, said, "Inside those fires are souls."

Original: catun si fascia di quel ch’elli è inceso"
Translate: each is bound by the flame that envelops it.

Original: "Maestro mio", rispuos’io, "per udirti son io più certo
Translate: "I said, "My teacher, now that I listen to you, I am more certain."

Original: ma già m’era avviso che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
Translate: But I already knew it was like this and I wanted to ask you:

Original: chi è ’n quel foco che vien sì diviso di sopra, che par surger de la pira dov’Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?"
Translate: "Who is inside that fire whose point is forked, so much so that it seems to rise from the funeral stake where Etheocles was put with his brother?"

Original: Rispuose a me: "Là dentro si martira Ulisse e Dïomede, e così insieme a la vendetta vanno come a l’ira
Translate: "He said to me, "Olysses and Diomedes are punished in there, and they are damned together as they committed their sins together."

Original: e dentro da la lor fiamma si geme l’agguato del caval che fé la porta onde uscì de’ Romani il gentil seme
Translate: And in their flame they expound the deceit of the horse of Troy, which opened the gate from which the noble seed of the Romans came out.

Original: Piangevisi entro l’arte per che, morta, Deïdamìa ancor si duol d’Achille, e del Palladio pena vi si porta"
Translate: "You are also punished for the fraud for which Deidamia, even if she died, still regrets Achilles, and also for the theft of Palladio"

Original: "S’ei posson dentro da quelle faville parlar", diss’io, "maestro, assai ten priego e ripriego, che ’l priego vaglia mille,
Translate: "I said, "If they can speak in those flames, Master, I pray you with insistence and I pray you again, so that prayer is worth a thousand, "

Original: che non mi facci de l’attender niego fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna
Translate: that you do not deny me to wait for that two-pointed flame to come here

Original: vedi che del disio ver’ lei mi piego"
Translate: See that I turn towards it from desire.

Original: Ed elli a me: "La tua preghiera è degna di molta loda, e io però l’accetto
Translate: "And he to me: "Your prayer is worthy of great praise, and therefore I accept it."

Original: ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna
Translate: But you're gonna have to hold your tongue.

Original: Lascia parlare a me, ch’i’ ho concetto ciò che tu vuoi
Translate: "Let me do the talking, since I know what you want."

Original: ch’ei sarebbero schivi, perch’e’ fuor greci, forse del tuo detto"
Translate: "In fact, since they were Greek, they may be reluctant to address the word to you"

Original: Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco, in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
Translate: "After the flame came to the point where time and place seemed appropriate to my teacher, I heard him speak in this way:"

Original: "O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco, s’io meritai di voi mentre ch’io vissi, s’io meritai di voi assai o poco  quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi, non vi movete
Translate: "O you who are two in one flame, if I have gained merit from you when I was alive, if I have gained great or small merits from you when, on Earth, I wrote the high verses, you do not go away."

Original: ma l’un di voi dica dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi"
Translate: but one of you tells where he went to die on a journey without return to his home

Original: Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica cominciò a crollarsi mormorando, pur come quella cui vento affatica
Translate: "The highest point of that ancient flame began to shake and murmur, like the one struck by the wind."

Original: indi la cima qua e là menando, come fosse la lingua che parlasse, gittò voce di fuori e disse:
Translate: "So, turning the top to one side and to the other, like a tongue speaking, he threw out his voice and said:"

Original: "Quando  mi diparti’ da Circe, che sottrasse me più d’un anno là presso a Gaeta, prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
Translate: "When I got away from Circe, who kept me more than a year there near Gaeta, before Enea gave this name to the promontory,"

Original: né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta del vecchio padre, né ’l debito amore lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
Translate: "nor tenderness for my son, nor devotion for my old father, nor the legitimate love that was to make Penelope happy "

Original: vincer potero dentro a me l’ardore ch’i’ ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto e de li vizi umani e del valore
Translate: "they could overcome in me the desire that I had to become an expert on the world, on the vices and virtues of men"

Original: ma misi me per l’alto mare aperto sol con un legno e con quella compagna picciola da la qual non fui diserto
Translate: But I traveled on the high seas only with a ship and with those few companions by whom I was not abandoned.

Original: L’un lito e l’altro vidi infin la Spagna, fin nel Morrocco, e l’isola d’i Sardi, e l’altre che quel mare intorno bagna
Translate: "I saw both sides of the Mediterranean as far as Spain, Morocco and Sardinia, and the other islands bathed by that sea"

Original: Io e’ compagni eravam vecchi e tardi quando venimmo a quella foce stretta dov’Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi  acciò che l’uom più oltre non si metta
Translate: "I and my companions were old and weak when we reached the narrow one where Hercules laid the pillars, a limit beyond which man must not proceed: "

Original: da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia, da l’altra già m’avea lasciata Setta
Translate: "to the right we had Seville, to the left Ceuta"

Original: "O frati," dissi, "che per cento milia perigli siete giunti a l’occidente,
Translate: "I said: "" Brothers, who have come to the far west through a hundred thousand dangers, "

Original: a questa tanto picciola vigilia  d’i nostri sensi ch’è del rimanente non vogliate negar l’esperïenza, di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente
Translate: "Do not deny to this little vigil that remains to your senses the experience of the uninhabited world, following the way to the west"

Original: Considerate la vostra semenza: fatti non foste a viver come bruti, ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza"
Translate: "Think of your origin: you were not created to live as beasts, but to follow virtue and knowledge""

Original: Li miei compagni fec’io sì aguti, con questa orazion picciola, al cammino, che a pena poscia li avrei ritenuti
Translate: "With this brief speech I made my companions so eager to travel, that later I would hardly hold them back"

Original: e volta nostra poppa nel mattino, de’ remi facemmo ali al folle volo, sempre acquistando dal lato mancino
Translate: "and turn the stern to the east, we rowed our wings on our mad flight, always continuing southwestwards "

Original: Tutte le stelle già de l’altro polo vedea la notte, e ’l nostro tanto basso, che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo
Translate: "The night now showed all the constellations of the southern pole, while the northern pole was so low that it did not emerge from the horizon line"

Original: Cinque volte racceso e tante casso lo lume era di sotto da la luna, poi che 'ntrati eravam ne l'alto passo,
Translate: "The light of the lunar hemisphere visible to us had already turned off and rekindled five times, after we had embarked on the journey, "

Original: quando n’apparve una montagna, bruna per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto quanto veduta non avëa alcuna
Translate: "when a dark mountain appeared to us by the distance, and it seemed to me taller than any other I had ever seen."

Original: Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto
Translate: "We rejoiced, but the joy soon turned into weeping: "

Original: ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque e percosse del legno il primo canto
Translate: For from that new earth came a storm that struck the ship at the bow.

Original: Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l’acque
Translate: "She turned it on herself three times, in a whirlwind."

Original: a la quarta levar la poppa in suso e la prora ire in giù, com’altrui piacque,  infin che ’l mar fu sovra noi richiuso"
Translate: "The fourth time he lifted up the stern high, and made the bow abyss, as it pleased others, until the sea was closed upon us."

Original: Già era dritta in sù la fiamma e queta per non dir più, e già da noi sen gia con la licenza del dolce poeta,
Translate: "The flame was now straight and firm, since it was no longer speaking, and it was moving away from us with the permission of the sweet poet, "

Original: quand’un’altra, che dietro a lei venìa, ne fece volger li occhi a la sua cima per un confuso suon che fuor n’uscia
Translate: "when another, who came after it, made us look at her tip for a confused sound that came out of it."

Original: Come ’l bue cicilian che mugghiò prima col pianto di colui, e ciò fu dritto, che l’avea temperato con sua lima,  mugghiava con la voce de l’afflitto,
Translate: "Like the Sicilian ox, who mugged for the first time with the laments of the one who had forged him with his work, moaned with the voice of the tortured, "

Original: sì che, con tutto che fosse di rame, pur el pareva dal dolor trafitto
Translate: so much that it seemed pierced by pain even though it was made of copper

Original: così, per non aver via né forame dal principio nel foco, in suo linguaggio si convertïan le parole grame
Translate: "so the wretched words were converted into the language of fire, because at first they did not find a way out."

Original: Ma poscia ch’ebber colto lor vïaggio su per la punta, dandole quel guizzo che dato avea la lingua in lor passaggio,  udimmo dire:
Translate: "But after they had found a way out through the tip, making it move like the tongue at their passage, we heard: "

Original: "O tu a cu’ io drizzo la voce e che parlavi mo lombardo, dicendo "Istra ten va, più non t’adizzo",
Translate: "O you to whom I address the voice, and who just spoke Italian saying, "Now go, I will not encourage you","

Original: perch’io sia giunto forse alquanto tardo, non t’incresca restare a parlar meco
Translate: Don't be sorry to keep you talking to me just because I came a little later.

Original: vedi che non incresce a me, e ardo
Translate: "You see that I do not mind, and yet I burn in the flames"

Original: Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco caduto se’ di quella dolce terra latina ond’io mia colpa tutta reco,  dimmi se Romagnuoli han pace o guerra
Translate: "If you have ended up in this dark world from that sweet land of Italy from which I bring all my guilt, tell me whether the Romagnoli are at peace or at war"

Original: ch’io fui d’i monti là intra Orbino e ’l giogo di che Tever si diserra"
Translate: For I was of the mountains between Urbino and the top from which the Tiber was born.

Original: Io era in giuso ancora attento e chino, quando il mio duca mi tentò di costa, dicendo:
Translate: "I was still careful and bowed down from the bridge, when my guide touched my side and said to me: "

Original: "Parla tu questi è latino"
Translate: "You speak, this is Italian"

Original: E io, ch’avea già pronta la risposta, sanza indugio a parlare incominciai:
Translate: "And I, who was ready to answer, began to speak without hesitation: "

Original: "O anima che se’ là giù nascosta,  Romagna tua non è, e non fu mai, sanza guerra ne’ cuor de’ suoi tiranni
Translate: "O soul that you are hidden from the fire there, your Romagna is not without war in the hearts of its tyrants"

Original: ma ’n palese nessuna or vi lasciai
Translate: However, I did not leave her engaged in any declared conflict.

Original: Ravenna sta come stata è molt’anni: l’aguglia da Polenta la si cova, sì che Cervia ricuopre co’ suoi vanni
Translate: "Ravenna has been in the situation in which it has been for many years: the Da Polenta eagle dominates it, so that it also covers Cervia with its wings"

Original: La terra che fé già la lunga prova e di Franceschi sanguinoso mucchio, sotto le branche verdi si ritrova
Translate: "The city that supported the long siege and massacred French troops, is dominated by the green rampant lion "

Original: E ’l mastin vecchio e ’l nuovo da Verrucchio, che fecer di Montagna il mal governo, là dove soglion fan d’i denti succhio
Translate: "And the old and the new hound from Verrucchio, who killed the Parcited Mountain, use their teeth as a suck where they usually do it."

Original: Le città di Lamone e di Santerno conduce il lïoncel dal nido bianco, che muta parte da la state al verno
Translate: "The cities of the Lamone and Santerno rivers are dominated by the white lion, which changes alliances from summer to winter"

Original: E quella cu' il Savio bagna il fianco, così com'ella sie' tra 'l piano e 'l monte, tra tirannia si vive e stato franco
Translate: "And the city whose side is bathed by the Savio, as it is between the plain and the mountain, lives between tyranny and free state."

Original: Ora chi se’, ti priego che ne conte
Translate: Now please tell us who you are

Original: non esser duro più ch’altri sia stato, se ’l nome tuo nel mondo tegna fronte"
Translate: "Do not be more reluctant than others, if your name in the world preserves fame"

Original: Poscia che ’l foco alquanto ebbe rugghiato al modo suo, l’aguta punta mosse di qua, di là, e poi diè cotal fiato:
Translate: "After the fire had roared for a while in its own way, the sharp point waved on one side and on the other, then uttered these words:"
