Original: "S’i’ credesse che mia risposta fosse a persona che mai tornasse al mondo, questa fiamma staria sanza più scosse
Translate: "If I thought I would answer to someone who could return to Earth, this flame would remain quiet "

Original: ma però che già mai di questo fondo non tornò vivo alcun, s’i’ odo il vero, sanza tema d’infamia ti rispondo
Translate: "but since no one has ever come out of the bottom of Hell alive, if I hear the truth, I answer you without fear of being infamous."

Original: Io fui uom d'arme, e poi fui cordigliero, credendomi, sì cinto, fare ammenda
Translate: "I was a man of arms, and then I became a Franciscan, believing that I would make amends for my sins by girding the cord."

Original: e certo il creder mio venìa intero,  se non fosse il gran prete, a cui mal prenda,
Translate: "and certainly how much I thought it would come true, it had not been for the pope, that God cursed him, "

Original: mi rimise ne le prime colpe
Translate: who caused me to sin again

Original: e come e quare, voglio che m’intenda
Translate: and I want you to feel how and why this happened

Original: Mentre ch’io forma fui d’ossa e di polpe che la madre mi diè, l’opere mie non furon leonine, ma di volpe
Translate: "So long as I was in the flesh, with the body given to me by my mother, my works were not marked by violence but by cunning."

Original: Li accorgimenti e le coperte vie io seppi tutte, e sì menai lor arte, ch’al fine de la terra il suono uscie
Translate: "I knew all the tricks and hidden ways, and I practiced their art in such a way that my fame reached the ends of the world."

Original: Quando mi vidi giunto in quella parte di mia etade ove ciascun dovrebbe calar le vele e raccoglier le sarte,
Translate: "When I saw myself at that stage of my life in which everyone should lower the sails and collect the tailors,"

Original: ciò che pria mi piacëa, allor m’increbbe, e pentuto e confesso mi rendei
Translate: "What I liked before displeased me and made me a friar, after I repented and confessed"

Original: ahi miser lasso
Translate: "Ah, poor me"

Original: e giovato sarebbe
Translate: Of course that would have helped me.

Original: Lo principe d’i novi Farisei, avendo guerra presso a Laterano, e non con Saracin né con Giudei,  ché ciascun suo nimico era cristiano,
Translate: "The prince of the new Pharisees, while fighting a war near the Lateran, and not against Saracens or Jews, for all his enemies were Christian, "

Original: e nessun era stato a vincer Acri né mercatante in terra di Soldano,
Translate: And none of them had besieged Acre, or traded in the land of the Soldan.

Original: né sommo officio né ordini sacri guardò in sé, né in me quel capestro che solea fare i suoi cinti più macri
Translate: "He had no regard for his supreme office, nor for the priestly orders, nor for that Franciscan cord which he used to make lean those who wear it."

Original: Ma come Costantin chiese Silvestro d’entro Siratti a guerir de la lebbre, così mi chiese questi per maestro  a guerir de la sua superba febbre
Translate: "On the contrary, as Constantine called to himself Pope Silvestro from his refuge on Mount Soratte to heal from leprosy, so he called me to heal from his terrible fever: "

Original: domandommi consiglio, e io tacetti perché le sue parole parver ebbre
Translate: He asked me for advice, and I kept silent because his words seemed to me the words of a madman.

Original: E’ poi ridisse: "Tuo cuor non sospetti
Translate: "He said to me, ""Do not be afraid of your heart: "

Original: finor t’assolvo, e tu m’insegna fare sì come Penestrino in terra getti
Translate: "I absolve you now, as long as you show me how to break down the Palestrina fortress."

Original: Lo ciel poss’io serrare e diserrare, come tu sai
Translate: "I can close and open the sky, as you well know"

Original: però son due le chiavi che ’l mio antecessor non ebbe care"
Translate: "In fact, two are the keys that my predecessor did not have dear"""

Original: Allor mi pinser li argomenti gravi là ’ve ’l tacer mi fu avviso ’l peggio, e dissi:
Translate: "Then the authoritative arguments convinced me, especially thinking that silence would have serious consequences for me, and I said: "

Original: "Padre, da che tu mi lavi  di quel peccato ov’io mo cader deggio, lunga promessa con l’attender corto ti farà trïunfar ne l’alto seggio"
Translate: ""Father, since you absolve me of that sin in which I must fall, promise much and keep little will make you triumph in the pontifical throne"""

Original: Francesco venne poi, com’io fu’ morto, per me
Translate: "Then as soon as I died, Saint Francis came to take my soul"

Original: ma un d’i neri cherubini li disse: "Non portar non mi far torto
Translate: "But a devil said to him, "Don't take her away; don't do me wrong."

Original: Venir se ne dee giù tra ’ miei meschini perché diede ’l consiglio frodolente, dal quale in qua stato li sono a’ crini
Translate: "He must come down among my damned ones, because he gave the fraudulent advice for which, from then to this day, I have been to his ribs."

Original: ch'assolver non si può chi non si pente, né pentere e volere insieme puossi per la contradizion che nol consente"
Translate: "In fact, those who do not repent cannot be acquitted, and it is not possible to repent and want to sin at the same time, because it is a contradiction in terms"""

Original: Oh me dolente
Translate: "Ah, poor me"

Original: come mi riscossi quando mi prese dicendomi: "Forse tu non pensavi ch’io löico fossi"
Translate: "how I shook when he took me, saying, "Maybe you didn't think I was a philosopher""

Original: A Minòs mi portò
Translate: He took me in front of Minos

Original: e quelli attorse otto volte la coda al dosso duro
Translate: And he twisted his tail eight times around his back.

Original: e poi che per gran rabbia la si morse,  disse: "Questi è d’i rei del foco furo"
Translate: "And having bitten her with great anger, she said, "This must go among the sinners of the fire who take them away from sight."

Original: per ch’io là dove vedi son perduto, e sì vestito, andando, mi rancuro"
Translate: "And that is why I am lost here where you see me, and so wrapped in the flames I am sorrowful walking"

Original: Quand’elli ebbe ’l suo dir così compiuto, la fiamma dolorando si partio, torcendo e dibattendo ’l corno aguto
Translate: "When the damned man had finished speaking, the flame went away painfully, twisting and beating the sharp tip."

Original: Noi passamm’oltre, e io e ’l duca mio, su per lo scoglio infino in su l’altr’arco che cuopre ’l fosso in che si paga il fio  a quei che scommettendo acquistan carco
Translate: "We went further, up the bridge until the next bridge over the Bolgia where those who, sowing discords, weigh themselves with sin are punished."

Original: Chi poria mai pur con parole sciolte dicer del sangue e de le piaghe a pieno ch’i’ ora vidi, per narrar più volte?
Translate: "Who could, even in prose and repeating the narrative, fully describe the blood and wounds that I saw?"

Original: Ogne lingua per certo verria meno per lo nostro sermone e per la mente c’ hanno a tanto comprender poco seno
Translate: "Every language would certainly fail, because of our language and mind that have little ability to understand all this."

Original: S’el s’aunasse ancor tutta la gente che già, in su la fortunata terra di Puglia, fu del suo sangue dolente  per li Troiani e per la lunga guerra che de l’anella fé sì alte spoglie,
Translate: "If even all the people who in the troubled land of southern Italy shed their blood for the Romans and in the long war that produced a great spoil of rings, "

Original: come Livïo scrive, che non erra,  con quella che sentio di colpi doglie per contastare a Ruberto Guiscardo
Translate: "as Livio writes that he is not wrong, with those people who were painfully struck to oppose Robert the Guiscard, "

Original: e l’altra il cui ossame ancor s’accoglie  a Ceperan, là dove fu bugiardo ciascun Pugliese, e là da Tagliacozzo, dove sanz’arme vinse il vecchio Alardo
Translate: "and with the other people whose bones are still gathered in Ceprano, where every Apulian baron was a traitor, and there in Tagliacozzo where old Alardo won with his wisdom."

Original: e qual forato suo membro e qual mozzo mostrasse, d’aequar sarebbe nulla il modo de la nona bolgia sozzo
Translate: "and if everyone showed his limbs pierced or severed, it would not be enough to match the horrible appearance of ninth Bolgia"

Original: Già veggia, per mezzul perdere o lulla, com’io vidi un, così non si pertugia, rotto dal mento infin dove si trulla
Translate: "A cask, without the slats of the bottom, is not pierced as I saw a damned cut from the chin as far as it farts "

Original: Tra le gambe pendevan le minugia
Translate: His entrails hung between his legs

Original: la corata pareva e ’l tristo sacco che merda fa di quel che si trangugia
Translate: We could see the internal organs and the disgusting sack that turns what we eat into excrements.

Original: Mentre che tutto in lui veder m'attacco, guardommi e con le man s'aperse il petto, dicendo: "Or vedi com'io mi dilacco
Translate: "While I looked upon him, he looked at me in turn and opened his chest with his hands, saying, "Now see how I am torn."

Original: vedi come storpiato è Mäometto
Translate: See how maimed Muhammad is

Original: Dinanzi a me sen va piangendo Alì, fesso nel volto dal mento al ciuffetto
Translate: "Ali is crying before me, with her face torn from her chin to her forehead."

Original: E tutti li altri che tu vedi qui, seminator di scandalo e di scisma fuor vivi, e però son fessi così
Translate: "And all the others that thou seest in this place were alive sowers of scandal and schism, and therefore are so maimed."

Original: Un diavolo è qua dietro che n’accisma sì crudelmente, al taglio de la spada rimettendo ciascun di questa risma,
Translate: "Here is a devil behind us, who so cruelly dresses us, subjecting each damned one of this host to the edge of the sword again, "

Original: quand’avem volta la dolente strada
Translate: once we've completed the sad round of Bolagia

Original: però che le ferite son richiuse prima ch’altri dinanzi li rivada
Translate: "In fact, before everyone comes back to him again, the wounds are healed."

Original: Ma tu chi se’ che ’n su lo scoglio muse, forse per indugiar d’ire a la pena ch’è giudicata in su le tue accuse?"
Translate: "But what art thou, that standeth down on the bridge, that thou tarryest to suffer the punishment that is inflicted upon thee for thy sins?"

Original: "Né morte ’l giunse ancor, né colpa ’l mena", rispuose ’l mio maestro, "a tormentarlo
Translate: "My teacher said to him, "This is not dead yet, nor is there any fault that leads him here to torment."

Original: ma per dar lui esperïenza piena,  a me, che morto son, convien menarlo per lo ’nferno qua giù di giro in giro
Translate: "but I, who died, must lead him through the Hell of Circle in order to fully show him this place, "

Original: e quest’è ver così com’io ti parlo"
Translate: And that's as true as the fact that I'm talking to you.

Original: Più fuor di cento che, quando l’udiro, s’arrestaron nel fosso a riguardarmi per maraviglia, oblïando il martiro
Translate: "There were more than one hundred damned who, when they heard it, stopped in the moat to look at me amazed, forgetting their pain"

Original: "Or dì a fra Dolcin dunque che s’armi, tu che forse vedra’ il sole in breve, s’ello non vuol qui tosto seguitarmi, sì di vivanda,
Translate: "So you, who may be coming back to Earth soon, tell Fr. Dolcino that if he doesn't want to reach me soon he will obtain many food, "

Original: che stretta di neve non rechi la vittoria al Noarese, ch’altrimenti acquistar non saria leve"
Translate: so that a harsh winter does not bring to the Novaras a victory that otherwise would be difficult to obtain

Original: Poi che l’un piè per girsene sospese, Mäometto mi disse esta parola
Translate: "After he lifted up a foot to go, Muhammad told me these words"

Original: indi a partirsi in terra lo distese
Translate: So he laid him on the ground to turn away.

Original: Un altro, che forata avea la gola e tronco ’l naso infin sotto le ciglia, e non avea mai ch’una orecchia sola,
Translate: "Another damned man, who had his throat ripped open, his nose snapped under his eyelashes and had no ear, "

Original: ristato a riguardar per maraviglia con li altri, innanzi a li altri aprì la canna, ch’era di fuor d’ogne parte vermiglia,  e disse:
Translate: "Stop looking at me as amazed as the others, before the others opened the reed of the throat that outside was red of blood, and said: "

Original: "O tu cui colpa non condanna e cu’ io vidi in su terra latina, se troppa simiglianza non m’inganna,
Translate: "O you who are not damned by any fault and whom I knew in Italy, if an excessive resemblance does not deceive me, "

Original: rimembriti di Pier da Medicina, se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano che da Vercelli a Marcabò dichina
Translate: "Remember Pier da Medicina, if you ever return to see the gentle plain that slopes from Vercelli to Marcabò"

Original: E fa sapere a’ due miglior da Fano, a messer Guido e anco ad Angiolello, che, se l’antiveder qui non è vano,
Translate: "And let the two best men of Fano know, to Sir Guido del Cassero and also to Angiolello da Carignano, that, if our foresight is not vain, "

Original: gittati saran fuor di lor vasello e mazzerati presso a la Cattolica per tradimento d’un tiranno fello
Translate: "they will be thrown out of their ship and thrown into a sack tied to a stone near Catholic, for the betrayal of a ferocious tyrant "

Original: Tra l’isola di Cipri e di Maiolica non vide mai sì gran fallo Nettuno, non da pirate, non da gente argolica
Translate: "Neptune has never seen such a serious crime throughout the Mediterranean, not committed by pirates or Argo raiders."

Original: Quel traditor che vede pur con l’uno, e tien la terra che tale qui meco vorrebbe di vedere esser digiuno,  farà venirli a parlamento seco
Translate: "That traitor who sees only with one eye and who rules the earth that a damned man here with me would never have seen, will cause them to come and talk to him"

Original: poi farà sì, ch’al vento di Focara non sarà lor mestier voto né preco"
Translate: Then he will see to it that they do not serve prayers and vows against the winds of Phocarah.

Original: E io a lui: "Dimostrami e dichiara, se vuo’ ch’i’ porti sù di te novella, chi è colui da la veduta amara"
Translate: "And I to him: "Show me and tell me, if you want me to talk about you on Earth, who is he who was damaged by seeing Rimini"

Original: Allor puose la mano a la mascella d’un suo compagno e la bocca li aperse, gridando: "Questi è desso, e non favella
Translate: "Then he put his hand on his companion's jaw and opened his mouth, crying out, "This is it, and he doesn't speak."

Original: Questi, scacciato, il dubitar sommerse in Cesare, affermando che ’l fornito sempre con danno l’attender sofferse"
Translate: "These, driven from Rome, extinguished all doubt in Caesar, stating that those who are ready to act always brought back damage in waiting"

Original: Oh quanto mi pareva sbigottito con la lingua tagliata ne la strozza Curïo, ch’a dir fu così ardito
Translate: "Oh, how amazed Curiosity seemed to me, with his tongue severed in his throat, he who was so ready to speak."

Original: E un ch’avea l’una e l’altra man mozza, levando i moncherin per l’aura fosca, sì che ’l sangue facea la faccia sozza,  gridò:
Translate: "And another man, who had both hands cut off and lifted the stumps up into the air and put blood on his face, cried out: "

Original: "Ricordera’ ti anche del Mosca, che disse, lasso,
Translate: "You will also remember Moscow of the Lamberts, who said - alas"

Original: ’Capo ha cosa fatta’, che fu mal seme per la gente tosca"
Translate: ""It was the boss," which caused so much harm to the Tuscans"

Original: E io li aggiunsi: "E morte di tua schiatta"
Translate: And I said, "And it also caused the end of your family."

Original: per ch’elli, accumulando duol con duolo, sen gio come persona trista e matta
Translate: "and then he, adding pain to pain, went away like a sad person and out of himself."

Original: Ma io rimasi a riguardar lo stuolo, e vidi cosa ch’io avrei paura, sanza più prova, di contarla solo
Translate: "But I stood and looked at the host of souls, and I saw something that I would fear to report alone, without further proof."

Original: se non che coscïenza m'assicura, la buona compagnia che l'uom francheggia sotto l'asbergo del sentirsi pura
Translate: "Unless I am comforted by my good faith, which accompanies man and makes him courageous by protecting him with the defense of having a pure conscience"

Original: Io vidi certo, e ancor par ch’io ’l veggia, un busto sanza capo andar sì come andavan li altri de la trista greggia
Translate: "I certainly saw, and it seems to me to see him again, a trunk without the head that went along with the others of that sad flock."

Original: e ’l capo tronco tenea per le chiome, pesol con mano a guisa di lanterna: e quel mirava noi e dicea: "Oh me"
Translate: "and kept his head cut off by the hair, dangling like a lantern, and she looked at us and said, "Alas!"

Original: Di sé facea a sé stesso lucerna, ed eran due in uno e uno in due
Translate: He shed light on himself with a part of himself and they were two individuals and only one at the same time:

Original: com’esser può, quei sa che sì governa
Translate: "how this can happen, the One who makes it possible knows it."

Original: Quando diritto al piè del ponte fue, levò ’l braccio alto con tutta la testa per appressarne le parole sue,  che fuoro:
Translate: "When he was by the bridge, he lifted up his arm with all his head to address us his words, which were these: "

Original: "Or vedi la pena molesta, tu che, spirando, vai veggendo i morti: vedi s’alcuna è grande come questa
Translate: "Now you see my sorrowful sorrow, you who visit the dead alive: see if there is another one as great as this one."

Original: E perché tu di me novella porti, sappi ch’i’ son Bertram dal Bornio, quelli che diedi al re giovane i ma’ conforti
Translate: "And that thou mayest bring tidings of me, know that I am Bertran de Born, who gave the young king bad counsel."

Original: Io feci il padre e ’l figlio in sé ribelli
Translate: I pushed his son against his father:

Original: Achitofèl non fé più d’Absalone e di Davìd coi malvagi punzelli
Translate: "Achitofel didn't do anything different with Absalom and David, with evil incitements."

Original: Perch’io parti’ così giunte persone, partito porto il mio cerebro, lasso, dal suo principio ch’è in questo troncone
Translate: "And since I have divided people so united, I carry my brain divided by the spinal cord that is in this trunk."

Original: Così s’osserva in me lo contrapasso"
Translate: So in me it is evident the contrappasso" (Translated with Google Translate)

Original: La molta gente e le diverse piaghe avean le luci mie sì inebrïate, che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe
Translate: "The many damned and horrible plagues had filled my eyes with tears, to the point that they wanted to cry."

Original: Ma Virgilio mi disse: "Che pur guate? perché la vista tua pur si soffolge là giù tra l’ombre triste smozzicate?
Translate: "But Virgil said to me, "Why do you keep looking? Why does your gaze linger there among the mutilated souls?"

Original: Tu non hai fatto sì a l’altre bolge
Translate: You didn't do that in the other Bolges.

Original: pensa, se tu annoverar le credi, che miglia ventidue la valle volge
Translate: "In case you want to count them, think the circumference of the hole here is twenty-two miles."

Original: E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi
Translate: And the moon is now under our feet:

Original: lo tempo è poco omai che n’è concesso, e altro è da veder che tu non vedi"
Translate: the time that is given to us is little and you still have to see more of the other

Original: "Se tu avessi", rispuos’io appresso, "atteso a la cagion per ch’io guardava, forse m’avresti ancor lo star dimesso"
Translate: "I answered immediately after: "If you had known the reason why I was looking, perhaps you would have allowed me to stay still"

Original: Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava, lo duca, già faccendo la risposta, e soggiugnendo:
Translate: "My guide went away and I followed him, continuing to answer and adding: "

Original: "Dentro a quella cava  dov’io tenea or li occhi sì a posta, credo ch’un spirto del mio sangue pianga la colpa che là giù cotanto costa"
Translate: "Inside that pit where I kept my eyes just a moment ago, I believe that a spirit of mine atones for the guilt that is so gravely served there."

Original: Allor disse ’l maestro: "Non si franga lo tuo pensier da qui innanzi sovr’ello
Translate: "Then the teacher said, "Your thought shall not be tormented from now on, upon him."

Original: Attendi ad altro, ed ei là si rimanga
Translate: "Think of something else, and that stays where it is."

Original: ch’io vidi lui a piè del ponticello mostrarti e minacciar forte col dito, e udi’ ’l nominar Geri del Bello
Translate: "For I saw him at the foot of the bridge pointing at you with his finger, and he threatened you, and I heard them calling him Geri del Bello."

Original: Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte, che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito"
Translate: "Then you were so busy listening to Bertran de Born, the one who held the castle of Hautefort, that you didn't look towards him until he left."

Original: "O duca mio, la vïolenta morte che non li è vendicata ancor", diss’io, "per alcun che de l’onta sia consorte,  fece lui disdegnoso
Translate: "I said, "O my master, his violent death, which has not yet been avenged by anyone who, as a member of his consort, shares his shame, made him disdainful."

Original: ond’el sen gio sanza parlarmi, sì com’ïo estimo: e in ciò m’ ha el fatto a sé più pio"
Translate: "That is why he went away without speaking to me, as I believe, and this made me more pitiful toward him."

Original: Così parlammo infino al loco primo che de lo scoglio l’altra valle mostra, se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo
Translate: "We spoke this way until the first point of the bridge from which we would see all the other Bolygia to the end, if only there were more light."

Original: Quando noi fummo sor l’ultima chiostra di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi potean parere a la veduta nostra,
Translate: "When we came over the last pit of the Malebolges, so that his damned men could be seen by us, "

Original: lamenti saettaron me diversi, che di pietà ferrati avean li strali
Translate: I was struck by various lamentations that led to piety

Original: ond’io li orecchi con le man copersi
Translate: And they moved me to shut my ears with their hands.

Original: Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali di Valdichiana tra ’l luglio e ’l settembre e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali  fossero in una fossa tutti ’nsembre,
Translate: "If from the hospitals of Valdichiana, Maremma and Sardinia between July and September were to gather all the sick in one place, one would see a suffering similar to that that there was in the Bolgia "

Original: tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n’usciva qual suol venir de le marcite membre
Translate: And the smell that came out of it was like that of the rotten members.

Original: Noi discendemmo in su l’ultima riva del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra
Translate: "We descended on the last bank of the long bridge, always proceeding to the left"

Original: e allor fu la mia vista più viva  giù ver’ lo fondo, là ’ve la ministra de l’alto Sire infallibil giustizia punisce i falsador che qui registra
Translate: "and then my gaze could be directed to the bottom, where divine justice, God's infallible minister, punishes the forgers who write on Earth when they sin."

Original: Non credo ch’a veder maggior tristizia fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo, quando fu l’aere sì pien di malizia,  che li animali, infino al picciol vermo, cascaron tutti,
Translate: "To Aegina, when the air was so saturated with plague that all the animals were killed to the smallest worm, "

Original: e poi le genti antiche, secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,  si ristorar di seme di formiche
Translate: "and the ancient nations, according to the testimony of the poets, repopulated themselves with the ants, "

Original: ch’era a veder per quella oscura valle languir li spirti per diverse biche
Translate: "I do not believe that the vision of all the sick people was more sad than that of the dark pit, where the spirits languished in heaps."

Original: Qual sovra ’l ventre e qual sovra le spalle l’un de l’altro giacea, e qual carpone si trasmutava per lo tristo calle
Translate: "They lay one on the other, on the belly, and on the shoulders, and some carried on that sad place."

Original: Passo passo andavam sanza sermone, guardando e ascoltando li ammalati, che non potean levar le lor persone
Translate: "We proceeded in slow steps without speaking, watching and listening to the sick who could not get up."

Original: Io vidi due sedere a sé poggiati, com’a scaldar si poggia tegghia a tegghia, dal capo al piè di schianze macolati
Translate: "I saw two of them sitting on each other's feet, as they put two pans on the fire, covered with crusts from head to toe."

Original: e non vidi già mai menare stregghia a ragazzo aspettato dal segnorso, né a colui che mal volontier vegghia,
Translate: "and I never saw a boy waiting for his lord, or a stableman watching ill-willed, use the stripe "

Original: come ciascun menava spesso il morso de l’unghie sopra sé per la gran rabbia del pizzicor, che non ha più soccorso
Translate: "as every one of them used his fingernails on himself for the craving of the pinch, which had no other relief."

Original: e sì traevan giù l’unghie la scabbia, come coltel di scardova le scaglie o d’altro pesce che più larghe l’abbia
Translate: "and they would remove the scab with their fingernails like a knife takes away the scales of the scardova, or another fish that would have them wider."

Original: "O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie", cominciò ’l duca mio a l’un di loro, "e che fai d’esse talvolta tanaglie,
Translate: "My teacher began to say to one of them: "O you who scrub with your fingers, and sometimes use them as pinnacles,"

Original: dinne s’alcun Latino è tra costoro che son quinc’entro, se l’unghia ti basti etternalmente a cotesto lavoro"
Translate: "Tell us if there are Italians among these damned in here, and can the nails be enough forever for this job"

Original: "Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti qui ambedue", rispuose l’un piangendo
Translate: "One of the two replied crying: "We are both Italians, whom you see here so disfigured"

Original: "ma tu chi se’ che di noi dimandasti?"
Translate: "But who are you, that ask us these things?"

Original: E ’l duca disse: "I’ son un che discendo con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo, e di mostrar lo ’nferno a lui intendo"
Translate: And the master answered, "I am one who goes down with this living circle in Circle, and my purpose is to show Hell to him."

Original: Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo
Translate: Then the two stopped leaning on each other.

Original: e tremando ciascuno a me si volse con altri che l’udiron di rimbalzo
Translate: "and, trembling, they both turned to me, along with others who heard it indirectly."

Original: Lo buon maestro a me tutto s’accolse, dicendo: "Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli"
Translate: The good teacher came to me and said, "Tell them what you want."

Original: e io incominciai, poscia ch’ei volse:
Translate: "and I began to speak, for so he wanted:"

Original: "Se la vostra memoria non s’imboli nel primo mondo da l’umane menti, ma s’ella viva sotto molti soli,
Translate: "May your memory not disappear from human minds in the world, but instead survive for many years"

Original: ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti
Translate: Tell me who you are and where you come from

Original: la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi"
Translate: Your horrible and annoying punishment will not give you fear to present yourself to me.

Original: "Io fui d'Arezzo, e Albero da Siena", rispuose l'un, "mi fé mettere al foco
Translate: And he said, I was of Arezzo, and Tree of Siena condemned the burning of me.

Original: ma quel per ch'io mori' qui non mi mena
Translate: But what I died for isn't the guilt that brings me here.

Original: Vero è ch’i’ dissi lui, parlando a gioco: "I’ mi saprei levar per l’aere a volo"
Translate: "It is true that I told him joking: "I would know how to get out of the air in flight"""

Original: e quei, ch’avea vaghezza e senno poco,  volle ch’i’ li mostrassi l’arte
Translate: "and that one, who was capricious and had little sense, wanted me to show him that art."

Original: e solo perch’io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece ardere a tal che l’avea per figliuolo
Translate: "and only because I didn't turn into Daedalus did he make me burn by someone who considered him his son."

Original: Ma ne l’ultima bolgia de le diece me per l’alchìmia che nel mondo usai dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece"
Translate: "But Minos, to whom it is not lawful to err, condemned me in the last of the ten Bolge for the alchemy I practiced in the world"

Original: E io dissi al poeta: "Or fu già mai gente sì vana come la sanese? Certo non la francesca sì d'assai"
Translate: And I said to Virgilio: "Is there ever a foolish and frivolous people like the Sienese people? Certainly not the French people anymore."

Original: Onde l’altro lebbroso, che m’intese, rispuose al detto mio:
Translate: "Then the other leper, who heard me, answered my words: "

Original: "Tra’ mene Stricca che seppe far le temperate spese,  e Niccolò che la costuma ricca del garofano prima discoverse ne l’orto dove tal seme s’appicca
Translate: "Exclude Stricca, who knew how to do moderate shopping, and Niccolò who first discovered the expensive use of cloves in the garden where this seed takes root."

Original: e tra’ ne la brigata in che disperse Caccia d’Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda, e l’Abbagliato suo senno proferse
Translate: "and exclude the brigade in which Hunting of Ascian dissipated the vineyard and the vast farms, and in which the Abbagliato showed his sense."

Original: Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda contra i Sanesi, aguzza ver’ me l’occhio, sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:
Translate: "But that you may know who will follow you in this way over the Sienese, sharpen your eyes to me, so that you may recognize my face:"

Original: sì vedrai ch’io son l’ombra di Capocchio, che falsai li metalli con l’alchìmia
Translate: "then you'll see that I'm the soul of Capocchio, who falsifies metals with alchemy."

Original: e te dee ricordar, se ben t’adocchio,  com’io fui di natura buona scimia"
Translate: "and you must remember, if I know you well, how I was a good imitator of nature"

Original: Nel tempo che Iunone era crucciata per Semelè contra ’l sangue tebano, come mostrò una e altra fïata, Atamante divenne tanto insano,
Translate: "In the time when Juno was angry with the Theban seed because of Shemeles, as he showed on two occasions, Atamante became so crazy "

Original: che veggendo la moglie con due figli andar carcata da ciascuna mano,  gridò:
Translate: "who, seeing his wife holding the two sons, one on a side, cried out: "

Original: "Tendiam le reti, sì ch’io pigli la leonessa e ’ leoncini al varco"
Translate: "Let's keep the nets so I can catch the lioness and the lions"

Original: e poi distese i dispietati artigli,  prendendo l’un ch’avea nome Learco, e rotollo e percosselo ad un sasso
Translate: "and then stretched out his ruthless claws, taking one of the two named Learcus, and swirled him into the air and threw him against a rock."

Original: e quella s’annegò con l’altro carco
Translate: the wife drowned herself holding the other son

Original: E quando la fortuna volse in basso l’altezza de’ Troian che tutto ardiva, sì che ’nsieme col regno il re fu casso,
Translate: "And how much destiny reduced the height of the Trojans who desired anything, so that the kingdom was destroyed and the king killed,"

Original: Ecuba trista, misera e cattiva, poscia che vide Polissena morta, e del suo Polidoro in su la riva  del mar si fu la dolorosa accorta, forsennata latrò sì come cane
Translate: "Ecuba after seeing that Polissena had been killed and she noticed with pain the death of Polidoro by the sea, she began to bark like a dog, outside of herself."

Original: tanto il dolor le fé la mente torta
Translate: so the pain upset her mind

Original: Ma né di Tebe furie né troiane si vider mäi in alcun tanto crude, non punger bestie, nonché membra umane,
Translate: "But they never saw the furies of the Thebans, nor those of the Trojans so cruel against anyone, nor sting beasts or human beings, "

Original: quant’io vidi in due ombre smorte e nude, che mordendo correvan di quel modo che ’l porco quando del porcil si schiude
Translate: How much I saw in two pale and naked souls that ran biting like a pig when it comes out hungry from the pig

Original: L’una giunse a Capocchio, e in sul nodo del collo l’assannò, sì che, tirando, grattar li fece il ventre al fondo sodo
Translate: "One of them rushed on Capocchio and pierced him to the back of the head, so that, dragging him away, he scratched the rocky soil of Bolgia with his belly."

Original: E l’Aretin che rimase, tremando mi disse: "Quel folletto è Gianni Schicchi, e va rabbioso altrui così conciando"
Translate: "And Griffolino d'Arezzo, who stood there trembling, said to me, "That little rascal is Gianni Schicchi and, full of anger, he is tanning the other damned."

Original: "Oh", diss’io lui, "se l’altro non ti ficchi li denti a dosso, non ti sia fatica a dir chi è, pria che di qui si spicchi"
Translate: "Oh, I answered him, "I hope that the other soul will not be able to penetrate you: don't you mind telling me who he is, before he escapes from here."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Quell’è l’anima antica di Mirra scellerata, che divenne al padre, fuor del dritto amore, amica
Translate: "And he to me: "That is the ancient soul of the wicked Myrrh, who fell in love with his father contrary to every moral law."

Original: Questa a peccar con esso così venne, falsificando sé in altrui forma,
Translate: "This one managed to perform adultery with him, pretending to be another person, "

Original: come l’altro che là sen va, sostenne,  per guadagnar la donna de la torma, falsificare in sé Buoso Donati, testando e dando al testamento norma"
Translate: "as the other who leaves managed to sell himself for Buoso Donati, in order to obtain the queen of the armament, and to falsify the will and then register it regularly"

Original: E poi che i due rabbiosi fuor passati sovra cu’ io avea l’occhio tenuto, rivolsilo a guardar li altri mal nati
Translate: "And after the two rabid men on whom I had kept my eyes left, I looked at the other sinners."

Original: Io vidi un, fatto a guisa di lëuto, pur ch’elli avesse avuta l’anguinaia tronca da l’altro che l’uomo ha forcuto
Translate: "I saw one that would have been equal to a lute, if only the groin had been separated from the two legs."

Original: La grave idropesì, che sì dispaia le membra con l’omor che mal converte, che ’l viso non risponde a la ventraia,
Translate: "The severe hydropsy, which, because of the sap disposed of badly deforms to such an extent the limbs that the face is much thinner from the belly, "

Original: faceva lui tener le labbra aperte come l’etico fa, che per la sete l’un verso ’l mento e l’altro in sù rinverte
Translate: "He pushed him to keep his lips open like the herbalist, who, by thirst, holds his upper lip up and his lower lip up to his chin."

Original: "O voi che sanz’alcuna pena siete, e non so io perché, nel mondo gramo", diss’elli a noi, "guardate e attendete  a la miseria del maestro Adamo
Translate: "He said to us: "O you who are without pain in Hell, and I don't know why, look with attention to the miserable fate of Master Adam: "

Original: io ebbi, vivo, assai di quel ch’i’ volli, e ora, lasso,
Translate: "I had what I wanted in life, and now,"

Original: un gocciol d’acqua bramo
Translate: I wish vainly for a drop of water

Original: Li ruscelletti che d’i verdi colli del Casentin discendon giuso in Arno, faccendo i lor canali freddi e molli, sempre mi stanno innanzi,
Translate: "The streams that descend from the green hills of Casentino towards the Arno, making their beds fresh and wet, always stand before my eyes "

Original: e non indarno, ché l’imagine lor vie più m’asciuga  che ’l male ond’io nel volto mi discarno
Translate: "and not for nothing, for their image dries me much more than the evil for which my face is dug"

Original: La rigida giustizia che mi fruga tragge cagion del loco ov’io peccai a metter più li miei sospiri in fuga
Translate: The harsh divine justice that torments me exploits the place where I sinned to make me sigh even more

Original: Ivi è Romena, là dov’io falsai la lega suggellata del Batista
Translate: "There rises the castle of Romena, where I falsified the florin."

Original: per ch’io il corpo sù arso lasciai
Translate: And for this I was burned alive

Original: Ma s’io vedessi qui l’anima trista di Guido o d’Alessandro o di lor frate, per Fonte Branda non darei la vista
Translate: "But if I saw here the evil soul of Guido, Alexander, or their brother, in return I would give up drinking from the Source Branda."

Original: Dentro c’è l’una già, se l’arrabbiate ombre che vanno intorno dicon vero
Translate: "One of them should be here already, if angry souls circling around tell the truth"

Original: ma che mi val, c’ ho le membra legate?
Translate: "but why do I need it since I can't move?"

Original: S’io fossi pur di tanto ancor leggero ch’i’ potessi in cent’anni andare un’oncia, io sarei messo già per lo sentiero,
Translate: "If I were still so agile that I could walk an ounce in a hundred years, I would have already set out on my way,"

Original: cercando lui tra questa gente sconcia, con tutto ch’ella volge undici miglia, e men d’un mezzo di traverso non ci ha
Translate: "Looking for him in the midst of these damned disease-defaced diseases, even though the Bolgia has a circumference of eleven miles and a width not less than half a mile."

Original: Io son per lor tra sì fatta famiglia
Translate: I'm here because of them:

Original: e’ m’indussero a batter li fiorini ch’avevan tre carati di mondiglia"
Translate: They moved me to mint the guilders that had three carats of vile metal.

Original: E io a lui: "Chi son li due tapini che fumman come man bagnate ’l verno,  giacendo stretti a’ tuoi destri confini?"
Translate: "And I to him: "Who are the two wretched who smoke like the hands wet in winter, and who lie tight to your right hand?"

Original: "Qui li trovai - e poi volta non dierno -", rispuose, "quando piovvi in questo greppo,  e non credo che dieno in sempiterno
Translate: "He replied: "I found them here when I fell into this cliff, and since then they have not moved, nor do I think they will ever move again."

Original: L’una è la falsa ch’accusò Gioseppo
Translate: One is the liar who wrongfully accused Joseph

Original: l’altr’è ’l falso Sinon greco di Troia:  per febbre aguta gittan tanto leppo"
Translate: "The other is the false Synon, the Greek of Troy: they suffer from acute fever and emit this stench of burnt fat"

Original: E l’un di lor, che si recò a noia forse d’esser nomato sì oscuro,  col pugno li percosse l’epa croia
Translate: "And one of them, who perhaps was annoyed that he was appointed so offensively, struck him with a fist on his belly"

Original: Quella sonò come fosse un tamburo
Translate: That sounded like a drum.

Original: e mastro Adamo li percosse il volto  col braccio suo, che non parve men duro, dicendo a lui:
Translate: " and Master Adam struck his face with his arm, no less violently, saying to him: "

Original: "Ancor che mi sia tolto lo muover per le membra che son gravi,  ho io il braccio a tal mestiere sciolto"
Translate: " Even if I'm barred from any movement for my legs weighed down, I still have agile arms to hit it."

Original: Ond’ei rispuose: "Quando tu andavi al fuoco, non l’avei tu così presto
Translate: "Then the other answered, "When you went to the stake, you were not as agile."

Original: ma sì e più l’avei quando coniavi"
Translate: But you moved your arms well when you forged coins.

Original: E l’idropico: "Tu di’ ver di questo: ma tu non fosti sì ver testimonio  là ’ve del ver fosti a Troia richesto"
Translate: "And the hydropic: "You tell the truth about this: but you were not a sincere witness when the truth was asked of you by Troy."

Original: "S’io dissi falso, e tu falsasti il conio", disse Sinon
Translate: "Sinone said, "If I said the false, you forged the coin."

Original: "e son qui per un fallo,  e tu per più ch’alcun altro demonio"
Translate: "and I am here for one sin, but you for a greater number than any other damned"

Original: "Ricorditi, spergiuro, del cavallo", rispuose quel ch’avëa infiata l’epa
Translate: "The one whose belly was swollen answered, "Remember, perjury, the horse, "

Original: "e sieti reo che tutto il mondo sallo"
Translate: and let it be a torment to you that the whole world knows it.

Original: "E te sia rea la sete onde ti crepa", disse ’l Greco, "la lingua, e l’acqua marcia  che ’l ventre innanzi a li occhi sì t’assiepa"
Translate: "The Greek said, 'You are tormented by the thirst for which your tongue is broken, and by the rotten water which makes your belly so swollen before your eyes.'"

Original: Allora il monetier: "Così si squarcia la bocca tua per tuo mal come suole
Translate: "Then the monetier: "In the same way your mouth is torn to pieces for your evil, as usual."

Original: ché, s’i’ ho sete e omor mi rinfarcia, tu hai l’arsura e ’l capo che ti duole, e per leccar lo specchio di Narcisso, non vorresti a ’nvitar molte parole"
Translate: "For I am thirsty, and the water makes me swell, but you have the arsura and the head that pains you, and to lick a few drops of water you would not need so many invitations."

Original: Ad ascoltarli er’io del tutto fisso, quando ’l maestro mi disse: "Or pur mira, che per poco che teco non mi risso"
Translate: "I was all careful to listen to them, when Virgil said to me, "Keep on looking, that it's almost time I didn't fight with you."

Original: Quand’io ’l senti’ a me parlar con ira, volsimi verso lui con tal vergogna, ch’ancor per la memoria mi si gira
Translate: "When I heard him speak to me with anger, I turned to him with such shame that he is still present in my mind."

Original: Qual è colui che suo dannaggio sogna, che sognando desidera sognare, sì che quel ch’è, come non fosse, agogna,
Translate: "As he who dreams of his harm, and dreaming would dream, so that he desires what is true as if it were not,"

Original: tal mi fec’io, non possendo parlare, che disïava scusarmi, e scusava me tuttavia, e nol mi credea fare
Translate: "so I did, not daring to speak, because I wanted to apologize and, even though I did not believe to do so, I was still doing so"

Original: "Maggior difetto men vergogna lava", disse ’l maestro, "che ’l tuo non è stato
Translate: The teacher said, "A lesser shame washes a greater guilt than yours has been.

Original: però d’ogne trestizia ti disgrava
Translate: then abandon all sadness

Original: E fa ragion ch’io ti sia sempre allato, se più avvien che fortuna t’accoglia  dove sien genti in simigliante piato:
Translate: "And be assured that I will always be at your side, if it ever happens again that destiny leads you where there are people fighting in this way: "

Original: ché voler ciò udire è bassa voglia"
Translate: "In fact, wanting to listen to certain brawls is vile will"

Original: Una medesma lingua pria mi morse, sì che mi tinse l’una e l’altra guancia, e poi la medicina mi riporse
Translate: "The same voice first rebuked me, making me blush both Goths, then gave me the medicine "

Original: così od’io che solea far la lancia d’Achille e del suo padre esser cagione prima di trista e poi di buona mancia
Translate: "so it seems to me that she used to make the spear of Achilles and his father Peleo, who was cause before sad and then of good assault "

Original: Noi demmo il dosso al misero vallone su per la ripa che ’l cinge dintorno, attraversando sanza alcun sermone
Translate: "We turned our backs to the sad pit of Malebolge, along the rocky embankment that surrounds it, and went without speaking."

Original: Quiv’era men che notte e men che giorno, sì che ’l viso m’andava innanzi poco
Translate: "Here was a twilight, so that I could push my gaze a little forward"

Original: ma io senti’ sonare un alto corno,  tanto ch’avrebbe ogne tuon fatto fioco,
Translate: "but I heard a horn ringing, so loud that it would overtake any thunder and that it directed my gaze, "

Original: che, contra sé la sua via seguitando, dirizzò li occhi miei tutti ad un loco
Translate: "that followed the opposite direction to that of sound, all towards a place"

Original: Dopo la dolorosa rotta, quando Carlo Magno perdé la santa gesta, non sonò sì terribilmente Orlando
Translate: "When Charlemagne lost his rear guard of paladins at Roncesvalles, Orlando did not sound his horn just as terrible"

Original: Poco portäi in là volta la testa, che me parve veder molte alte torri
Translate: "I turned my head a little further, so much so that I seemed to see many high towers"

Original: ond’io: "Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?"
Translate: "So I asked, "Master, tell me, what land is this?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Però che tu trascorri per le tenebre troppo da la lungi, avvien che poi nel maginare abborri
Translate: "And he to me: "Since you look in the darkness too far, it happens that then your thoughts are confused"

Original: Tu vedrai ben, se tu là ti congiungi, quanto ’l senso s’inganna di lontano
Translate: "You will see well, once you get there, how the senses are deceived by distance."

Original: però alquanto più te stesso pungi"
Translate: So hurry up and get there.

Original: Poi caramente mi prese per mano e disse:
Translate: "Then he took me by the hand with sweetness, saying: "

Original: "Pria che noi siam più avanti, acciò che ’l fatto men ti paia strano,
Translate: "Before we push ahead, and so that it seems less strange to you, "

Original: sappi che non son torri, ma giganti, e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa da l’umbilico in giuso tutti quanti"
Translate: "Know that these are not towers but giants, and they are all stuck in the rock around the well from the navel down."

Original: Come quando la nebbia si dissipa, lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura ciò che cela ’l vapor che l’aere stipa,
Translate: "As when the fog thins and the gaze little by little clearly distinguishes what the steam hides in the air,"

Original: così forando l’aura grossa e scura, più e più appressando ver’ la sponda, fuggiemi errore e cresciemi paura
Translate: "so, passing through the thick and dark air, as we approached the edge of the well, the error vanished in me and my fear grew"

Original: però che, come su la cerchia tonda Montereggion di torri si corona,

Translate: "And my guide to him: "O foolish soul, be content with the horn and vent with that when anger or another passion takes you"

Original: Facemmo adunque più lungo vïaggio, vòlti a sinistra

Translate: "I can't tell who the architect was, but someone tied his left arm in front of him. "

Original: e dietro il braccio destro  d’una catena che ’l tenea avvinto dal collo in giù, sì che ’n su lo scoperto si ravvolgëa infino al giro quinto

Original: "Questo superbo volle esser esperto di sua potenza contra ’l sommo Giove", disse ’l mio duca, "ond’elli ha cotal merto
Translate: "My teacher said, "This haughty man wanted to experience his strength against the high Jupiter, so he has such merit."

Original: Fïalte ha nome, e fece le gran prove quando i giganti fer paura a’ dèi
Translate: "His name is Fialte, and he took part in the battle when the giants frightened the gods"

Original: le braccia ch’el menò, già mai non move"

Translate: "And I to him: "If it is possible, I would like my eyes to see the immense Briareus"

Original: Quel che tu vuo’ veder, più là è molto ed è legato e fatto come questo, salvo che più feroce par nel volto"
Translate: "What you want to see is much farther, and is bound and of the same aspect of this, except that it seems more fierce in the face"

Translate: "Then I feared more than ever to die, and this fear would have been enough if I had not seen the chains."

Translate: "We then went forward and reached Anteo, who emerged from the rock five to the without the head."

Original: "O tu che ne la fortunata valle che fece Scipïon di gloria reda, quand’Anibàl co’ suoi diede le spalle,  recasti già mille leon per preda,
Translate: "It is you who in the lucky valley of Zama, who made Scipion heir of glory when Hannibal fled with his, made spoils a time of a thousand lions "

Original: e che, se fossi stato a l’alta guerra de’ tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda  ch’avrebber vinto i figli de la terra:
Translate: "and that, if I had taken part in the great war of your brothers, it is believed that they would win the sons of the Earth "

Original: mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo, dove Cocito la freddura serra
Translate: have no disdain to lay where the cold turns the lake of Cocito into ice

Translate: So bow down and don't turn your face away.

Translate: "He can still give you fame in the world, for he is alive and still awaits a long life, if divine grace does not call him to himself before the time"

Original: Così disse ’l maestro
Translate: That's what the teacher said.

Original: e quelli in fretta le man distese, e prese ’l duca mio, ond’Ercule sentì già grande stretta

Translate: "Virgilio, when he heard himself grasping, said to me, "Come near, that I may take you."

Original: poi fece sì ch’un fascio era elli e io

Original: Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda sotto 'l chinato, quando un nuvol vada sovr'essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:
Translate: "As the tower of Garisenda appears to those who look at it from below, when a cloud passes over it, so that it seems to hang forward."

Original: tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora ch’i’ avrei voluto ir per altra strada
Translate: "so it seemed to me that I was careful to see him bow, and it was so scary that I wanted to go another way"

Original: Ma lievemente al fondo che divora Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò

Original: io premerei di mio concetto il suco più pienamente

Translate: "In fact, describing the bottom of the entire universe is not a task to be taken lightly, nor proper to a childish language."

Translate: "But help me those goddesses who helped the poet Amphion to gird of the Thebes wall, so that my words are not dissimilar from reality."

Translate: "O sinners more than all others created for evil, than you are in the place of which it is difficult to speak, it would have been better if you had been sheep or goats in life."

Translate: "As soon as we were down in the dark pit, much lower than the giant Anteo's feet, and while I still looked at the high rock wall, I heard someone say to me: "

Translate: "Be careful where you walk. Try not to trample on the heads of those who were your brothers in life."

Original: E come a gracidar si sta la rana col muso fuor de l’acqua, quando sogna di spigolar sovente la villana,

Original: livide, insin là dove appar vergogna eran l’ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia, mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna

Original: Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia

Original: da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo tra lor testimonianza si procaccia

Translate: "After I had looked around for a while, I looked at my feet and saw two damn people so close that they had their hair mixed together."

Original: "Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti", diss’io, "chi siete?"
Translate: "I said, "Tell me, who are you who tighten the breasts so much?"

Translate: "And when they had raised their faces to me, their eyes, which were before weeping in the inside, dripping tears on their lips, and the frost pressed them, closing their eyes."

Original: Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse forte così
Translate: Never did an iron squeeze squeeze two woods so hard

Original: ond’ei come due becchi cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse

Original: E un ch’avea perduti ambo li orecchi per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe, disse:
Translate: "And another damned man, who had lost both his ears because of the cold, keeping his face low, said to me: "

Original: "Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?  Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due, la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue
Translate: "Why do you look at us with such insistence?If you want to know who these two are, know that they come from the valley from which the Bisenzio river descends, like their father Alberto."

Original: D’un corpo usciro
Translate: They were born from the same mother

Original: e tutta la Caina potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra degna più d’esser fitta in gelatina:
Translate: " and you can search all over Cain, without finding a soul more worthy of them to be stuck in this jelly "

Original: non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l’ombra con esso un colpo per la man d’Artù
Translate: Not the one to whom King Arthur broke his breast, and the shadow with a spear stroke.

Original: non Focaccia
Translate: Not Phoenix

Original: non questi che m’ingombra  col capo sì, ch’i’ non veggio oltre più, e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni
Translate: "not these who shade me with the head, to the point that I see no further and that it was called Sassolo Mascheroni"

Original: se tosco se’, ben sai omai chi fu
Translate: "If you're Tuscan, you know who it is."

Original: E perché non mi metti in più sermoni, sappi ch’i’ fu’ il Camiscion de’ Pazzi
Translate: "And so that you don't speak to me yet, know that I was Crazy Shirt."

Original: e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni"
Translate: And I wait here for Carlino to make my guilt appear less serious.

Original: Poscia vid’io mille visi cagnazzi fatti per freddo
Translate: "Then I saw a thousand faces poonazzi for the cold, "

Original: onde mi vien riprezzo, e verrà sempre, de’ gelati guazzi
Translate: "which I still feel disgust for, and will always come to me, seeing frozen waters"

Original: E mentre ch’andavamo inver’ lo mezzo al quale ogne gravezza si rauna, e io tremava ne l’etterno rezzo
Translate: "And as we progressed toward the center to which all the burdens of the Earth tend, and I trembled in that eternal cold."

Original: se voler fu o destino o fortuna, non so
Translate: "I don't know if it was by my will, or by fate or luck,"

Original: ma, passeggiando tra le teste, forte percossi ’l piè nel viso ad una

Translate: "This crying cried out to me, "Why did you tread me down? If you didn't come to increase the punishment for Montaperti, why are you here torment me?"

Translate: "And I: "Master, now wait for me here so that I solve my doubt about this one"

Original: poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta"
Translate: Then you'll hurry me how much and how you want to do it.

Translate: "My guide stood still, and I said to the damned one who was still blaspheming hard: "Who are you, who rebukes others like that?"

Translate: "He answered, "Who are you, rather, who walks through the Ancestor by hitting the heads of others, so that, if I were alive, it would be too serious an outrage?"

Translate: "My answer was, "I am alive, and it may be useful for you, if you seek fame, for me to include your name in my verses."

Original: Ed elli a me: "Del contrario ho io brama
Translate: And that to me: "I have desire to the contrary

Original: Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna, ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama"
Translate: " Get out of here and don't bother me any further, since your flattery is worth nothing in this low Hell"

Translate: "So I grabbed him by the collar and said, "You'll do well to tell me your name, or you won't have a hair left."

Translate: "I already had his hair twisted in my hand and had torn several strands of it, while he latrified with his eyes turned down, when another cried out: "

Translate: "I said, "I don't want you to talk anymore, you evil traitor."

Original: ch’a la tua onta io porterò di te vere novelle"

Original: "Va via", rispuose, "e ciò che tu vuoi conta
Translate: He said, "Go away and tell me what you want."

Original: ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi, di quel ch’ebbe or così la lingua pronta
Translate: "but don't be silent, if you ever get out of here, the name of the one who had such a loose tongue."

Original: El piange qui l’argento de’ Franceschi: "Io vidi", potrai dir, "quel da Duera là dove i peccatori stanno freschi"
Translate: "He regrets here the silver of the French: you can say, "I saw Buoso da Duera, where sinners are fresh"""

Original: Se fossi domandato "Altri chi v’era?", tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera
Translate: "And if they ask you, "Who else was there?", know that there is Tesauro dei Beccheria next door, to whom the Florentines cut off their heads."

Original: Gianni de’ Soldanier credo che sia più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello, ch’aprì Faenza quando si dormia"
Translate: "I believe that later there is Gianni dei Soldanieri, who opened the gates of Faenza during the night, along with Gano di Maganza and Tebaldello de' Zambrasi"

Original: Noi eravam partiti già da ello, ch’io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca, sì che l’un capo a l’altro era cappello
Translate: "We had already gotten away from that damned man, when I saw two more frozen in a hole, so that the head of one was a hat to the other."

Original: e come ’l pan per fame si manduca, così ’l sovran li denti a l’altro pose là ’ve ’l cervel s’aggiugne con la nuca:
