Original: non altrimenti Tidëo si rose le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno, che quei faceva il teschio e l’altre cose
Translate: "Tideo didn't bite the temples in Menalippo in a different way for hate than that damned skull and other parts did."

Original: "O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi, dimmi ’l perché", diss’io, "per tal convegno,
Translate: "I said, "O you who show such a beastly hatred for the one you are devouring, tell me the reason for this covenant:"

Original: che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi, sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca, nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,
Translate: "if you are right to complain about him, knowing who you are and his sin, I will return you once you return to Earth, "

Original: se quella con ch’io parlo non si secca"
Translate: provided that the language in which I speak does not dry out

Original: La bocca sollevò dal fiero pasto quel peccator, forbendola a' capelli del capo ch'elli avea di retro guasto
Translate: "That sinner lifted up his mouth from the fierce meal, cleaning it with the hair of his head that he had penetrated from behind."

Original: Poi cominciò: "Tu vuo’ ch’io rinovelli disperato dolor che ’l cor mi preme già pur pensando, pria ch’io ne favelli
Translate: "Then he began: "You want me to renew a desperate pain that oppresses my heart already only to think about it, before I speak about it."

Original: Ma se le mie parole esser dien seme che frutti infamia al traditor ch’i’ rodo, parlare e lagrimar vedrai insieme
Translate: "But if my words are to be a seed that bears infamy to the traitor that I bite, you will see me speaking and weeping at the same time."

Original: Io non so chi tu se’ né per che modo venuto se’ qua giù
Translate: "I don't know who you are, nor how you got down here."

Original: ma fiorentino mi sembri veramente quand’io t’odo
Translate: But you look really Florentine to me when I hear you talking.

Original: Tu dei saper ch’i’ fui conte Ugolino, e questi è l’arcivescovo Ruggieri: or ti dirò perché i son tal vicino
Translate: You must know that I was Count Ugolino and this is Archbishop Ruggieri: now I will explain why I am such a beastly neighbor to him

Original: Che per l’effetto de’ suo’ mai pensieri, fidandomi di lui, io fossi preso e poscia morto, dir non è mestieri
Translate: "It doesn't have to be said that because of his evil plans, trusting him, I was captured and then killed."

Original: però quel che non puoi avere inteso, cioè come la morte mia fu cruda, udirai, e saprai s’e’ m’ ha offeso
Translate: "Therefore thou shalt hear what thou couldst not have heard, that is, how terrible my death was; and thou shalt judge whether he hath offended me."

Original: Breve pertugio dentro da la Muda, la qual per me ha ’l titol de la fame, e che conviene ancor ch’altrui si chiuda,
Translate: "A narrow slit inside the Tower of the Muda, which today is called for me Tower of the Fame and which will have to accommodate other prisoners, "

Original: m’avea mostrato per lo suo forame più lune già, quand’io feci ’l mal sonno che del futuro mi squarciò ’l velame
Translate: "He had already shown me through his opening many moons, when I had the bad dream that revealed the future to me."

Original: Questi pareva a me maestro e donno, cacciando il lupo e ’ lupicini al monte per che i Pisan veder Lucca non ponno
Translate: "This seemed to me lord of the brigade and guide of a hunting trip, on the trail of the wolf and his little ones, on the mountain for which the Pisans cannot see Lucca"

Original: Con cagne magre, studïose e conte Gualandi con Sismondi e con Lanfranchi s’avea messi dinanzi da la fronte
Translate: "He had put the Gualandi, the Sismondi and the Lanfranchi in front of the advanced front, with sleazy, hungry and trained bitches."

Original: In picciol corso mi parieno stanchi lo padre e ’ figli, e con l’agute scane mi parea lor veder fender li fianchi
Translate: "After a short run the father and the children seemed tired, and I thought I saw the bitches sinking sharp fangs in their hips."

Original: Quando fui desto innanzi la dimane, pianger senti’ fra ’l sonno i miei figliuoli ch’eran con meco, e dimandar del pane
Translate: "When I woke up before dawn, I heard my little children with me crying in their sleep and asking for bread."

Original: Ben se’ crudel, se tu già non ti duoli pensando ciò che ’l mio cor s’annunziava
Translate: "You're really cruel, if you don't already feel pain thinking about the omen I had in my heart"

Original: e se non piangi, di che pianger suoli?  Già eran desti, e l’ora s’appressava che ’l cibo ne solëa essere addotto, e per suo sogno ciascun dubitava
Translate: "and if you don't cry, what usually makes you cry?They were awake by now and the time was approaching when we were usually given food, even if everyone doubted it for his dream."

Original: e io senti’ chiavar l’uscio di sotto a l’orribile torre
Translate: And I heard that underneath the horrible tower the door was nailed.

Original: ond’io guardai nel viso a’ mie’ figliuoi sanza far motto
Translate: So I looked at my children's faces without talking.

Original: Io non piangëa, sì dentro impetrai: piangevan elli
Translate: "I didn't weep, so much I was relentless in my soul: they wept, "

Original: e Anselmuccio mio disse: "Tu guardi sì, padre
Translate: "and my Anselmuccio said, "You have such a look, Father."

Original: che hai?"
Translate: "What do you got?""

Original: Perciò non lagrimai né rispuos’io tutto quel giorno né la notte appresso, infin che l’altro sol nel mondo uscìo
Translate: " Then I didn't weep or answer, all that day and the next night, until the sun came out the next morning."

Original: Come un poco di raggio si fu messo nel doloroso carcere, e io scorsi per quattro visi il mio aspetto stesso,  ambo le man per lo dolor mi morsi
Translate: "As soon as a shy ray of sun was penetrated into the painful prison, and I saw in those four faces my identical slender appearance, I bit both hands from pain."

Original: ed ei, pensando ch’io ’l fessi per voglia di manicar, di sùbito levorsi  e disser:
Translate: "and they, thinking that I did it out of the will to eat, rose up immediately and said: "

Original: "Padre, assai ci fia men doglia se tu mangi di noi: tu ne vestisti queste misere carni, e tu le spoglia"
Translate: ""Father, there will be much less painful if you eat our bodies: you have given us these wretched meats, and you have stripped us of them"""

Original: Queta’ mi allor per non farli più tristi
Translate: Then I calmed down so as not to make them sad.

Original: lo dì e l’altro stemmo tutti muti
Translate: That day, and the next day, we all remained silent.

Original: ahi dura terra, perché non t’apristi?
Translate: " alas, cruel land, why didn't you swallow us?"

Original: Poscia che fummo al quarto dì venuti, Gaddo mi si gittò disteso a’ piedi, dicendo: "Padre mio, ché non m’aiuti?"
Translate: "When we arrived on the fourth day, Gaddo fell before my feet, saying, "My Father, why don't you help me?"

Original: Quivi morì
Translate: Here he died

Original: e come tu mi vedi, vid’io cascar li tre ad uno ad uno tra ’l quinto dì e ’l sesto
Translate: "And as thou seest me, so I saw one by one the other three fall, between the fifth and the sixth day."

Original: ond’io mi diedi,  già cieco, a brancolar sovra ciascuno, e due dì li chiamai, poi che fur morti
Translate: "So I, already blind and dying, went crawling over their bodies, and called them for two days after their death."

Original: Poscia, più che 'l dolor, poté 'l digiuno"
Translate: " Later, more than pain, he killed my hunger"

Original: Quand’ebbe detto ciò, con li occhi torti riprese ’l teschio misero co’ denti, che furo a l’osso, come d’un can, forti
Translate: "When he had said this, twisting his eyes, he began to burn the poor skull with his teeth, which were as strong as a dog's on that bone."

Original: Ahi Pisa, vituperio de le genti del bel paese là dove 'l sì suona,
Translate: "Alas, Pisa, shame of the peoples of the beautiful country where the "yes" resounds, "

Original: poi che i vicini a te punir son lenti,  muovasi la Capraia e la Gorgona, e faccian siepe ad Arno in su la foce, sì ch’elli annieghi in te ogne persona
Translate: "For the neighbors are slow to punish you, and the Capraia and the Gorgona move, and block the mouth of the Arno, so that the river drowns every one of your inhabitants."

Original: Che se ’l conte Ugolino aveva voce d’aver tradita te de le castella, non dovei tu i figliuoi porre a tal croce
Translate: "In fact, if Count Ugolino was suspected of betraying you by surrendering the castles, you would not have had to condemn your children to such torture."

Original: Innocenti facea l’età novella, novella Tebe, Uguiccione e ’l Brigata e li altri due che ’l canto suso appella
Translate: "The young age, or novel Thebes, made Uguccione and the Brigade innocent, and the other two whom the song mentioned earlier"

Original: Noi passammo oltre, là ’ve la gelata ruvidamente un’altra gente fascia, non volta in giù, ma tutta riversata
Translate: "We passed by, where the ice cruelly imprisons other damned, not facing down but upwards."

Original: Lo pianto stesso lì pianger non lascia, e ’l duol che truova in su li occhi rintoppo, si volge in entro a far crescer l’ambascia
Translate: "There the weeping itself does not let them weep, and the pain that finds an impediment on the eyes goes back to make the anguish grow"

Original: ché le lagrime prime fanno groppo, e sì come visiere di cristallo, rïempion sotto ’l ciglio tutto il coppo
Translate: "in fact the first tears freeze and form like crystal visors, which fill the entire cavity of the eye under the eye"

Original: E avvegna che, sì come d’un callo, per la freddura ciascun sentimento cessato avesse del mio viso stallo,
Translate: "And even though for the cold every feeling had left my face, just like a callus, "

Original: già mi parea sentire alquanto vento
Translate: I thought I heard some wind:

Original: per ch’io: "Maestro mio, questo chi move? non è qua giù ogne vapore spento?"
Translate: "So I asked: "Master, who produces this wind? Isn't any atmospheric event absent down here?"

Original: Ond’elli a me: "Avaccio sarai dove di ciò ti farà l’occhio la risposta, veggendo la cagion che ’l fiato piove"
Translate: "And he to me: "Ben soon you will be at the point where the eye will give you the answer, seeing the cause that produces this phenomenon"

Original: E un de’ tristi de la fredda crosta gridò a noi: "O anime crudeli tanto che data v’è l’ultima posta,
Translate: "And one of the damned imprisoned in the ice cried out to us: "O cruel souls, to the extent that you are assigned the last Circle, "

Original: levatemi dal viso i duri veli, sì ch’ïo sfoghi ’l duol che ’l cor m’impregna, un poco, pria che ’l pianto si raggeli"
Translate: "Get the ice crusts out of my face, so that I can vent a little the pain that oppresses my heart, before the tears come back to freeze"

Original: Per ch’io a lui: "Se vuo’ ch’i’ ti sovvegna, dimmi chi se’, e s’io non ti disbrigo, al fondo de la ghiaccia ir mi convegna"
Translate: "Then I said to him, "If you want me to help you, tell me who you are and if I don't free your eyes, may I go all the way to the bottom of the ice."

Original: Rispuose adunque: "I’ son frate Alberigo
Translate: Then he answered, "I am Brother Alberigo."

Original: i’ son quel da le frutta del mal orto, che qui riprendo dattero per figo"
Translate: "I am the fruit of the wicked garden, which here I obtain dates in exchange for figs."

Original: "Oh", diss’io lui, "or se’ tu ancor morto?"
Translate: I said to him, "Oh, are you dead already?"

Original: Ed elli a me: "Come ’l mio corpo stea nel mondo sù, nulla scïenza porto
Translate: And he to me: "No idea of how my body is on Earth."

Original: Cotal vantaggio ha questa Tolomea, che spesse volte l’anima ci cade innanzi ch’Atropòs mossa le dea
Translate: This Toloma has this advantage: often the soul falls before Atropus has put an end to life

Original: E perché tu più volontier mi rade le ’nvetrïate lagrime dal volto, sappie che, tosto che l’anima trade  come fec’ïo,
Translate: "And so that you may more willingly remove the frosted tears from my face, know that as soon as the soul performs the betrayal as I did, "

Original: il corpo suo l’è tolto da un demonio, che poscia il governa mentre che ’l tempo suo tutto sia vòlto
Translate: His body is taken from a demon who later governs him until the time of his life is finished.

Original: Ella ruina in sì fatta cisterna
Translate: It falls into this hellhole

Original: e forse pare ancor lo corpo suso de l’ombra che di qua dietro mi verna
Translate: and perhaps the body of the soul that winters here behind me is still in the world

Original: Tu ’l dei saper, se tu vien pur mo giuso: elli è ser Branca Doria, e son più anni poscia passati ch’el fu sì racchiuso"
Translate: "You must know, if you come here only now: he is Ser Branca Doria, and it is many years since he ended up in this place."

Original: "Io credo", diss’io lui, "che tu m’inganni
Translate: I said to him, "I think you deceive me."

Original: ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche, e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni"
Translate: "For Branca Doria is not yet dead, and eats, drinks, sleeps and wears clothes"

Original: "Nel fosso sù", diss’el, "de’ Malebranche, là dove bolle la tenace pece, non era ancora giunto Michel Zanche,  che questi lasciò il diavolo in sua vece nel corpo suo,
Translate: "He said: "Michele Zanche had not yet arrived in the Bolgia dei Malebranche, where the pitch viscose boils, that he left the devil in his place "

Original: ed un suo prossimano che ’l tradimento insieme con lui fece
Translate: and so one of his accomplices who made treachery with him

Original: Ma distendi oggimai in qua la mano
Translate: But you're laying your hand here.

Original: aprimi li occhi"
E io non gliel’apersi
Translate: And I didn't open them.

Original: e cortesia fu lui esser villano
Translate: and being a villain was a courtesy to him

Original: Ahi Genovesi, uomini diversi d'ogne costume e pien d'ogne magagna, perché non siete voi del mondo spersi?
Translate: "Alas, Genoese, alien men from all good customs and full of all vice, why are you not scattered in the world?"

Original: Ché col peggiore spirto di Romagna trovai di voi un tal, che per sua opra in anima in Cocito già si bagna,
Translate: "In fact, along with the worst spirit of Romagna, I found your fellow citizen, so that by his actions his soul is already bathed in Cocytus, "

Original: e in corpo par vivo ancor di sopra
Translate: and his body still seems alive on Earth

Original: "Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni verso di noi
Translate: The banners of the king of Hell draw near to us

Original: però dinanzi mira", disse ’l maestro mio, "se tu ’l discerni"
Translate: "So look before you, if you can see it," said my teacher."

Original: Come quando una grossa nebbia spira, o quando l’emisperio nostro annotta, par di lungi un molin che ’l vento gira,  veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta
Translate: "Like when there is a thick fog or when night falls in our hemisphere, and a windmill appears in the distance, so then I seemed to see such a building."

Original: poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro al duca mio, ché non lì era altra grotta
Translate: "So by the wind I sheltered behind my guide, since there was no other refuge."

Original: Già era, e con paura il metto in metro, là dove l’ombre tutte eran coperte, e trasparien come festuca in vetro
Translate: "I now found myself, and I write it with fear in my verses, in the area where the souls were completely buried in the ice, and they looked like straws in the glass."

Original: Altre sono a giacere
Translate: "Some are lying down, "

Original: altre stanno erte, quella col capo e quella con le piante
Translate: "Others are straight, sometimes with their heads high and sometimes with their feet"

Original: altra, com’arco, il volto a’ piè rinverte
Translate: "Others still carry their faces to their feet, bending like an arch"

Original: Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante, ch’al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi la creatura ch’ebbe il bel sembiante,
Translate: "When we were advanced to the point where my teacher seemed opportune to show me the creature that was so beautiful, "

Original: d’innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi, "Ecco Dite", dicendo, "ed ecco il loco ove convien che di fortezza t’armi"
Translate: "He took off before me and made me stop, saying, "Behold, say, and here is the place where you need to arm yourself with courage."

Original: Com’io divenni allor gelato e fioco, nol dimandar, lettor, ch’i’ non lo scrivo, però ch’ogne parlar sarebbe poco
Translate: "Don't ask, reader, how I at that time froze and mute: I don't write it, for every word would be inadequate."

Original: Io non mori’ e non rimasi vivo
Translate: I didn't die and I didn't live:

Original: pensa oggimai per te, s’ hai fior d’ingegno, qual io divenni, d’uno e d’altro privo
Translate: "think of you now, if you have any ingenuity, how I became in that state suspended between life and death"

Original: Lo ’mperador del doloroso regno da mezzo ’l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia
Translate: The Emperor of the Kingdom of Pain came out of the ice to the belt

Original: e più con un gigante io mi convegno,  che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia:
Translate: And there is greater proportion between me and a giant than between the giants and his arms:

Original: vedi oggimai quant’esser dee quel tutto ch’a così fatta parte si confaccia
Translate: "See now, with respect to that part of the body, what the total dimensions of that being must be"

Original: S’el fu sì bel com’elli è ora brutto, e contra ’l suo fattore alzò le ciglia, ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto
Translate: "If he was as beautiful as he is now ugly, and in spite of this he dared to rebel against his Creator, it is right that all evil should come from him."

Original: Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia quand’io vidi tre facce a la sua testa
Translate: "Oh, how surprised I was when I saw that his head had three faces."

Original: L’una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia
Translate: One was in the middle and it was red

Original: l’altr’eran due, che s’aggiugnieno a questa sovresso ’l mezzo di ciascuna spalla, e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:
Translate: "the others were two and joined at the first half of each shoulder, and joined at the back of the head:"

Original: e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla
Translate: the right seemed to me between white and yellow

Original: la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali vegnon di là onde ’l Nilo s’avvalla
Translate: the left was of the color of those who come from the land where the Nile enters a valley

Original: Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand’ali, quanto si convenia a tanto uccello: vele di mar non vid’io mai cotali
Translate: "Under each face two great wings came forth, proportioned to such a great being: I have never seen sails of ships so wide."

Original: Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello era lor modo
Translate: "They weren't feathered, but they looked like bats."

Original: e quelle svolazzava, sì che tre venti si movean da ello:  quindi Cocito tutto s’aggelava
Translate: "and Lucifer slammed them, producing by himself three winds: because of them, all the lake of Cocitus was frozen."

Original: Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti gocciava ’l pianto e sanguinosa bava
Translate: "He cried with six eyes and tears dripping on the three minds, mixed with a bloody slime."

Original: Da ogne bocca dirompea co’ denti un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla, sì che tre ne facea così dolenti
Translate: "In each of the three mouths he tore a sinner with his teeth, as if it were a chisel, so that he tormented three at the same time."

Original: A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla verso ’l graffiar, che talvolta la schiena rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla
Translate: "For the sinner in the center the being bit was nothing compared to being scratched, to the point that sometimes his back remained all skinned"

Original: "Quell’anima là sù c’ ha maggior pena", disse ’l maestro, "è Giuda Scarïotto, che ’l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena
Translate: "The teacher said, "The damned one up there who suffers a greater pain is Judas Iscariot, who holds his head inside Lucifer's mouth and hangs his legs out."

Original: De li altri due c’ hanno il capo di sotto, quel che pende dal nero ceffo è Bruto:
Translate: "Of the other two who have their heads turned down, what hangs from the black face is Brutus: "

Original: vedi come si storce, e non fa motto
Translate: See how it twists without saying anything

Original: e l’altro è Cassio, che par sì membruto
Translate: "The other is Cassius, who looks so sturdy"

Original: Ma la notte risurge, e oramai è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto"
Translate: "But it is almost night, and we must go now, for we have seen all things."

Original: Com’a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai
Translate: "As Virgil wanted, I embraced his neck."

Original: ed el prese di tempo e loco poste, e quando l’ali fuoro aperte assai,  appigliò sé a le vellute coste
Translate: "and he waited for the time and the opportune place, and when the monster's wings were quite open he clinged to his hairy hips."

Original: di vello in vello giù discese poscia tra ’l folto pelo e le gelate croste
Translate: "and then he went downstairs, holding on to his locks, passing between his thick hair and the frozen crust of Cocito"

Original: Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l’anche, lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
Translate: "When we arrived at the point where the thigh of the joint in the pelvis, at the height of the femur, Virgil, with fatigue and shortness of breath, "

Original: volse la testa ov’elli avea le zanche, e aggrappossi al pel com’om che sale, sì che ’n inferno i’ credea tornar anche
Translate: "She turned her head where Lucifer had legs, and clinged to her hair like a climber, so that I believed we would return to Hell again."

Original: "Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale", disse ’l maestro, ansando com’uom lasso, "conviensi dipartir da tanto male"
Translate: "The master, groaning like a fatigued man, said, "Hold on, for we must go away from so bad by going up these stairs."

Original: Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d’un sasso e puose me in su l’orlo a sedere
Translate: "Then he went out through a crack in the rock, and made me sit on the edge of the opening."

Original: appresso porse a me l’accorto passo
Translate: So he carefully directed the step toward me

Original: Io levai li occhi e credetti vedere Lucifero com’io l’avea lasciato, e vidili le gambe in sù tenere
Translate: "I looked up and thought I saw Lucifer as I had left him, but I saw him holding his legs up."

Original: e s’io divenni allora travagliato, la gente grossa il pensi, che non vede qual è quel punto ch’io avea passato
Translate: "and if then I was perplexed, the ignorant people think it, that they did not understand the point that I had gone beyond."

Original: "Lèvati sù", disse ’l maestro, "in piede: la via è lunga e ’l cammino è malvagio, e già il sole a mezza terza riede"
Translate: "The teacher said, "Get up on your feet: the way is long and the path is uncomfortable, and the sun is already halfway through the third hour."

Original: Non era camminata di palagio là ’v’eravam, ma natural burella ch’avea mal suolo e di lume disagio
Translate: "The point where we were was not an easy path as in a palace, but an underground cavity that had impervious soil and little light"

Original: "Prima ch’io de l’abisso mi divella, maestro mio", diss’io quando fui dritto, "a trarmi d’erro un poco mi favella:
Translate: "When I was raised I said, 'My teacher, before I leave the hellish abyss, speak to me a little to solve a doubt:'

Original: ov’è la ghiaccia? e questi com’è fitto sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc’ora, da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?"
Translate: where is the ice? and how can Lucifer be so upside down? and how could the sun have traveled so quickly from evening to morning?

Original: Ed elli a me: "Tu imagini ancora d’esser di là dal centro, ov’io mi presi al pel del vermo reo che ’l mondo fóra
Translate: "And he to me: "You still think you are beyond the center of the Earth, where I cling to the fur of the horrendous animal that spoils the world"

Original: Di là fosti cotanto quant’io scesi
Translate: You were there until I came down.

Original: quand’io mi volsi, tu passasti ’l punto al qual si traggon d’ogne parte i pesi
Translate: "When I turned around, you crossed the point towards which all the world's weights tend"

Original: E se’ or sotto l’emisperio giunto ch’è contraposto a quel che la gran secca coverchia,
Translate: "And now you have come under the hemisphere, which is opposite to that which covers the land that has emerged, "

Original: e sotto ’l cui colmo consunto  fu l’uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca
Translate: "and where, under the highest point of the heavenly hemisphere, the man who was born and lived without sin was killed: "

Original: tu haï i piedi in su picciola spera che l’altra faccia fa de la Giudecca
Translate: You have your feet on a small sphere that has the opposite face in Judecca

Original: Qui è da man, quando di là è sera
Translate: "Here is morning, when in the other hemisphere is evening"

Original: e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo, fitto è ancora sì come prim’era
Translate: "and Lucifer, who with his hair made us from a ladder, is confiscated exactly as he was before."

Original: Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo
Translate: He fell down from the sky this way

Original: e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse, per paura di lui fé del mar velo,  e venne a l’emisperio nostro
Translate: "and the earth, which first emerged from the waters in the southern hemisphere, hid beneath the sea for fear of him, and came into our hemisphere."

Original: e forse per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto quella ch’appar di qua, e sù ricorse"
Translate: "and perhaps, to escape from him, the one that appears here left this empty space and re-emerged in the southern hemisphere "

Original: Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto tanto quanto la tomba si distende, che non per vista, ma per suono è noto  d’un ruscelletto
Translate: "There is a place down there as far from Belzebu as the underground cavity extends, which you cannot see but from which you can hear the sound of a little river. "

Original: che quivi discende per la buca d’un sasso, ch’elli ha roso, col corso ch’elli avvolge, e poco pende
Translate: "that descends here through a cavity which it has dug into the rock along its course, which has little slope"

Original: Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo
Translate: The master and I entered that hidden path to return to the light of the sun

Original: e sanza cura aver d’alcun riposo,  salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo,
Translate: "and without taking a moment's rest we went up high, he first and I behind, "

Original: tanto ch’i’ vidi de le cose belle che porta ’l ciel, per un pertugio tondo
Translate: until I saw the stars of heaven through a circular opening

Original: E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle
Translate: And from there we went out to see the stars.
